output: Mr. President! I very much welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, namely, to identify the root causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting illnesses.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, we fall into a very one-sided approach, regardless of whether we are discussing nutrient profiles, food labeling, or even in certain areas of the White Paper.
We are, in effect, attempting to resolve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
And I believe that it is a fundamentally flawed political approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many change requests demonstrate that this does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or alternatively, balanced and unbalanced diets.
That should be our approach.
The causes of inadequate nutrition are multifaceted.

To rectify this by attempting to guide consumers through product labeling or even resorting to advertising bans or regulations, or by implementing different value-added tax rates, will not lead us to the goal.

I believe that everything we do here does not wish to preempt the debate on the labelling regulation, but everything we do should be framed under the heading: What can we do to motivate consumers to reflect on their eating habits?
In my view, a traffic-light labeling system that suggests I am now facing a good or bad product is more an instrument of disempowerment than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
Therefore, I desire a balanced approach here and the recognition that we will not progress further through the path of product policy alone.
Mr. President, Madam Vice-President, esteemed colleagues! The budgetary control has no new topics.
We are satisfied with the old and would also be satisfied with advancements on the old topics.

Five Points of Priority
Our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial oversight.
We do not want to be where we are today in two years’ time, and therefore this point is extremely important to us.
The second point: The reliability declaration for the overall budget according to the tiered control procedure, involving the national audit offices.
It would be desirable if we could achieve decisive progress here within the last six months, which is all that remains for the Commission, or at the very least agree on a common path.
One does, after all, have to be modest as a budget controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We must provide greater assistance to the lower levels of administration within member states in the implementation of EU law.
It becomes apparent that they are completely overwhelmed by large portions of EU law, which explains the high error rates.
The fourth point is external assistance. Here, I would primarily like to address Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been in Kosovo, and I would now like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the discharge procedure.
I believe that we have remained far below the possibilities of the European Union to date and that we urgently need to revisit this.
The fifth point would be the improvement of cooperation among member states in the fight against fraud.
We have homework, primarily for the members of the council.
Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the regulation for fraud prevention, in November, and then we must collectively consider how to proceed if we wished to achieve better results in this area.
That has been our wish until now.
Mr. President! India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, particularly also at the level of what are known as ordinary people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, etc. A brief note on this: it is also relevant to the Commission’s legislative program, which we discussed previously.
In global air traffic, we need effective safety regulations—regulations that achieve something, and not mere alibi measures.
It would therefore be a reasonable, genuinely necessary measure, to finally abolish these pointless liquidity regulations and devise something better.
Mr. President! I voted in favor of the resolution because it is a clear call to the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled by the questionable, indeed fraudulent, parliamentary elections of September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of opposition and civil society.
Simultaneously, we have today urged the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens upon entry into the Schengen Area, thereby preventing a growing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
I would like to object, first of all, to the spirit of a statement heard just moments ago, that foreigners were flooding the labor market.
Secondly, I would have wished for a clearer, more definitive report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the European Union's capacity for social cohesion can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States, and the CJEU and not be satisfied with merely demanding a balance between fundamental rights and the freedoms of the internal market, free movement.
That changes nothing. Social fundamental rights, just like personal freedoms, are human rights that must not be restricted by flexibilities of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time for the introduction of a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU Treaties.
And it is time to amend the Posted Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements may not be limited as minimum requirements.
Mr. President! I would like to join the thanks to the rapporteur, Doris Pack, which many colleagues have already rightly expressed.
We have with her someone who, hopefully, will not pour out their heart and soul, but will invest a great deal of heart and soul in this space.
I am pleased with you and the colleagues who also said so, that there have been some advances, also in the area of police cooperation.
That is important so that actual life on the ground can also function within reasonable parameters.

However, I still believe that we must repeatedly remind our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that they themselves, from their side, still need to contribute considerably, perhaps even more than is currently being contributed in certain areas.
Internal collaboration, the willingness to engage in this internal collaboration among ethnic groups, is something that we must consistently demand.
It is not a matter of everyone trying to forge their own path.
And inclusion in the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is also important.
Madam President! The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not become as great as it has.
We need to ensure it is reduced in size.
In this context, the citizen's ombudsman has an important role to play, particularly when and where he performs it well.
It is primarily also a matter of reckoning with the engagement and judiciousness of the Citizens' Advocate.
It is about ensuring that we do not raise expectations that cannot then be met.

It is also, on the other hand, about ensuring that wherever irregularities have occurred within the administrative bodies of the European Union, they are addressed and, where possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can secure and satisfy citizens.
Past practice has demonstrated that the citizen’s representative undertakes this task seriously and effectively.
We can only hope that this remains the case, and we thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
I am a little nervous.
Dear colleagues, ten years after the implementation of the monetary union, Europe finds itself in a severe crisis.
Banks collapse or are propped up with billions from the state budget, sales plummet, and millions of people fear for their jobs and their future.
But not only has the market failed, also the prevailing political policies appear incapable of learning from their mistakes.

We are of the opinion that you do not particularly wish to distinguish yourself with such asides. We are of the opinion that grave errors were committed in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.

Such an error is the structural separation of monetary and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing taxation and expenditure policy to at least some degree.
I believe that the economic imbalances within the Eurozone have intensified considerably.
What we need now is, in fact, better coordination of the economy and, above all, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, furthermore, tax havens must be closed and capital flows finally controlled again.
The second significant error lies in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who believes a consolidation of households is indispensable in times like these evidently lives in a different world. Nothing would be more disastrous than responding to this economic crisis with public austerity measures as well.
The Stability Pact has definitively demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our view, what is needed is an investment offensive to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of those socially disadvantaged in Europe.
A third error lies in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic oversight and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for the democratic control of the European Central Bank, and furthermore, we demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, whereby growth and employment must be promoted at least equally with price stability in the future.
The present crisis also offers an opportunity for far-reaching reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Council, esteemed colleagues! Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has further intensified the crisis in this sector, and member states are currently working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key sector.
Therefore, we also need European solutions to manage the crisis for this key European industry.
Almost all automotive corporations have European structures.

And in order to make necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars – as has been mentioned several times here today – in order to be able to implement environmentally friendly and fuel-efficient technologies, automakers need public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supplier industry as well—this is very important—must not be forgotten in this context.
Particularly in the supplier industry, it is small and medium-sized enterprises where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
During the previous plenary session, the President of the Council proposed protecting key industries.

A good suggestion.
As I see it, if one consistently thinks this suggestion through to its conclusion, it means a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
And this would certainly be a useful tool.
But this protective measure is currently being challenged by the European Commission.

And given my question to the Commission: Will the European Commission maintain its position regarding legal action despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or is this course of action being reconsidered in light of the crisis?
Mr. President, Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr. Vice-President of the European Commission, dear colleagues! Indeed, it has become something of a tradition to observe,
We must understand that in the relationship between expenditure at the European level and administration at the national level, a declaration of assurance cannot be repeatedly issued.

I can recall conversations with the former President of the Federal Audit Office, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, due to the structures in place, it is simply not possible to provide a reliability declaration.
Therefore, we should consider together how this instrument can be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a declaration of reliability, when justified, can also be achieved.
We need to differentiate a few things from one another.
Firstly, a budget encompassing approximately 95 subsidies is significantly more susceptible to fraud than a national budget, or a regional, or a municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states, who have, in the new financial period, demanded significantly more autonomy from us, because the criticism of the previous funding period was that it was too centrally controlled.
That naturally also means that responsibility for the money must be assumed regionally and nationally.
And a third topic I would like to address briefly.
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These too are things that are readily lumped together.
I, too, am annoyed when EU funds are used to support things that are not strictly necessary.
That was not fraud, that was wastefulness.

Therefore, those responsible for projects, particularly in the area of structural policy, have a responsibility towards the Member States to ensure that money is not wasted and that only projects are funded that genuinely create added value for the region.
Therefore, I believe we should certainly also consider converting parts of structural policy to interest-free loans.
For if member states have to repay, then they only fund what they genuinely need. Thank you very much!
It is not only I who find it difficult to concur with this burgeoning self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to managing the financial market crisis.
goes, for if this EU were a functioning democracy, one would first have to address the question of accountability, how this could have come to pass.
It is simply not true that all the problems we now face are like a tsunami, something dictated by the laws of nature, but rather they are made by human hands.
Amidst all the regulatory zeal unleashed by this Union, one wonders: Why was action not taken, to a significant extent, when banks began to cross national borders?
Why was no action taken despite appropriate warnings as the derivatives infiltrated?
I recall very well that Nobel laureate Josef Stiglitz was here, addressing all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That is where one must begin, because recognizing one's own mistakes is, in itself, the only key to finding solutions in the future.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner! My question concerns your opinion on the introduction of the euro as a second currency in Iceland and Hungary.
Do you believe that this could resolve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is: Do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives that could then be used to strengthen the banks' equity?
My third question is: don’t you believe that a reduction in value-added tax would accordingly support imports, particularly from China and India?
Wouldn't it be more sensible to consider tax reductions for our businesses and for our employees, that investment premiums are paid, that progressive depreciation is adjusted accordingly?

The central aim is to increase primarily low-value assets by a factor of 10, so that fictitious profits are not taxed, the money remains within the ventures, and wages can also be paid better as a result.
Madam President! The comprehensive report highlights how many human rights violations occur around the world every day.
This is particularly alarming 60 years after the proclamation of the Charter of Human Rights and calls on us to redouble our efforts.
For this reason, I would also like to advocate for establishing the current Sub-Committee on Human Rights as the main committee.
Today, we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jia, who advocates for human rights and the environment in China.
Because he is currently detained, he was unable to take possession of it personally.
Shame for China, and tomorrow there will be a debate here on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, we must give not only economic interests, but above all human rights a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hudzhia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr. President, esteemed members of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! As rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one makes interesting observations, such as the fact that everyone talks about anti-fraud measures, and then no one acts.
Or the experience of member states meticulously calculating their payments to the European Union with a pointed quill, but donning their generous trousers when it comes to spending this money?
and even make it easy for fraudsters, for example, by the fact that, on average, it still takes 36 months before any irregularities are reported to the European Union.
The European Parliament disagrees with this.
We want an efficient fraud prevention system that also includes prevention.
We want the Member States to make fraud prevention a priority and that we discuss the necessities and problems associated with it together.
We aim for a greater interest from national judicial authorities in the follow-up of OLAF findings.
In irregular routes, there should no longer be free right-hand spaces as has been the case previously.
We need an equalization of European money with national money.
We desire an independent office that possesses the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
And we want an office that can work noiselessly and efficiently with the member states.
Our position regarding the legal basis 1073 addresses all of these points.
We advocate for the continued development of this regulation as a core element of the Office for Countering Fraud, together with the Council.
We urge the Council to incorporate our observations, we urge the Council to initiate discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We aim to bring about a resolution to the problems of OLAF.
I thank all factions of this House who support this, as well, in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up and return the Parliament’s ball.
We have also incorporated solutions that the Council working group developed and submitted in our proposals.
From our side, I am authorized to express our interest in a swift conclusion of this regulation and to assure you of our readiness for constructive discussions based on our proposals.
A consolidation of all OLAF legal bases, as the Council has indeed foreseen, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
OLAF will soon be celebrating its tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
For that reason, combating fraud is too important to us.
We intend, therefore, to realize what is feasible now in collaboration with the Council.
Thank you very much!
Mr. President! I would like to take up a remark that my Austrian colleague, Paul Rübig, mentioned earlier.

We spend less than 1% of European gross domestic product on Europe, and at the same time, we demand that an ever-increasing number of tasks for an ever-increasing number of member states be handled by the European Union.
This calculation cannot be correct; it is therefore also truly unbelievable if we have been pursuing an austerity course for many years, but not only in the thrifty
to utilize our funds, but fundamentally to ensure that, at the end of the year, the finance ministers can reclaim the money and channel it into their own budgets.
We have enough new tasks for which we should be spending our money.
We also have tasks that we have not truly funded appropriately from a budgetary perspective for years.
I believe that the European Union’s information funding should be significantly increased if we genuinely want to connect European citizens with Europe.
And there are numerous tasks in the area of student and trainee exchange that Europe could undertake.
The Commission is also advancing into an area traditionally reserved for the state within the judicial sector.
This corresponds to the altered living conditions of the people in our Union.
But this remark has already been made several times. Integration must not intrude too deeply into traditionally established structures, particularly those that are functioning well.
Not everything can be swept under the rug.
Public documents and public officials are interpreted in quite different ways in many Member States.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notary public, as a public registrar, has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This must not be jeopardized unnecessarily, simply because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and reciprocal openness, yes, but with moderation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues! Plant protection products were and remain essential inputs for the agricultural sector.
Farmers require a minimum selection of plant protection products, as this concerns the protection of the native cultural landscape, high-quality nutrition, and the safeguarding of resources.
We discuss chemicals far too often on a very irrational level.
To obtain sensible results, however, we must think and act rationally.
The consequences of the original parliamentary position—a broad ban on plant protection products—would have been fatal, resulting in lower yields in agriculture and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am pleased that a barely acceptable compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is commendable that we have maintained the three-zone regulation, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step toward a consistent internal market solution would look different in this instance. Beyond the acceptable compromises, we should refrain from prematurely defining endocrine-disrupting substances, but rather grant the EU Commission the full four years to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be overextending the precautionary principle at this point.
Finally, I find it regrettable that we have not initiated a follow-up assessment of the agreement reached at this time.
Mr. President! When last, during a visit by a head of government or head of state, similar expressions of opinion arose, the President of this House intervened decisively.
At that time, it concerned a matter that was itself important to him, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When today the President, the sovereignly elected President of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the President does not shout.
Do you know what this is?
That is not democracy; that is arbitrary rule, and I call for appropriate measures to be taken.
Madam President! Children and politics – rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so greatly.
For citizens across Europe, the topic of childhood stands foremost.
For politicians, children arrange concerns within distant lives, as we can observe again here.
I know of no country that has its own ministry for children. Nor does the commission have its own representative for the interests of our youngest citizens.
In Parliament, the topic of children is dispersed across all committees.
Therefore, I would like to particularly highlight to the Commission at this point that today it is dealing with childcare facilities and the Barcelona Goals.
Mr. President! In our parliamentary working group on Quality of Childhood, we have determined the following: Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now, and today is entirely uncertain.
A child of today can climb to the very top of the social scale or fall very far down.
It can remain within its own cultural sphere or seek a new one.
It can embark on a similar life path as its parents or do precisely the opposite.
One may marry someone of the opposite sex or of the same sex.
All of that was more than 50 years ago, when we lifted the united Europe from its baptism, quite different.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans, this diversity has become a defining factor in children’s lives.
The concept of diversity must therefore be integrated into the pedagogy of childcare providers and teachers.
This is currently far too little considered.
Europe’s childcare facilities and schools are struggling with the challenge of integration.
In integration matters, we must press the reset button back to the beginning.
Therefore, we will approach this topic once again completely free of preconceptions, in accordance with the motto “Unity through Diversity.”

Furthermore, I ask all my succeeding Members of the European Parliament: do not focus solely on gender mainstreaming, but also champion child mainstreaming, especially during this time of global financial crisis, lest we burden our children with immeasurable debts.
Thank you, Mr. President. I will keep this very brief.
I am very grateful for these constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would like to transmit only two messages in conclusion. Firstly, I would like to express my explicit gratitude to the Commissioner for not having spoken out fundamentally against the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net.
This proposal is not a devil's brew, nor is it a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving tool to which we should give an opportunity.
Therefore, I would simply like to advocate for that here.
And the second thing I would like to say, and this is directed now to my British friends, is to cross all the parties.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline, I do understand your problem.
I can readily understand that, for a certain period, a nation might prioritize energy security over adherence to an air pollutant limit.
I have considerable understanding of that.
I am also the last person who would deny Your Majesty additional time when it comes to constructing new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it, can’t we?
The problem is, we didn't do precisely that.
This conversation has never taken place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you to, this being the outlook in the second reading, remain open-minded at this point and to say, “Let us discuss a compromise at this juncture.”

I am in favor of abandoning the, from my perspective, entirely irrational resistance, the fundamental opposition to the minimum standards, which is not justifiable from a competition policy or environmental policy perspective.
This is the point where a compromise can be reached, one that I hope will ultimately be achieved in a second reading.
Incidentally, I do not believe that we should avoid seeking a compromise in a first reading.
For this, the legislation is too complex.
I do not wish to conclude this legislative term as rapporteur and leave the next parliament with legislation involving a text that is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
Therefore, I request your support for the compromises when we vote here in one hour.
Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues! I believe that the crucial question regarding all the economic programs now being finalized across Europe is, of course, who ultimately receives the money?
will further blank checks be issued to the banks, even though the rapid nationalization would ultimately be considerably cheaper for the taxpayer.
Should corporations and high-income earners be further relieved of their tax burden, despite having been coddled for years across Europe through tax breaks?

The more money is squandered for such purposes, the more predictable the failure of these programs becomes, and the more likely it is that the European economy will sink further and further into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The decades-long policy of privatization, deregulation, and liberalization—precisely this policy—has increasingly concentrated incomes among the top ten thousand, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
Anyone who believes that they can overcome this crisis by continuing precisely this policy with minor modifications simply doesn’t understand.
The exact opposite is required.
Instead of buying up toxic assets from the banks, tax funds should be used for the renovation of schools, hospitals, and for the ecological restructuring of the European economy.

If private companies receive public funds, it must be the case that no tax money is provided without employment guarantees, and above all, no tax money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, in particular, the general public can participate in future earnings.
The very best economic stimulus program that currently exists would be a radical redistribution of income and assets from the top to the bottom.
The sector of exploitative low wages in Europe must be curtailed, rather than further encouraged.
We need higher minimum wages; we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that millionaires and the profiteers of the past financial market boom now also bear the immense losses that have arisen, and not the vast majority of citizens who, for all the financial boom, never benefited from it.
I believe that the socially just is, presently, also the economically most reasonable.
It is the only way to break the devastating crisis dynamic.

Mr. President! At the beginning of March, the political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be indicted again on the basis of untenable charges.
The first day of public hearings has been scheduled for March 31st.
On the same day, human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were scheduled to take place.
These important discussions have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia is thereby demonstrating very clearly the low priority it assigns to human rights.
The judiciary will continue not only to fail to deliver justice, but to be employed in the elimination of regime opponents, and the EU will thereby be compromised.
Mr. President! Commissioner, dear colleagues, thank you very much! I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for again referencing the prohibition of animal testing.

I drew the attention of the Member of Parliament to the fact that this is now the third amendment to cosmetics legislation that I have likely accompanied. The sixth amendment, the seventh amendment, and now the amendment to a regulation.
And we have, in fact, managed to prohibit animal experimentation.
We have managed to ensure that, for example, consumers know how long a product remains shelf-stable by seeing a small container with a number indicating the remaining validity period.

I also say this to some colleagues, particularly to Colleague Reutow, who unfortunately could not be present at the beginning. Markings are never warnings at any point in time; if a product is not safe, then it must not be on the market, then it must not be marketed.
Every product present on this European market must be safe and harmless.
But the labeling provides consumers with the opportunity to choose.
That is democracy, and that is your freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have endeavored to design the procedure in a very transparent manner.
I have attempted, as Ms. Costette also stated, to bring together different opinions.

For I am concerned that we create legislation that is good for all, for consumers in the European Union, for the industry that must work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who will benefit from it.
And when I tell my colleague Schnellhardt, I say again, yes, DEO affects everyone differently, but the statement “Keeps you sweat-free” is still made.
Therefore, it is important that the statements regarding my fold depth around the eyes are also reasonably realistic and reliable after one week in Strasbourg.
I would like to express my thanks once again to the commissioner, also concerning the explanations he provided, to my colleagues, and to my employee, who did the majority of the work.
I thank you.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! The report by Mr. Van Nistelrooij concerning the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most significant of the Regional Affairs Committee in recent years.
We agree with the fundamental concept of the Green Paper, according to which territorial cohesion is essentially about promoting the polycentric development of the EU.
overall, to ensure sustainable development of the territories with diverse characteristics and peculiarities, while also preserving their diversity.
It is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of phased support for transitional regions exceeding the threshold of 75
must be created so that these regions receive a distinct status and thus have greater security in their development, should they exceed 20% of the protein landscape product.
In the report by Ms. Crewe on obstacles to the initiation of structural fund programs, the most significant shortcomings faced by applicants in the

Among the drawbacks associated with utilizing structural funds, we find, for example, excessive administrative costs, an overabundance of complex regulations, and slow and cumbersome centralized administration within the member states.
Numerous recommendations are made to the Commission regarding the adoption of effective measures to reduce these obstacles.
I would simply like to highlight and reaffirm two such measures.

Firstly, currently project managers are required to retain their project documentation for a period of ten years in order to have it available for inspections, which may be conducted by the Commission.
Especially for smaller projects, it represents an overly bureaucratic effort.
It is correct that this is to be reduced to a period of three years. Secondly, the EU Commission’s assessment criteria for innovative projects are causing significant problems.
In innovative projects, the same assessment criteria should not apply as with other projects.
It is simply necessary that something different occurs here.

Madam President! When Europe puts money on the table, and above all the member states put a great deal of money on the table, to help the automotive industry in its crisis situation, then this cannot be just about securing existing structures and the status quo and preventing bankruptcies, but it concerns a number of other issues.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about enabling people to seek employment, and ensuring that they have that employment, and doing so in a long-term fashion.
And for that, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all sustainability within the transport system more strongly than we have done previously.

Therefore, we should link all our measures to these objectives, so that we are not compelled to endure the reproach in a few years' time. We should have considered all of this many years ago; otherwise, we would not be facing the next and new crisis.
Madam President! It would be kind if you would also grant me the additional half-minute that my Green colleague, Ms. Breyer, has just been allotted.
The Commission had presented a good proposal for updating the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some proposed amendments attempt to supplement this proposal with stipulations that are either incompatible with the objectives of the regulation or even seek to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with regard to the health and welfare of animals would simply overwhelm retailers.
Once again, there is an attempt to undermine existing GMO laws, namely the demand for specific labeling of novel foods derived from animals that have been fed genetically modified feed.
We have heard it. I think:
Principally, everything pertaining to the GMO legislation should not be addressed within the Noble Food Regulation.
I say this, although I myself, for example, had submitted a proposal to specifically delineate corresponding new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be the case that interested parties within this institution abuse the Nobil Food Regulation for campaign purposes.
It appears that the proposed amendments 62 and 90 also represent such an attempt, for which the Green Party has requested a roll-call vote.
Dear colleagues, what precisely do you intend to expose?
My faction has always advocated for the consumer's right to know what is contained in food.
Why, then, shouldn't the declaration of ingredients indicate a nano origin?
And although Amendment 62 rather clumsily attempts to anticipate my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling by Noble Food to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend to my parliamentary group approval of the aforementioned proposals and will include in my report on the Food Information Regulation references to the portion of the Noble Food Regulation dealing with labeling.
That is possible because we postponed the first reading on food labeling to the next legislative term against the wishes of the Green Party.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement proved to be.
Briefly regarding cloning, it is animal cruelty.
We object.
Nevertheless, foodstuffs must be included in this regulation accordingly, as otherwise they would be in a
Madam President, it is quite simple.
Whoever does not wish for this man to chair the formal opening session of the European Parliament should support my proposal to amend the rules of procedure.

Madam President, Madam President, dear Commissioner, esteemed colleagues!

One thing is clear from the outset: the provision of food to those in need, particularly in these economically challenging times, is not open to debate in the upcoming vote on our colleague Tschikersky’s report.
Therefore, I also want to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common line within our parliamentary group.
I therefore respect the personal decision of each colleague in our group to deviate from this course and to not agree to the rejection of the report that we have planned.
Why can I not approve of the committee vote’s result in this manner?
There are a number of reasons for this, none of which, absolutely none, have to do with assistance for those in need within the European Union during these economically challenging times.

On the contrary, the amendment proposals submitted by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ALDE Group, but unfortunately not found to be admissible, were intended to place the existing system on a sustainable basis.
For the current system is an anachronism from times of agrarian overproduction, which thankfully belongs to the past.
Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, intervention stocks have steadily declined in recent years, meaning that today up to 85% of foodstuffs must be purchased on the open market.
That, however, fundamentally altered the character of the program and resulted in the loss of its agricultural policy dimension.
However, as we are now dealing with a social program, we must create a corresponding legal basis for it.
We hereby share the assessment of the Legal Service of the Council, which, instead of Article 37 of the EC Treaty concerning the common agricultural policy, merely
Article 308 is considered a legal basis, because otherwise it would clearly constitute an infringement on the member states' national competencies.
The only possible solution, given the inadmissibility of our proposed amendments, can be a new draft from the European Commission.
It should continue to uphold the principle of co-financing, for only on-site can the sense and nonsense of such programs be assessed in the interests of all as contributors to peace.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen,

First and foremost, we too welcome the proposal of the European Commission and this Green Paper in principle.

There is, and this is not in dispute, a mass phenomenon that has been described by the various previous speakers, namely, the occurrence of relatively minor damage affecting a large number of individuals.
The damage to the individual is minor, but when considered collectively, it is substantial.
An instrument is required to address this problem.
It is, in my view, correct that consideration is given to such matters.

I also highly welcome—and to remain positive—that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a crucial emphasis in its Green Paper on the question of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

This represents a significant difference from the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition, which was also discussed here yesterday, and which has hitherto completely disregarded the possibility of extrajudicial dispute resolution mechanisms.
I believe that here, the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has gone further in its Green Paper than its competition colleagues.
However, I want to make two things quite clear as well, which, in my estimation, should certainly be understood as critical observations.
The Parliament will vote on my report regarding the Directorate-General for Competition's White Paper in a few minutes, here at twelve o’clock.
We will, with an overwhelming majority in this House, demand of the European Commission that a horizontal approach be adopted when dealing with this matter.
It cannot be the case that we end up with sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, one for antitrust law, one for the capital market, perhaps even one for the environment.

Perhaps one more for Social [Affairs], and they all contradict each other, all intervening in the legal order of the member states and ultimately leading to a policy confusion that no practitioner can any longer manage.
We have frequently encountered such examples in the past.
I am thinking only of the debate regarding the professional qualifications directive, which we subsequently compiled into an instrument as well, because this fragmentation was no longer manageable.
The commission should not make the same mistake here.
It should promote a horizontal approach from the outset.
That is the clear position of the parliament; it will become evident here in a few months, in a few minutes.

And one final point, I also very much welcome the consensus we have reached that we do not want a litigation industry modeled after the American system, generating $240 billion in revenue annually, where only lawyers ultimately profit and the consumer gains nothing.
We want genuine rule of law in Europe and to remain true to our traditional systems and our understanding of law.

Dear colleagues,

There are many ways to manage the sustainable consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure within the European Recovery Programme, is designed as a good response, albeit not entirely sufficient, but primarily as a good response to this temporary, albeit exceptionally critical, situation.
It also includes the promotion of a more significant simplification of procedures and greater flexibility in the application of existing
We have established the provisions within the framework of the Structural Funds Regulation following a request, dear colleagues, which the European Parliament has repeatedly made in recent years.

It is also to be welcomed, and I would like to emphasize this particularly, that an amendment to Article 7 concerning the eligibility of expenditure is intended to enable the Member States and regions of the EU.
to invest in structural policy funding in energy efficiency and renewable energy in the building sector and that these measures should not be limited to households with low incomes.

The related amendment proposal therefore rightly removes the line "households with low incomes" and instead introduces a ceiling of 4 percent of the total EEFR allocation for each member state for such expenditures.
This is just one of many proposed improvements.
In short, if this comprehensive package is implemented, it will result in accelerated spending and therefore further liquidity for the execution of necessary

There are stipulations originating from funds of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), and the Cohesion Fund, and a simplification of the regulations to enable rapid program implementation.
A, as I believe, a more effective, as I believe, a more effective contribution, albeit not yet sufficient, not sufficient contribution to managing the current crisis situation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, in principle, I welcome the European Ecolabel.
It is correct that we are undertaking a new effort to further disseminate this community’s environmental label.
I also believe it is correct that we should adhere to voluntary participation in the future.
The sign will only prevail in the future if there are clear criteria and standards that precede its acquisition.
Here, I appeal to the EU Commission to develop reasonable, clear, and comprehensible criteria.
The principle of incentive must be paramount.
It would be regrettable if the establishment of the eco-label were to fail due to bureaucratic obstacles.
Ultimately, the consumer determines success or failure, as acceptance must be achieved with them.

Although I am personally very fond of the Blue Angel, which we have in Germany, it must ultimately not be a matter of taste, but rather it must convey to the consumer at a glance what special properties a product has.
Consumer benefit arises only when the member states forgo their respective national marks and there is, in the end, a unified mark at the European level.
A jumble of symbols confuses the consumer and does not inform them.

A sign, a statement.
We should work together on this.
Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I believe that we have made considerable progress together during this legislative term concerning the discharge procedures of the European institutions.
I do regret, however, that it has taken so long, because we have essentially only now processed everything that accumulated with the commission's resignation in 1999, that is, ten years ago.

This demonstrates that we still need to refine our working methods and procedures and ensure that the necessary transparency is achieved more quickly when it comes to informing citizens how their tax money is being used.
I would particularly like to thank my colleague Casaca, with whom I had the honor of working for the EPP Group on parliamentary duties.

I deeply regret this, which is why I have just quickly checked to see that a colleague, who comments very intensively on the press regarding various matters of the European Parliament, has neither participated in committee consultations, nor in committee votes, nor in this plenary debate.
I want to state this very clearly at this point, so that it is preserved and remains preserved for posterity. We are well aware that there have been a number of problems here.

We are, and we have been the members of parliament who are now here, who over the last five years have ensured that the necessary reforms, in a variety of areas and in the interest of the members of parliament, have been achieved.

And for all of you, a most heartfelt thank you. We have done what was necessary, and we have not ensured that everything would be widely publicized in the media, but without any cooperation on our part.
For this, a thank you for the reliable collaboration.

Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues, the ODI report, heartfelt thanks to the rapporteur, truly moves us forward because it contains innovative elements, such as naming and shaming, a milestone in budgetary control.
Targeted criticism instead of sweeping accusations.
That the Socialist Group of all factions is now backing down and would rather sweep the truth under the rug is a scandal and a disservice to our oversight responsibilities.
But the credibility of Parliament is at stake, and I appeal to my colleagues not to allow that to happen.
A word about our biggest problem children, Romania and Bulgaria.
The Commission’s failure in preparing for the accessions is most evident here.
We have lost a great deal of money.
The Commission had long observed and only in 2008 froze funds, for Bulgaria now over one billion euros, for Romania approximately 142 million euros.
Freezing assets is not a solution to the problems.
The cooperation and verification mechanism, for which the Commission President himself is responsible, is a paper tiger, and the progress reports do not deserve the name.
Here, the audit report proposes how things could be improved.
The EU Commission misled Parliament regarding the accession readiness of these countries, and the Enlargement Commissioner should, in fact, draw consequences from this.
However, our concern is the management of future contributions, and therefore this topic will remain on the agenda.
Our faction will share the relief measures with the Commission, but I personally will deny the Commission the relief measures for that reason.
Unfortunately, the commission's zeal for reform, which one could have detected a small glimmer of last year, has already died down again.
Stagnation in fraud prevention, nothing on the topic of prevention, ethics not desired, etc.
The Commission, and Commissioner Kallas in particular, should be clear about one thing: anyone who wishes to be part of the new Commission is dependent on the support of the Parliament.
Mr. President! Yes, we have a problem with copyright, and we have a problem with the remuneration of artists.
That is correct, and that is where we also need to become active and do something.
But when we become active, it is about truly responding to the challenges of the digital age and not flogging dead horses.
I will explain to you why I arrive at this word.
Firstly, the proposal before us essentially fulfills only one promise, and that is the promise to support the music industry.
When we come to what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and we calculate that, then we arrive
such low average amounts that it in no way serves as a livelihood for an artist, allowing them to make a living from it.
Furthermore, this money does not reach the artists directly.
And the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist with whom I discussed this matter told me that here, a redistribution is taking place from the living to the dead.
I must disagree. It is a redistribution of funds from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and specifically to the major players.
All things considered, Mr. Commissioner, this proposal is not suitable.
We must find better ones.
We need to create something like a flat rate, for example.
Even the suggestions you make regarding the use it or lose it clause remain theoretical law.
Let us create something clever and well-founded, as the artists themselves recommended and requested in our hearing in the Legal Committee.
Mr. President! I share the Rapporteur Gilles Sabary’s regret that the Commission has abandoned its original plan for a comprehensive action plan.
There are many good reasons why all stakeholders, from local municipalities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that current traffic conditions are anything but optimal.
Therefore, fundamental agreement with the plan and the report by the colleague Savary, to develop corresponding integrated proposals originating from this Parliament.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the specific suggestions.
At the same time, however, I want to signal with all clarity that what many fear or believe they must fear will not come to pass.
No one wishes to deny municipalities, or local and regional administrative bodies, their right to shape their transport conditions.

From the European side, we merely want to contribute to ensuring that proceedings are conducted according to reasonable, common rules when a municipality, a city, or a regional unit deems this appropriate.
The principle of subsidiarity is not jeopardized.
What we aim to do here is to protect this principle.
It therefore remains that we, in the interest of the citizens, endeavor to ensure that not, when a citizen 10 km
As he continues through Europe, he encounters a traffic-calmed zone that he believes he knows from his home community, only to find entirely different rules applying there.

No one wishes to impose city tolls or other regulations in any municipalities, but if they are indeed implemented here, then they should be established within a discernible framework for the citizens.
For over a hundred years, we have agreed on the sense of common approaches regarding traffic signs.
That should also be the case with this topic in the future.
Mr. President! We have been dealing with urban transport within the EU for quite some time now.
Why, actually?

We are simply not responsible for this. The jurisdiction was originally constructed because approximately 80 percent of the population lives in urban areas, and because of the climate debate, there is now a desire to address the issue.
Well, fortunately, we were able to reduce these ambitions of the European Commission to an action plan for urban transport through our protest.
I thank Commissioner Tajani for his understanding.
Subsidizing, after all, tends more towards supporting than prescribing, but he, as an Italian, naturally knows that better than I, a German with only one significant Latin qualification.
It is primarily important to me that our report, the Parliament’s report, emphasizes the strict observance of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at the European level are inadmissible for urban transport.
Supportive measures—that is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices is sensible.
Not everyone needs to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need tailored solutions, but these can only be developed by the actors on site, as they alone know what is necessary.
Municipalities must address a wide range of diverse situations. They therefore require sufficient scope for action, also in order to maintain the vitality of inner-city retail.
That is important for the attractiveness of a city.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual transport, but rather to focus more on urban logistics.
I would therefore like to see research on intra-urban enemy distribution promoted.
That relieves a city.
It is also important to consider demographic change.
Our society is ultimately aging.
Mobility needs and housing requirements are changing.
We need a supply of daily necessities close to where people live if we want to reduce traffic, and that is also a challenge for the retail sector.
Anything else would only demand the green meadow.
Concluding Remarks: We do not require a traffic observation post for urban traffic.
Such a position would cost a great deal of money and produce a great deal of paperwork, which would be filed only in Brussels.
Madam President! I fully support the Commission’s objective of establishing a legal framework for the coordinated implementation and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle for the standard-issue introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, underscores the urgency for me almost daily. Yet, intelligent transport systems can achieve much more.
They serve environmental compatibility, efficiency gains, enhanced safety, and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road freight and passenger transport.

Furthermore, it supports multimodality, among other things, through the development of interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways, and air transport, where the integration of intelligent transportation systems has already begun.
All of this cannot be achieved by the member states alone, but only as a shared task.

Intelligent transport systems, based on EU-wide, legally binding fundamental standards and regulations regarding minimum quality, improve the environment for innovation and create planning certainty, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open, vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent transport systems services.

The action plan now includes a timeline for the introduction of individual systems A for road traffic safety, such as ESP and eCall, B for continuity in traffic management, for example, for information.
Avoidance of toll charges or parking management and congestion traffic C. The utilization of real-time road, traffic, and travel data will benefit not only professional drivers, but all road users.
The Directive aims to establish detailed requirements for the EU-wide, uniformly binding, and coordinated introduction of intelligent transport systems and their application in the Member States.
It also secures the handling of personal data.

However, caution: The introduction of intelligent transport systems incurs high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We know too little about the willingness and ability to pay of potential users.
Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues! We clearly and unequivocally support assistance for people with rare diseases.
However, amendment proposal 15 is ethically entirely unacceptable.
There must never again be a debate in Europe concerning life that is worth living and life that is not.
There must be no political or social pressure on parents in Europe to consciously decide against a child with a disability.
The selection of embryos would constitute a significant ethical rupture.
Therefore, this amendment must be rejected, and it is not sufficient to simply remove the word that, unfortunately, corresponds to a fascistic mode of expression.
but it would still be a matter of selection of embryos.
And it would be unbearable if this proposed amendment, which speaks of a selection of embryos, were thus to become a stirrup for a new ethics in Europe.
We must resolutely oppose genetic discrimination.
Therefore, Amendment A 15 must be rejected in its entirety; otherwise, our parliamentary group would unfortunately be compelled to vote against this report, which is otherwise quite positive.
Mr. President! In the vote on the discharge of liability, for the first time since I have been a member of this House, I voted against the discharge of liability for the Commission, and would like to
Let me lay out my reasons. My primary concern is the manner in which the European Commission handled and managed the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high level of corruption, with a great deal of money, with a great deal of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only began freezing these funds in 2008.
In 2007, we lost a significant amount of money and are now dealing with either virtually nonexistent control systems or systems that function only sporadically.
In Romania, we are confronted with a high rate of corruption and problems within the judiciary.
All of this is attributable to the preceding access process.

My aim is to set a precedent, to tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently regarding future accessions, and also to tell it that, as has been observed in other countries, it could certainly be more successful if it were to do so.
I would like to urge the Commission to assist the two countries in establishing financial control systems that live up to their name and to eliminate the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we would have a persistent problem and a perpetual headache for all of Europe.

Madam President! I would like to draw your attention to the fact that behind me, in the area reserved for the far-right, there are individuals who are not Members of Parliament, and as far as I can see, they are indeed marking their ballot papers.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I expressly welcome Horst Schnellhardt’s draft report and thank him for his excellent work.
Following the numerous crises of recent years concerning products of animal origin that pose a danger to human and animal health, a comprehensive legal framework is essential.
A revision of the current regulations has become necessary.
We must continue to ensure a high level of security.
Although we generally agree with the report, I see several points that give me pause.
The regulation is relaxed in many respects, thereby easing trade in animal by-products.
There are some examples. There is a permit for the use of specific material from Category I in pet food.
Materials of category 2 or 3 can be disposed of more easily under official supervision when the weekly waste volume is low, regardless of their risk.
However, the risk posed by animal by-products of any category is determined only in part by their quantity.
It remains the case that the European Commission will issue the implementing regulation, and the draft, as with the previous one, contains numerous enabling powers for the Commission.

That is to say, the Commission can adopt comprehensive and fundamental regulations concerning the handling of animal by-products using the comitology procedure. This means that Parliament is excluded, as is unfortunately often the case.
Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Afghanistan has a difficult history behind it.
I believe that families there hold together very strongly and that the woman in the family plays an important role.
Therefore, economic development is particularly important, namely, the support of small and medium-sized enterprises should be promoted especially strongly.
And, of course, a modern infrastructure is also necessary to help the country develop more easily.

And I believe that infrastructure projects in particular could help foster greater mutual understanding, and naturally, through the means of information and communication technology, a different worldview could gradually gain traction there, while fully preserving identity.

Marine pollution tends to become a focal point of interest only when a spectacular incident occurs, and then there is vigorous discussion about the threat to our oceans posed by these ongoing pollutions.
Unfortunately, that then increasingly recedes into the background in the meantime.

The constant and repeated violations, which contribute just as much and dramatically to the fact that not only our oceans, but also our coasts are suffering under a threat, were to be taken seriously by us.
I must thank my colleagues, with whom we were able to discuss, for consistently upholding the line that our ocean must be protected.
I speak here as a member of a landlocked nation, yet I feel as a European the responsibility to protect our seas from lasting pollution resulting from cheap economic
to protect interests and to integrate the principles of the third maritime package as well, which is urgently necessary, as the Legal Committee has also proposed.
Madam President, colleagues! I too would like to congratulate Mr. Obiol Sigmar on his excellent report.
Mr. President! Worldwide, the respect for human rights is very poor in many countries.
But also here in Europe, if we consider Belarus, for example.
Therefore, the European Union must significantly strengthen its efforts by implementing human rights policy in all areas and establishing clear standards.
In our understanding, human rights are indivisible.
This can, for example, occur during negotiations for a new agreement with Russia through a binding human rights clause that has influence across all negotiation areas.
Furthermore, I would like to reiterate my advocacy for the Sub-Committee on Human Rights to be elevated to a Standing Committee.
Okay! The EPP EDF Group calls on the government and the Communist Party of China to conduct the upcoming human rights dialogue in a constructive manner.
This would significantly ease the relationship between the EU and China.
We have a genuine interest in improving bilateral relations.
But this dialogue must also be conducted honestly.
Therefore, we will have to maintain our justified demands against China.
Thus, from our perspective, the civil rights activists should be released immediately.
Thus, the conversations with the Dalai Lama as the religious leader of the Tibetans can be resumed.
And so the Chinese region of Tibet should be made immediately accessible to journalists and UN human rights experts.
In my opinion, the People’s Republic of China demonstrated before the Olympic Games that it can grant more press freedom, for example, without jeopardizing the stability of the country.
Now she should have the courage to tackle new reforms—reforms concerning re-education camps, rights of the accused, the death penalty, freedom of religion, and freedom of assembly.
These human rights should be her concern, and she should engage in dialogue with us.
Madam President! Madam Vice-President! Also, today's decision of the Czech Senate, which we welcome with great pleasure and warmly congratulate.
President Klaus, among other things, reacted by asserting that the Lisbon Treaty was nevertheless dead, because it had been rejected by the referendum in Ireland.
Thus, he mounts an attack against majority decisions of his own parliament and senate as a political zombie, confirming his infamous and sectarian stance in other areas of politics as well.
Fortunately, he only makes himself look ridiculous after the positive votes.
We Greens view the European integration process positively and constructively, of course, also with critical observations where necessary.
Once again, heartfelt thanks to the Czech Senate, Parliament, and the government.

Mr. President! Mr. Council President, ladies and gentlemen! Last week, I had the pleasure of hearing Mr. Machmalbach in the foreign affairs committee, which was convened for me as a newly elected member.

To an Iranian film director who has made it very clear to us that there was democracy in Iran before this election, after this election, which he considers a coup, there is no democracy whatsoever anymore.

I, too, endorse this designation. It was indeed a coup d'état carried out through massive electoral fraud, which deprived the majority of the Iranian population, who had voted for change, of their right.
Mr. President, what interests me above all is this: There will be an inauguration ceremony for Mr. Ahmadinejad, quoted as having been re-elected, in mid-August.
What is currently being discussed in the Council and with the Member States?
Will there be an official formal representation of the European Union and also of its member states here?
I hope there won’t be any, because I believe that after this electoral coup, there should be no official representation of the European Union or
There are no member states, although I advocate for further dialogue, but at this inauguration, I believe, no one should be officially represented on behalf of the European Union.
What is your position on this?
How is this currently being handled?
Mr. President! Mr. President! Mr. President! Mr. President! Mr. President!
There is the growing social inequality, there are the dangerous and unsolidary macroeconomic imbalances between the member states, and there is Europe’s dependence on rising resource prices.

The citizens of Europe deserve a Commission that repeatedly places these underlying causes on the agenda, rather than taboos them, rather than doing the opposite, rather than shifting responsibility onto the member states.
We need genuine European coordination of economic and fiscal policy.
We need fiscal cooperation in Europe that ends tax dumping.
Only then does it become possible to halt social division and finance the necessary ecological investments.
We need a policy that consistently promotes green technologies and lifestyles, ensuring a steep decline in the EU’s dependence on finite resources.
This is an ecological green revolution. I don’t find any of this in your program, Mr. Barroso.
That is the reason why I cannot choose them.
Mr. Barroso, imagine you are a
You would be facing an election in Europe, just you alone, no other candidate. What percentage of the votes would you receive?
What would the citizens do?
You would have likely been listening today and seeing how you have promised everyone everything.
You would hopefully also receive the information regarding what you did five years ago.
You have promised a great deal, a very great deal.
One must compare what you have already promised, what you are promising now, and what is to be expected.
I believe that is very, very little.
You stand for the old, for the failed Europe, for the contribution to the financial crisis, because the Commission has failed, for the lack of commitment in climate matters, and so on.
I would take the side of the majority of European citizens, because I believe they would not receive more than 10 or 12 or 15 votes.
Mr. President! I would like to express my support for retaining the new proposal, because it is clear that the negotiations in Honduras have failed.
There is no common proposal for this election.
This election is illegitimate because the current president came to power through a coup.
That is to say, I request that the plenary approve the proposal of the Presidium for this amendment, which removes the elections.
Mr. President! Democracy needs a revolution, and it is never wrong, Mr. Dartmouth, to advocate for transparency, Mr. Verhofstadt.
And you, precisely as you now hold the Swedish Council Presidency, could indeed be a shining example and truly tell us how things will proceed.
It concerns the thoroughly undignified power-sharing arrangements for top positions, and here, too, Mr. Barroso could take the lead in nominating the commissioner.
Germany and Austria provide a negative example, but others do as well.
Qualified individuals are present in this hall, but lack an opportunity for access.

Please be courageous now that the Lisbon Treaty has been ratified, and be honest and say that we need much clearer decision-making structures, transparent decision-making structures for the Commission and the opposition?
It must be possible to identify capable individuals here, from the European Parliament, with such expertise, and to find them, not to locate them in some arbitrary federal states.
Mr. President! The topic we are discussing here tonight has appeared on the agenda of the European Parliament on several occasions previously.
The Commission, as is well known, bases its grant of assistance on the conditions of the International Monetary Fund.
That has resonated a few times already.
Against this background, there have been repeated requests from the EP to the Commission.
The EP requested the Commission in November 2008 to submit an analysis of the effects of the behaviour of banks that transferred their assets from member states which had recently acceded.
On April 24 of this year, the EP reiterated this demand.

Furthermore, the EP has demanded to be informed about the letters of intent, which are being detailedly concluded between the Commission and the Member States receiving aid, and which detail the conditions for the aid.
As far as I am aware, these inquiries have not yet been answered.
My first question is therefore: Is it correct that these requests have not yet been answered?
If that is correct, then my second question is: Why have these requests not been answered thus far?
My third question is then, When can we expect a response to these inquiries?
Ladies and gentlemen, the GUE/NGL group will not support this resolution.
The Stockholm Programme sails completely past the genuine challenges of the present.
The fundamental error lies in establishing a Europe of rights that is to be granted to EU citizens, but not to other people living in Europe.
The same citizens and human rights shall they not receive.
On the one hand, the EU wants to accede to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are sorted according to the principle of legal or illegal.
Thus, Frontex is being equipped for the massive suppression of so-called illegal migration, and I tell you, this completely distorts the perspective on an unbiased immigration policy.
Here, Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the entirely imbalanced relationship between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a bargaining chip, but a universal right of every human being.

Stockholm, conversely, symbolizes the EU’s obsession with security, in which vast supranational databases are created without sufficient oversight mechanisms, integrating intelligence and law enforcement data across Europe.
This will make the right to informational self-determination of individuals, obsolescence, and the vision of a transparent person a reality.

Allow me, as a Member of Parliament from East Germany, to conclude by stating that, 20 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, it is unbearable for me to witness how Europe is increasingly becoming a fortress.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner! You are correct. Compared to other modes of transport, the railway system is a very safe system.

However, despite many positive aspects, liberalization in the form of fragmentation of individual societies, separation of infrastructure and operations, outsourcing of maintenance work, and leasing of equipment and personnel has nevertheless introduced a certain degree of uncertainty.
It must, in my view, be ensured that national security authorities issue security certificates and approvals in accordance with ERA regulations after the Railway Agency.
Are there enough checks?
It is ensured, for example, that the training of personnel, the certifications, and the working conditions are properly monitored.
How does this relate to the introduction of a uniform community certificate?
What is the status of the European train driver's license?
The efforts concerning ERTS must be further expanded.
The recently devised implementation plan you suggested must be binding and must not be delayed by financial or national considerations.
The efforts regarding the implementation of the technical specifications TSI must be continued and expanded.
This would represent a significant advancement, particularly during material homologation, and would provide a greater level of safety in material maintenance.
Many of the recent railway accidents and near misses can be attributed to inadequate maintenance.
For cost reasons, the intensity is particularly neglected, and the intervals for maintenance work are extended.
How does this situation stand regarding a Europe-wide certification system for maintenance workshops?
It must, in my view, be everything undertaken to avoid each individual member state reverting to its old rules and acting again in a disparate and autonomous manner.
In particular, the border crossings between individual member states pose a security risk.
How does the Commission intend to address this problem in the short term?
And when creating your balance sheet, I would like you to ensure that you also consider the social aspects.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, good morning in this new world of the Lisbon Treaty. This is an opportunity for you.
For eleven years now, I have been following your reports in this house, previously as a journalist, and ultimately, they are very similar.
Now, however, you have the opportunity to look forward.

Utilize the subject-matter expertise of this institution; it is not entirely coincidental, as colleagues are presently assembled in this very hall. I see colleagues Söndergaard, I see colleagues Tchachimakachis, there is Mr. Staes, there is my fellow candidate, Mr. Ehrenhauser from our list, and re-establish the work of the Court of Auditors.
Look at what works elsewhere in Germany, where the economic viability and meaningfulness of expenditures can be examined, in Austria.

I would like you to develop a concept, perhaps within the scope of an initiative report that is coming to the Parliament, on how to significantly improve what you do, so that you can effectively fulfill your tasks.
We need a revolution of democracy that brings people into the world.
I remember very well that the debates, as we hear them today, had already begun in this chamber ten years ago.
I would strongly urge you, Madam Commissioner, above all to take note of what comes from ALDEZIR, but also from the Greens and some left-leaning Members, and to record it definitively.

Do you not notice that with the approach with which the European Union has entered into these negotiations – and is continuing to do so – we cannot remedy the imbalance as an honest mediator? I believe that, in conjunction with what we are currently experiencing in Copenhagen in these hours and days, we need a new approach in reality.
Developing countries are, in many respects, no longer developing countries.
Emerging markets, developed countries, and very self-assured.

If it fails to achieve a fresh start with fair conditions from the European side, then we will end up where we do not want to be, namely with protectionism and, following 1933, with its consequences also in Europe.
I would like to use the blue card solely for the purpose of correction.
Support in Austria is not granted to just one person.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! A microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those threatened by unemployment, and especially for people who do not have access to conventional credit markets, is a good intention and is supported in principle by our parliamentary group.
However, what the Commission and Council have achieved in terms of performance in this process is simply inadequate, partly incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
First point of criticism: the question of financial provision.
What is presented as financial support here is not financial support for an unemployment reduction program. It cannot be termed a microfinance program; at best, it is nanofinance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to performing such sleight of hand without any effect, at the expense of other programs and thus dissipating endlessly.
Thirdly, the perception of the sustainability and success of such a program must inherently include mentoring and coaching.
