Many new start-ups, particularly in the microfinance sector, fail; therefore, the program must also ensure that this is accounted for.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the Member States are not reduced for the purpose of accessing this programme, otherwise it will be ineffective.
That cannot sustainably combat unemployment.
We will reject it in this form.

Mr. President! Today, after eight years, we all essentially know it:
The Afghanistan strategy, previously focused on military force, has failed.
The imbalance between military operations on the one hand and the insufficient resources for civilian purposes effectively prevents any improvement in the living conditions in Afghanistan.
And therefore, our most important message as UNGL is that a radical change in strategy is imperative.
We need a radical shift in strategy away from the military and, above all, toward the people.
That means that 40 of the Afghans are unemployed. More than half of them live in truly abject poverty, lacking both healthcare and adequate education.
The social question must be brought to the forefront, and that is what we expect from the Council, from the Commission, from all those involved.
This naturally includes strengthening responsible government action, bolstering agriculture, and integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I tell you quite honestly: whoever only pursues this path halfway and reverts to military adventures forfeits every opportunity.
It is five minutes to 12.
Madam President! My question concerns whether it isn't sensible to prevent unemployment altogether.
Can you envision public tasks that could be assigned to the unemployed?
And above all, how could we strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises, facilitating the establishment of new ones?
Are there possibilities for applying cross-border methods and best practices here, to create more and new ventures?
We need a revolution of democracy.
As an admirer of so many Swedish traditions, I was all the more disappointed in the assessment of their work.
It was unfortunately not a people's home presidency, but a council prince presidency and also an institutional investor presidency, all Wallström; it was not Malström.
I know you well, Member of the European Parliament, from that time, when you still were.
Now they were something else.
I sincerely hope that when you return, you will resume where you left off, namely inspired by parliamentarianism.
Why wasn’t it adopted too late?
Why are we now dealing with something akin to a directorate at the EU level, and that under the goals of Sweden with its transparency?
Please utilize your future to return to a place you have already been.
Mr. President! The current debate is a central debate about the character of the European Union.
The question is market or social policy?
The Commission’s previous considerations regarding the future of cohesion policy are unacceptable.
The Structural Funds must be strengthened, not reduced.
Europe must not do less, but more, to overcome economic and social development disparities.

I say this quite openly: the renationalization, even of only parts of the current cohesion policy, would have severe consequences for disadvantaged regions, moreover in Germany, for example in Eastern Germany.
Following the most recent round of European Union enlargement, the differences between regions within the Union have also demonstrably increased.
It is also important to me, moreover, that the socioeconomic conditions in regions just above the 75 threshold of GDP per capita are also recognized.
A sudden termination of funding after 2013 would be devastating for these regions.
Ladies and gentlemen! Naturally, strengthening specific urban funding, funding related to cities, through the European Union is extraordinarily important as well.
This is important, as there lies considerable power for the economy and for finance, and as the crisis has particularly impacted that area.
A final word on the border regions.
As a member of parliament from eastern Germany, I tell you, we must invest a great deal there, do a great deal.
And that is precisely where I have serious concerns that the Commission will fail.

Mr. President! Regional structural promotion is an essential instrument in European integration, and particularly Target 2 funding has in the past been perceived by people in many regions as a driver of local structural and economic development.
It is an important element for managing structural change in regions and municipalities alike.
Here, too, Europe is truly experienced by citizens because it also has an effect on the ground.
However, we need simpler, clearer, and more transparent structures for the Cohesion Funds and better controls to ensure that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the convergence in social and economic development, is a primary objective within the EU, and therefore we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but rather strengthen it.
Cohesion policy in Europe requires greater clarity, increased transparency, efficiency, and also the individual responsibility of member states.
And therefore, it is important to adhere to the system of additive funding.
We do not, however, want a renationalization of structural support.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to ensure that the funding criteria meet these requirements from 2013 onwards.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues! I have two motions regarding the rules of procedure to propose. Mr. President, I request that you put them forward in the order I consider conducive to a good debate.

I do not have further details to share at this time, but I am among those who know that it is imminent, that we will have a resolution for this case today, in the course of the day.
Prominent representatives of the EU government are working on a positive solution.
It would therefore be sensible for us to remove this urgency from the agenda this afternoon, because any further debate would only impede the work being done by certain diplomatic channels there.

Therefore, my request is that the assembly agree to temporarily remove this matter of urgency from the agenda, because we will thereby assist in resolving the case more effectively than if we were to discuss it.
That would be my first request.
I will present the second request immediately thereafter.

Madam President! It seems to me, and thus to the EU in general, but also to Parliament in particular, to be somewhat symptomatic that we reflexively conduct discussions about situations in countries whose situation is not new.
It is unfortunately the case that events often occur overnight, leading to a sudden, wave-like outpouring of political demands, some of which I find somewhat questionable.
I believe that it does not become us to instigate a general debate about Yemen solely on the basis of a failed aircraft attack.
I believe that we should be clear that it would behoove us to consider a strategy for dealing with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires careful analysis, namely, that it is a failed state in which a government operates that no longer controls large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks arise from this for Europe.
The risks appear to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is evidently taking place.
Therefore, it is up to us and perhaps also to Ms. Ashton to consider what we can do against these risks.
For my part, the question can primarily be: How can we bolster the government in Yemen, regain control of the country, and contain these risks?

All other discussions regarding the long-term development of the country, of course, must also be had, but I do not believe it is truly sensible and that we will be taken seriously if we now initiate a catalogue of demands spanning all policy areas—from media freedom to the rights of women here in Parliament.
I believe that will not achieve the desired outcome in Yemen, but rather we should focus on what concrete assistance we can provide in the current situation to resolve an acute problem.
Mr. President! Esteemed ladies and gentlemen! The massacre of November 23rd of last year in the province of Maguindanao, Philippines, was a dark day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
57 dead, raped, women, injured—they speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, it is particularly striking to me that 30 journalists were among the deceased.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, never before in any documented case have so many journalists been murdered at once.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, as EPP, we demand that the present text be softened in three places through separate votes, because we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence and therefore refrain from making accusations against the government.
Therefore, I request, on behalf of the EPP Group, a vote on Consideration Ground F specifically. This accuses the Philippines of exhibiting all signs of a dysfunctional legal system.
Secondly, Quotation In point two, we wish to remove the assumption of so-called initial delays in the investigation.
Finally, point 6 alleges that there are missing persons held in Philippine prisons.
This, too, is currently an unproven assertion and, in our opinion, should be removed.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen! I am pleased that the Social Democratic parliamentary group has engaged intensively with this report.

However, I would like to state that in December 2008, we, as Parliament, adopted a resolution with near unanimity, in which we requested the European Commission to present precisely such a proposal as we are currently discussing here.

And if Mr. Schulz’s efforts are aimed at expanding the circle of supporters, I also have no objection to a postponement until the next plenary session in March.
That is my personal position.
That is not the position of the group, which this morning explicitly decided otherwise.
But I think we should give the socialists the opportunity to gain insight here, so that they too can contribute to the relief of small and medium-sized enterprises and the reduction of bureaucracy.
I understand.

from the developing world, where we are also to be integrated into the ITS system, in order to expand the market and allow these countries to participate in that system.

Madam President! This is about ensuring that we, as the European Union, pursue a clear strategy and prevent a gold or oil rush.
Europe must actively intervene here.
Here, Europe can demonstrate strength as a partner by speaking with a single voice.
It concerns shipping on and under water, it concerns fishing, it concerns resources in the form of primary energy sources and raw materials.
Here, we need, together with the other partners in the Arctic, sustainable and reliable agreements.
We need cooperation instead of confrontation.
We need dialogue in the field of environmental protection to preserve natural resources and nature.
We need dialogue in the field of animal welfare in order to preserve biodiversity. We need protection and respect for the inhabitants and their human rights.
When we conduct positive resource management collaboratively with partners in the Arctic, we will have the opportunity to pursue new political avenues here.
This will also be an initial test for our common foreign policy, where we can demonstrate that we, as Europeans, pursue common goals together.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, the G20 summit in Pittsburgh provided a good foundation.
He has called for cyclical recovery plans to promote decent work that contributes to the security and creation of jobs, and has prioritized employment growth.

European Labour Ministers are therefore urged to press the G20 members to, firstly, not scale back stimulus packages, but to deploy them on a larger scale and with greater emphasis on job creation, secondly, financially secured short-time work.
thirdly, to leverage public investment for job creation and sustainable ecological growth, and fourthly, to strengthen and expand social security systems to enable access.
It also secures purchasing power within the internal market and employment, and combats poverty.
Collaboration with social partners is particularly encouraged by European Labour Ministers in order to further strengthen social dialogue, as the Commissioner would like to see it strengthened.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues,

First of all, many thanks to Mr. Leichtfried for an excellent report that constructively develops and carries forward sound content.
Ultimately, what is at stake?
The aim is to strengthen transparency, consumer protection, security and coordination, as well as quality management.
However, I must caution against establishing a new authority to address these issues.
I view the principle of subsidiarity in the report positively; it should certainly be maintained.
For me, a clear distinction between taxes and fees, and all tasks that are of a sovereign nature, even those pertaining to identification, is also very important.
Not by law enforcement, be it counter-terrorism or the like, all these measures are unequivocally to be financed from public funds and not from user fees.
If individual nation-states then have a vital interest in taking additional security measures, I also see them as responsible for the associated costs in this area.
He who commissions security in the sovereign sphere pays for it.
I am certainly more concerned regarding technical or personal matters, which could certainly disadvantage the air passenger, provided it is clearly declared what is involved.
Remarkably, however, the impact assessment presented to us by the Commission also includes an estimate of approximately 0.1 of the total transport revenue for these measures.
Therefore, we should not begin at too high a level.
I believe that we can reach a viable compromise even with the Federal Republic of Germany, which has extraordinary reservations in this area concerning subsidiarity.
I desire that the final result be very close to our proposal.
Mr. President! Dear Commissioner, Mr. Council President! The evaluation of passenger data is being approached in a manner similar to that of SWIFT, in an attempt to prevent global terrorism.
to reconcile serious criminal activity with the fundamental rights of each individual to the protection of privacy and also informational self-determination.
We must also be aware that in Europe and worldwide, in this age of mobility, there will be no sufficient security without effective and timely data exchange.
In the digital age, we must also ensure special protection regarding informational self-determination and privacy.
I therefore also consider it necessary to differentiate more precisely between the data necessary for crime prevention and the data sensitive with regard to privacy.
For me, it is actually not a question at all that we must firmly integrate controls, remedies, access rights, claims for damages, and the duration of storage into the agreement.
When using the push method, it must be determined whether exceptions may or must be made in urgent cases.
Regarding the use of passenger data, we should also include serious crime.
And for me, this includes offenses such as child pornography, human trafficking, murder, rape, and also drug trafficking.
And that, in my opinion, would also be a contribution to the protection of the personal rights of those affected.
I am pleased that we postponed the decision regarding the passenger data agreements in question, in order to establish a baseline model for all future agreements of this kind.
We also need to develop and present the Commission with a framework for negotiations that, of course, takes our own conceptions of data protection into account.
Perhaps there will also be an opportunity in the future to consider conducting counter-terrorism and crime prevention jointly with our transatlantic partners in a shared institution.
And that would certainly also be a step to meet globalized crime globally.
Mr. President! We have rightly drawn attention to the importance of the EIB in the introductions.
Colleague Kadenbach, for example, spoke of the vitally necessary contribution to social convergence.
I would like to place that in a political context.
We observe with great concern that in an increasing number of states, parties of the far right are gaining traction.
They do so because social convergence within the European Union has not functioned as we all hoped.
In this instance, these extreme right-wing figures very, very frequently present themselves as wolves in sheep’s clothing, thereby concealing a profound and cynical contempt for humanity.

Last example, Mr. President, I too know your political stance. What Mr. Mölzer just did – he gives a rather pleasant speech, but in the middle, he calls a political opponent, namely myself, a psychopath.
This is the language of Hitler fascism, this is how they operate. Political opponents were already branded as subhuman.

I urge you to proceed accordingly, and I ask my colleagues at the EIB to continue their work, and to become even more transparent in the area of transparency, because their approach is also a help in combating the emerging new fascism.
Policy coherence for development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

For example, it makes little sense to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries when, at the same time, we destroy local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
Equally, we can strive as much as we like for better healthcare if we obstruct trade in generic drugs or drive up medicine prices to unaffordable levels through patent extensions.

And while Agro fuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU to a limited extent, they lead to deforestation and land-use change in developing countries, thereby exacerbating climate change – precisely what we are attempting to avoid – not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and reduction in arable land for food production.
Currently, that is to say the EU as such—is not particularly coherent.
That political measures should not contradict each other has been recognized by the EU in theory for some time.
The Treaty of Lisbon enshrines policy coherence for development.
Article 208 states: When implementing political measures that may affect developing countries, the Union takes account of the objectives of development cooperation.
We must be measured against this demand.
This year, we are reviewing progress toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear: Without political coherence, we will not succeed in fulfilling our promises.

We must become aware of this responsibility, all of us who make and implement laws. Before a measure is decided upon, there must be an impact assessment, so that we can even recognize what aspects of European legislation could have negative consequences for developing countries.
We require expertise in advisory bodies, commissions, and parliament that recognizes inconsistencies.
The Commission's policy coherence programme is a positive step in this regard.
Now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Policy coherence for development means that in the fisheries reform, we must give greater consideration to the interests of local people and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing conglomerates.
It means that we must dry up tax havens into which funds drain from developing countries.
It means that we cannot agree to ACTA if the suspicion remains that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
Thus far, the Commission has been unable to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that when establishing the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the powers of the Development Commissioner must be expanded, not restricted.
And it is also essential that we, for example, enable Fair Trade procurement in municipalities, as my colleague Heide Rühle has proposed.
In many cases, we must carefully observe the actions of Members of the Commission and the Council to ensure that they shape policy coherently.
In many cases, it also rests with us, the members of parliament, to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to improve coordination between the committees, and we require a permanent rapporteur.
The report, unanimously adopted by the Development Committee, contains many good proposals and brings us a significant step forward.
I would like to thank all shadow rapporteurs, the ombudsman, and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.
Mr. President, my esteemed ladies and gentlemen colleagues! I have taken from the voting list that you, Mr. President, intend to declare motion 2 inadmissible.
I ask you to reconsider this once more.
It is indeed correct that Article 229 of the Treaty provides for a session of the European Parliament to take place on the second Tuesday of March.
That does not, however, contradict the motion put forward by my group.
The motion by my parliamentary group aims to shift Strasbourg Week from the tenth week to the eleventh week.
It does not prevent you from holding a plenary session on the second Tuesday in March.
We do, however, want the Strasbourg Week to be in the eleventh week, so I say that there is no impropriety here.
I would ask you to reconsider this once more. Thank you.

Mr. President of the Commission! Following the questions posed by my colleague Manfred Weber, Commissioner Malmström informed the College that serious concerns exist regarding the current state of negotiations in this House.
Therefore, the Commission is clear that what it has decided today is certainly not what Parliament considers to be sufficient progress.

Are you aware, Mr. President, that you have approved something today that, if implemented as such, would result in employees of a private company, such as SWIFT, having more control rights than civil servants of the European Union?
Has Ms. Mæstrom been informed about these matters?
If so, how could you then decide?
If not, why did Ms. Malmström not clarify this for you?
For the kind descriptions of your debate regarding EU membership
That was not the answer.
Therefore, I will try again more precisely, and I request that you respond very precisely.

Did Ms. Malmström, during the debate in the Commission preceding the College’s decision, tell you that there is a risk that Parliament will vote against the text you are now presenting as an agreement?
Or did Ms. Malmström tell you that with this text we will obtain a parliamentary majority?
I repeat very precisely: Did Ms. Malmström say that with this text we would obtain a parliamentary majority, or did she say that with this text the parliamentary majority is not secure?
I would be grateful if you could be precise.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues! For months, we have been discussing the question of driving and working hours in road transport.
And I wonder what arguments will now be deployed to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is nonsense.
The most recent argument is: We urgently need to change something here, so that nothing changes.
Do you not notice, dear Frau Bauer, how absurd this argumentation has become, how riddled it is with lies and half-truths?
This discussion concerns nothing other than an extension of working hours for self-employed individuals.
In labor law, the fundamental question for 150 years has been the protection of people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both self-employed individuals and salaried employees.
It is entirely irrelevant whether it is a self-employed individual feeling overwhelmed, or whether an employer is overburdening an employed driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessive working hours, in part also from employers and clients.
Secondly, concerning road traffic safety, it is asserted here that absolutely nothing can happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in a hobby hardware store, nor are we amateur craftspeople. We cannot make laws in the spirit of "let's see what comes of it."
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours create a propensity for accidents, particularly in road traffic, with significant consequences.
Third point: Who, then, is to control such a highly differentiated regulation, as you envision, on our roads in the future?
Today, a state labor judge cannot verify whether someone is ostensibly or genuinely self-employed without extensive review of the records.
Drop this nonsense; it’s about fair competition.
It is not about setting a precedent today, tomorrow, for the future dispute regarding the extension of working hours.
Do not play such games with this house. I thank you.
Madam President! Today, as I have for many years, I advocate for traffic safety, an improvement of the working conditions of our professional drivers, and the enhancement of their professional image.

And quite clearly, today we are not discussing the traffic safety-relevant regulations for driving and rest times that all self-employed and employed professional drivers must observe; today, we are discussing working time regulations.
It is primarily a regulation to protect employees, serving therefore only the social protection of drivers and by no means traffic safety.
We do not need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

Compliance with working hours is neither controllable with significant bureaucratic effort for independently operating truck and bus drivers, nor is there a discernible reason for any control to be exercised at all.
Restricting self-employed professionals, such as in the future perhaps also independent tradespeople, architects, or elected officials, in their permissible working hours is the wrong signal.
Rather, Member States should ensure that bogus self-employment among the
actively combated by drivers.
Madam President! Heartfelt congratulations to the rapporteur, but also to our shadow rapporteur. I believe that a good report has been produced here.
For me, the essential point is that both sides currently making life difficult in Bosnia and Herzegovina finally demonstrate insight and retreat from their extreme positions.

One extreme position is repeatedly to question Bosnia and the integrity of the country, threatening referendums that achieve nothing but can generate sentiment and hatred; the other extreme position is to question the fundamental structure of DETEN.
Must the Eten be adapted?
Yes, that is indeed.
It has already been adopted, and further action is still required.
And if, from one side, it is repeatedly stated that the office of the High Representative should be dissolved, then I concur.
But the side that demands this must create the preconditions for it to reach a point where the politicians in the country themselves assume responsibility.
That must be our goal, but politicians must also assume responsibility.
And hopefully, the voters will also elect, in the next elections, those politicians—both male and female—who are willing to assume responsibility for their own country.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues! Just a few days ago, we witnessed with shock on television the extent to which vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries were flooded.
People have perished in the floodwaters, and our deepest sympathy belongs to their families. Villages, towns, farmland, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been superseded by others, but the immense damage must still be painstakingly removed.
In addressing damages of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the European Union’s member states.
Following the 1997 flood disaster, Poland and, this time, other Central European states are once again affected by a flood catastrophe.
We cannot yet regulate the weather, and flooding is inherent to rivers at certain times.
But the questions we must ask are whether, in light of the awareness that these natural events can always occur, the appropriate preventative measures against
whether damage was caused by such natural events and whether, for example, in landscape planning the questions of sustainable disaster protection received due consideration.
When assistance is provided, it should initially benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster to ensure their survival.

And then, however, greater coordination should be undertaken at the European level by the member states, in international cooperation—since natural disasters do not respect national borders—regarding the prevention of damage caused by natural disasters.

That collectively managed preventive measures can offer protection is demonstrated by the flood protection measures on the Oder River, which have so far been jointly developed there by Polish and German authorities.
But we are far from being at the end yet.
We do not, however, require European disaster protection.
The protection of its country from disasters should primarily be the responsibility of a nation’s government, which should also include the development of disaster plans.

But a coordination of assistance in cases of damage and events should also benefit from efficient European coordination, and organizations that provide rapid and unobtrusive assistance on a voluntary basis should not be left to bear their costs.
Therefore, I support the Commissioner, Ms. Georgieva’s, plans that we also expedite these within.
Mr. President! Unfortunately, my debilitating illness has thus far prevented me from speaking with such clarity in the international arena as I have done on other European issues.
But in a minute, Mr. Commission President!
You are living in a historical time.
They will be measured in the realm of financial markets, primarily on their success in implementing regulations that effectively close loopholes.
Currently, everything coming from the Commission and what we have had so far in Parliament does not exclude it.

There are no necessary improvements to be made; they will then stand in history as one who, when the house was already ablaze, did not arrange for the necessary extinguishing material, let alone for new construction materials.
Point two: Equity capital. If it fails to curtail this calamitous, devastating shadow banking system and merely contain it, you deprive
the real economy and billions of citizens around the world not only their own basis for action in the economic sphere, but also trust in everything that is called democracy.
For then, China and the totalitarians, who are already ensuring their banks are controlled, would be better off than the European Union.

Three. Naturally, we need a system that minimizes systemic risks, meaning that implementation must be proactive, with progressive tax regulations, so that if a bank becomes too large, it simply must be constrained.

In 2007 and 2008, Libya voted against the resolutions of the United Nations General Assembly calling for a moratorium on executions, and neither did it provide official information in response to repeated requests from human rights organizations.
Therefore, it is of great importance to us that the identities of those executed are now officially disclosed.
Every execution is one too many.
We oppose executions and the death penalty.
It is inhumane, unhuman, and each one is one too many.
Therefore, in our resolution, we explicitly request that we change this, that we disclose it, and that we now work together to ensure a change occurs here.

No more hidden figures, but open statements regarding what is happening here, and a humane punishment for genuine offenders, but not an excessive penalization of those who critically engage with the regime in Tripoli.
Mr. President! I wished to support the motion of the colleague Cohn Bendit on behalf of our group.
Now it is precisely so.
This is a highly sensitive, very delicate subject, where it would certainly be sensible to find a broad parliamentary majority.
Therefore, it would be beneficial if the report could be postponed and an attempt made to further develop any potential consensus.
Therefore, we support this
I would like to restrict myself, esteemed colleagues, to the Kanchan report within the constraints of time.
It is undisputed that passenger rights and, consequently, consumer rights in scheduled bus services must be implemented.
However, I would like to reiterate the problems currently facing small and medium-sized enterprises, specifically from the perspective of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Public transport and regional transport cannot be separated, especially in rural areas within our region, as they frequently jointly serve a radius of approximately 50 kilometers.
Secondly, advance payments of benefits independent of debt are not possible for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Here we have the principle of liability insurance, which has proven itself very well to date and has thereby also kept fares stable.
Thirdly, I cannot imagine that non-fault delays must be paid by the contractor, just as the liability can only apply to circumstances for which the contractor is responsible.
Mr. President! First and foremost, my heartfelt thanks to Matthieu Grosch for this profound report and the tremendous work he has undertaken.

Europe without dividing borders cannot be experienced without a functioning transport system, and the European economy would not be successful, indeed would not even be conceivable, without a high-performing transport system, without high-performing, future-proof transport systems on land, water, and in the air.
In particular, in environmentally friendly rail transport, we need more community and less national-state egoism.
For a sustainable future of transport, all modes of transport must address the challenges facing society in terms of environmental protection and economic viability.
The report also provides valuable and instructive guidance.
I must, however, disagree with the report on one point. I cannot endorse the creation of a transport fund financed by cohesion policy funds.
Why?
Certainly, transportation is a particular driver of cohesion in Europe. A dedicated fund from Cohesion Policy resources, however, would not fulfill the expectations it would generate.
We must unilaterally burden the Cohesion Fund and relieve the member states that are particularly challenged from ensuring a sustainable future for transport.
And we have just established a special committee in Parliament, which is debating how the European Union’s cohesion and structural funds will look in the future—work that should not be deprioritized.
Therefore, I kindly request your approval of the amendment to the report as well.
Furthermore, I believe that when we discuss sustainability and the future of transport systems, magnetic levitation technology should also be given a future and an opportunity.
Madam President, my esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, we have a common internal market, but a fragmented supervisory landscape.
It is self-evident that this cannot function.
We need strong central European structures that utilize bodies possessing expertise and detailed knowledge of the member states, but also have the authority to intervene decisively in emergencies.
I believe the citizen expects, given the enormous tax burden imposed by this crisis, that decisions will be made here swiftly, promptly, and in a well-founded manner.
Citizens are little concerned when power games are played at the national level, where the issue is solely this question.
The most important thing that citizens want is for decisions to be made effectively, for problems to be solved.

It is objectively the case that when emergency situations require measures, these must be centrally regulated and decided upon at the European level if coordination between the member states is insufficient and does not function.
That does not align with the decisions of the G20, the G8 of heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The council makes him small, small, small square.
That is not an acceptable policy for citizens.
We expect the Council to act.

Gentlemen Commissioners, dear colleagues! One sometimes wonders what we have actually been doing for over a year now with discussions and debates, with numerous meetings in the trilogue, where I could certainly have envisioned spending my time doing something more pleasant.

And we stand, more than a year after the European elections, where we proclaimed in the streets and squares how we intended to tame the financial markets, essentially facing a very meager to nonexistent result.
And the problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that operate globally today.
Member states still believe that they are able to enforce rules here with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely that it didn’t function—he also didn’t trigger the financial crisis with one contribution—but he did make a contribution to the fact that it also affected Europe.

And that is why the question arises for me as to when this realization, frequently articulated in Sunday speeches, will also be translated into political action—where it suddenly concerns protecting stock exchange locations, protecting banking structures, and no longer protecting the citizens.

We in the European Parliament have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will dedicate themselves to it as well, as they share responsibility for implementing sound supervisory rules for the citizens, rules that ensure the individual’s savings remain permanently secure.

Naturally, gentlemen commissioners, I do hope that the Commission will now truly do everything possible to ensure that we arrive at a good result as quickly as possible, in the interests of the people of Europe.
Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues! We stand here in this European Parliament with the responsibility for the robust regulation of financial markets.
All of what we proposed has been significantly diluted in the trilogues.
The government and administration do not want extensive interventionist powers.
Giegold is right to describe what is currently happening as parochial thinking.
Not strict regulation, but rather to construct the system with a little fewer faults, appears to be the intention.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will be unable to exercise genuine control over the financial markets.
From this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, inadequate consequences are drawn, thereby preparing the next crisis.
Many national economies, even in Europe, will not survive the coming shocks, with all the social and economic consequences for the people of Europe.
But you expect this predatory financial market capitalism to be recaptured and the primacy of politics restored.
When the CEO of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, stated at the weekend, "We need a strong and unified European financial supervisory authority and a common rule for
If he calls for stricter capital regulations within the member states, then that is an appeal to this Parliament to truly establish these rules.
It is the responsibility of this European Parliament to pressure the Council to urgently implement effective regulation; it would be merely the first step towards a status quo.
Let concrete actions finally follow these bold promises. My group stands for strong European regulation.
Anything short of regulation would be a danger to the euro, to a united EU, and to democracy.
A poor timing for this statement.
I would have liked to see the Dutch team win, even if it were the last time at this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because we are no longer allowed to watch now, and then they probably won’t win after all.

But on the subject of Commissioner, you’re giving the correct signal. Commissioner, Mr. President, we will finalize today or, strictly speaking, tomorrow, a legislative package that we have been discussing for more than two years.
Not only is the controversy to blame, but also an intervening European election and the entry into force of a new EU treaty, which has led to the need to adjust certain aspects.

But I believe that if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we should now vote on a compromise, one that is certainly worth affirming, even if one might perhaps do so with a clenched fist in one’s pocket.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
That concerns the environmental requirements for industrial facilities.
The aim here is to ensure that the best available technology in Europe is more effectively implemented.
I believe that we have found an exceptional situation in the compromise now available that gives the EU Commission, Mr. Potočnik, and this is quite clearly directed at you, the tool.

We must, in the coming years, pay greater and better attention than we have previously to ensuring that the approximately 52 industrial facilities—those affected in Europe—ultimately utilize Best Available Techniques more effectively than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
I would like to address one point and reflect it here, as I simply cannot comprehend it.
I have often been told that the use of best available technology is too expensive, and that it jeopardizes the competitiveness of European industry, especially during a crisis.
I do not like to recall my past, but I am from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also attributable to having missed out on decades of investment in state-of-the-art technology.

I believe that every industry, every industrial enterprise, is obligated by its very existence to invest in the latest state of technology, because otherwise it will lose competitiveness and, incidentally, also reduce pollutant emissions.
I believe we have the opportunity today to enact a law that improves this initial situation.
The second part of the directive – and this is somewhat the concentrated fist that I mentioned – concerns large combustion plants.

We are once again discussing—as we already addressed in the previous directive—repeated exemptions until 2020, and in some cases until 2023, for large combustion plants that do not need to meet environmental requirements, particularly air pollutant emission limits.
I am directing this address to the council, but perhaps also a little to us all, that we must very carefully consider how sensible this actually is, that we regularly

Ambitious environmental goals are welcomed, which are discussed and here considered welcome, but whenever it comes to implementing them, to codify them into concrete legislation, then a tragedy begins in Europe.
Then, member states suddenly realize what this costs, which bills they have to pay, and typically, those who have made prior commitments are penalized as a result.
There is, in fact, a number of member states that already meet the requirements today and will, at the end, be left standing in the rain.
I’ll reiterate this point as well: Both industrial plants and large combustion plants—we’re talking, essentially, about coal-fired power stations—are not matters of science fiction.
We are not discussing things that are not available, but rather the state of the art.
What is available on the market from a competitive and cost perspective can be integrated into these systems. Against this background, we conclude
I abhor this legislative package today, believing it to be superior to what is currently in effect, and for that reason, I urge us all to approve it.

I would also like to thank my colleagues who, over the past two years, have often worked with considerable force, for their support, for their contributions, and above all, for the fact that nearly all important factions have co-signed this compromise.
Mr. President! Three interesting things have happened while we have been debating. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become football world champion.
A good omen, I believe.
Who then shall work, who must clean?
I simply do not want to express any preferences at this time.
Secondly, Germany is receiving compliments from the UK.
Chris Davis, many thanks. It doesn’t happen every day.
It is worthwhile to note that.
And thirdly, the world is still in order. Even among the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Bas Eikud has already left again.
But heartfelt congratulations, of course, to our Dutch friends.
I wished to raise two aspects in the debate, which I have just now had the opportunity to follow.
Firstly, I understand all the worries and hardships of my Eastern European friends only too well.
I am, as someone from East Germany, also half Eastern European.
I understand that not every environmental policy measure undertaken in Western European countries in recent decades can now be immediately replicated in Eastern Europe.
Environmental protection at a high level must be affordable.
Yes, that is correct.

But I believe that even when considering this sentence, it is worthwhile to agree to this compromise, because it does justice to the different starting situations in which many member states find themselves.
And secondly, the argument that the use of best available techniques endangers competitiveness, particularly in comparison to China. This argument is not only false, it is even dangerous.
We must confront the fact that industrial processes in Asia are, without a doubt, cheaper than they are here.
And we will only succeed in this competition if we implement the best available technology in as many industries as possible.
Those who fail to do so lose competitiveness.
No one, not even this law, demands that an industrial operation be shut down tomorrow.
No one demands a leap from zero to one hundred to achieve any pollutant limit within a week.
We have sufficient transitional periods, but to say that one should forgo them for competitive reasons is incorrect.
I believe that with this directive, we have not only set an environmental policy course, but also an industrial policy one, for which it is worthwhile to work in the coming years.

Mr. President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to begin by thanking my colleagues from the other groups for their contributions to the preparation of my report on Kosovo, and in particular Ms. Eva Marr, who has done very valuable work here in the secretariat.

And to you, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to express my thanks for the good cooperation, but also for what you mentioned, that it was important to you to travel to the north of Kosovo, to even spend a night there, and thereby make it clear to the population that you also stand for that population there.
You delivered a speech at the university and inaugurated the EU House there.

I believe that was an important sign to make clear what this European Parliament has expressed in the past and is expressing again now, namely, its support for independent Kosovo on its path to the European Union.
We are currently in a situation where, so to speak, there is once again a crucial juncture for Kosovo, for the citizens—especially those of all ethnic groups in Kosovo.
In a few weeks, the International Court of Justice will deliver its opinion on the status of the declaration of independence, made just over two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion will be an opportunity—something like an open window, as it is called in English—to place regional cooperation on a new foundation, but respecting national sovereignty.

I suspect that Kosovo, starting from and based on independence, needs to make clear that the common future for all states in the region – for Serbia, for Kosovo, and for all others – lies in membership of the European Union, and that on the path towards that goal, the problems that still exist must be resolved.
It is also the text of the resolution that makes clear: The future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

I am pleased that we have a majority that also urges the five member states that have not yet recognized [the state/entity] to do so soon, and that the Commission is once again urged to initiate visa liberalization as soon as possible.

For the citizens of the country, especially the young, must not have the impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot go out, while everyone else in the surrounding region will soon have that future.
I believe that is the task.
I hope to find a large majority for it tomorrow in the plenary session.

I have also submitted a new motion that places strong regret over the outbreaks of violence in recent days to the fore and expresses great hope for swift and independent clarification, without allowing this to serve as a basis for escalating emotions in the coming days and weeks.
Madam President, High Representative, Commissioner, dear colleagues! The recent events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the

The devastation of houses and the streams of hundreds of thousands of refugees who abandoned their home places and attempted to flee the violence – all of this shook me and evoked compassion for the victims.
Simultaneously, these events in Kyrgyzstan also cast a spotlight on the situation in Central Asia, which should not leave us unaffected here in the European Parliament.
On the contrary, we should devote our full attention to the countries of this region.

In doing so, our focus should not be limited to states rich in resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but rather encompass all states equally within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
That is our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which gained independence less than 20 years ago from what was once Tsarist and later Soviet rule, bear a heavy legacy.
Stalin's arbitrarily drawn borders, disregarding the traditional homelands of the peoples living there, evidently complicate coexistence both within and beyond the borders of these states.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human rights and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions that, for example in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, drive hundreds of thousands into
When we force labor migration and, as is now the case in Kyrgyzstan, resort to the use of force in conflict resolution, we leave the path of these states into the future marked with question marks.
Here, we must not simply stand by and watch the European Union.

If we do not wish to lead these states down a path towards fundamentalist structures, if we do not wish to leave the people there permanently at the mercy of dictatorial regimes, it requires our full commitment.
Besides the urgently needed material assistance, we need contact with these states, active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbaeva a chance in pacifying Kyrgyzstan and on the path towards stable political relations; let us debate it here and vote on it tomorrow.

May the resolutions presented here also be followed by actions, so that the people of Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states feel that we do not abandon them on their path to the future, nor deliver them to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of these countries for us Europeans are high; we should not disappoint them.
The report stemmed from four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the subtleties of which will continue to cause us considerable concern.
The second point is that the European Ambassador will manage commission funds in the future.
This exposes the funds to a variety of risks, and the safeguards for these risks are, as yet, entirely unclear.
The third point concerns the role of this Parliament’s rights in a Council regulation.
We are, in this process, effectively sharing decision-making power, yet we have permitted a Council regulation to encroach upon parliamentary rights.
Therefore, I would like to state, before presenting my dossier, the rules of procedure, that I do not consider myself bound by today's resolutions.
The fourth point concerns how we actually interact with each other in parliament.
We approved a parliamentary reform in the last period, and procedures that we are now disregarding, with the agreement of the presidium and also with the agreement of the president.
Why are we enacting a parliamentary reform that dictates procedures when, at critical moments, we already violate them and do not adhere to them?
For these reasons, I cannot agree with this report.
Mr. President! Commissioner, I am very much in favor of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else.
That simply cannot be compared to it.
Cloning is animal cruelty. Many colleagues have already stated this.
I also presented this during the discussion before the summer break. Only a fraction of animal clones is actually viable.
And those survive, of whom very, very many die very early and, indeed, very painfully.
You suffer from malformations of extremities, of organs.
They have immunodeficiencies; they are susceptible to illness.
That means pain and suffering and precisely this agonizing death.
How can we possibly answer for that?
We advocate for animal welfare, and then we want to support such a technology.
No, that is not what we want, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want any cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is only consistent.

Yes, we know that products from cloned animals or their descendants are unlikely to be harmful to health, and I personally believe that they would actually be suitable for human consumption. There is, in fact, no shortage of conventionally produced meat.
Why should we engage in this cloning?
This is entirely unnecessary, to engage in this animal cruelty, and that is what the population does not want either.
The population does not want these products; we don’t need them ourselves either. There is no argument for cloned meat within the European Union.
And therefore, we want to establish a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and, indeed, for their progeny.
I want a ban on cloning and cloned products within the European Union, and I also believe that we can enforce this.
Naturally, this must also apply to imports.
I want to be certain that I am not surreptitiously served cloned meat, because it is not labeled, as has already happened here.
Scotland. I don't believe it’s possible to trace all meat.
It may be possible with beef.
However, with pork, due to the quantities produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether a clone was actually present in the lineage.
Fundamentally, yes, it is a matter of principle; it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said it. We must also address ethical questions, and we are responsible for ethical questions as well.
Of course, the question of animal welfare arises, but it is also another question.

Experience shows that I am an animal producer; I studied it. Experience demonstrates that all reproductive techniques, once they functioned effectively in animal production, were ultimately also applied to humans.
And we must therefore ask ourselves today: Do we want and can we, in the foreseeable future, want and can we accept this technology—cloning—also in humans?
I do not want that, and I cannot do that either.
And even if a replacement part, a clone, were perhaps someday to be able to donate a life-sustaining organ to me, a clone of myself, then I would not want it.
I do not believe that is an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that this would be possible within not too distant a future, should we permit cloning.
Therefore, we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their progeny throughout the EU.
I have no fear of the WTO.
We can enforce that.
We do not need to emulate everything the United States demonstrates to us, despite all transatlantic friendship.
Mr. President! It is no coincidence that we cannot easily reach an agreement here, in this case, because two incompatible subjects are being mixed here.
We would likely have been able to come to an agreement on intellectual property protection had we focused on it.
But the blending with the substance of the Internet is also factually incorrect, because it requires new, different strategies here than in material law.
That cannot be easily transferred.
Furthermore, one must be clear about the fact that we pay for every prosecution in the online realm with infringements on civil rights, because one cannot simply see or ascertain this on one's own.
And the third point is quite clear to me: if I already subject cultural enjoyment on the web to the threat of penalties, so that I am practically always standing with one foot
When I am in prison, when I look into the net, then I will not be able to utilize the opportunities that the internet also offers for art, culture, and creativity.
Therefore, my appeal: Let us continue to discuss it.
>> MURAT: That is also a
Mr. President! Property, whether intellectual or physical property, is a cornerstone of a market economy.
Therefore, I believe it is important that we consider how to resolve this issue together in a satisfactory consensus.
We absolutely need a
It must become easier for consumers, for the self-employed, and for small and medium-sized enterprises to obtain the corresponding licenses here.
And precisely the availability of licenses for intellectual property rights that are valid throughout the EU is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
We need, above all, the original language to be available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible to grant licenses for a language that apply throughout Europe and can therefore be used by all citizens.
We need interoperability and technical neutrality in order to be able to utilize this intellectual property accordingly.
And we need, above all, sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues! I have taken note that the Council does not wish to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council that the European Parliament already wishes to discuss it and that the Council should not behave like children and say it will not respond to our questions and our proposals.
Secondly, I must ask the council, in this context, whether it does want Lisbon, or whether it does not want Lisbon.
Lisbon is not a purely technical change, but entails more tasks, means more task fulfillment, and consequently, addressing related financial matters.
Furthermore, the Council adopted resolutions that will result in new financial expenditures.
This has been performed by many colleagues.

If the council desires this and if the council desires that no further funds should be expended, then the council must also state where it specifically wishes to make savings, how it wishes to make savings, where it wishes to reallocate funds exactly, and not merely offer general statements.

We must propose percentage shifts and then leave it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide where the adjustments should be made, particularly since our possibilities for reallocations and changes to the budget are extremely limited.

The additional tasks you assign to us are, however, so challenging that they do not involve minor, incidental matters, but I will mention solely the areas of financial stability of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
But when the program must be utilized, then these are not small sums that one could simply shift around on the side.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to questions of internal security, the same applies to major research questions, and the same also applies to issues when I address priority areas that the Parliament has, namely in the field of youth education and research.
We are dealing, in part, with inadequate implementation, and in part also with a lack of transparency regarding the disposal of funds.
All these questions must be addressed and processed in conjunction with one another, and not answered by silence on the part of the Council.
Mr. President, Commissioner Hahn, colleagues! I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we discuss mountains, islands, and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression from individual submissions that they are ex territorially and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that is not the case.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state, which are sovereign.
And the implementation of European resolutions and objectives remains, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the responsibility of the Member States.

And when I consider the European level, we have always given particular attention to precisely these regions – mountain areas, sparsely populated areas, islands – in Commission communications, right up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here, too, in Parliament, many resolutions were passed to support this region.

When I hear so many complaints here now that there are still deficiencies in those regions, the question arises for me: How have the member states dealt with the impetus we have sent from the European level?
And how did the regions themselves address this, and did they utilize European funding opportunities?

Here, a new strategy is being demanded. I already feel sorry for the officials at DG Regio who are tasked with incorporating the multitude of problems facing islands, mountainous regions, and sparsely populated areas into a single strategy.

Simultaneously, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies—Danube, Baltic Sea, Blackwater, climate change, and the like—to the point where we will soon need a strategy for the strategies, simply to maintain an overview.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, joking aside! I believe that what it's really about – and this has also been said today – is that we must fight to ensure that there is a cohesion policy and a regional policy at the European level even after 2013.
This is the focus of our work, and it is in this regard that we should also convince our parliamentary colleagues that this will be the case.
And as a continuation of cohesion and regional policy beyond 2013, mountains, islands, and other areas will also find their place.
However, we should not anticipate individual draft resolutions on this topic, for which there is currently no cause.
Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues! First of all, my sincere thanks to the colleagues who have worked so intensely on this project, particularly colleague Bilal Quadras.
This is proof that European policy is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that provide further assistance.
We have experienced this supply security situation on multiple occasions.
The issue of supply security has thus become clearer and more distinct.
We were compelled to act, and we have.

We have found solutions that were not simple, that also mean new tools, and what I find interesting about them is that they do not merely establish infrastructure standards in Europe, do not merely create common rules for prevention and emergency plans, do not merely provide the certainty as the Commissioner just…

That has proven, demonstrates, that we can offer people 30 days of security in the future, but has also demonstrated that we are capable of exploring compromises, compromises that then lead to actionable solutions.

It is arduous on the path, but it is now becoming clear that both the role and the responsibility of companies—those building the networks and those responsible for networks—as well as the flexibility of politics, which says we will not enforce things that ultimately no longer make economic sense or prove wise—are central.

no longer sensible. For example, the flexibility regarding backflows, regarding necessary backflows, but not to say about everything and always and at any price, but also the necessity or the possibility of being able to assess individual cases, just as strengthening collaboration at the regional level.

And just as important is the point that Member States must also assume their responsibilities, but if solutions are not to be found there, then the Commission receives an additional task—the Commission, which is strengthened, but which does not decide alone, but decides when other solutions are no longer possible or has the final say.
Also flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, not least ensuring that solutions exist—and that is the good news from Brussels for the people of Europe.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, and most esteemed Commissioners, I need not emphasize how important cohesion and regional policy are for the harmonious coexistence and consolidation of Europe.
However, I also believe that the regional and cohesion policy of the future must increasingly focus on cities.
For cities are an important engine of development in Europe.
Simultaneously, however, you are experiencing particularly pressing ecological, economic, and social problems at this time.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn is: What possibilities do you see to emphasize the urban dimensions?

Specifically, Mr. Commissioner! You recently suggested at an event here at our institution that you could envision a specific percentage reserved from regional funds, precisely to highlight the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
If so, what percentage could this potentially be?

Mr. President! Firstly, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for initiating a new debate here, as a former Minister for Economic Affairs and Innovation, a debate that, I believe, can make a significant contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe were to create one additional job, we would have no unemployment in Europe.
We should therefore consider how to enable small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular, to onboard new employees and to become actively engaged in international export markets.
But research infrastructure is also an important concern, just as is infrastructure in the transport sector.
Here, the Commission faces significant tasks, for example, restructuring the East-West connection, such as Paris-Budapest, or the North-South connection.
Here, additional jobs can be created, which we urgently need in Europe at present.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues! Undeniably, we have made progress in recent years regarding gender equality. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are relegated to low-skilled employment.
This applies not only to activities traditionally performed within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, employment subject to social security contributions has frequently been transformed into atypical, precarious, and insecure work relationships.
There, particularly women.
European employment trends from 2000 to 2010 encompass 60 new precarious and atypical employment relationships, predominantly affecting two-thirds of them women.
Frequently, women are denied democratic participation through their part-time employment and precarious employment in businesses.
Women are, however, considerably more engaged and better educated than in all previous generations.
You still earn 25 less than men on average.
We in the Employment Committee have engaged very intensively with this topic and developed good proposals for the question of women’s employment, irrespective of their employment status.

This means social security systems, the establishment of childcare facilities, the alignment of pensions and social systems with independent living, and the design of work according to the principles of decent work.
And all of this essentially reflects precarious employment of women as presented in the report.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the outcome of this work and requests approval for the submitted report.
Madam President! Mr. President of the Council! Landmines will likely continue to pose a significant problem for the foreseeable future.
Do you believe it is possible to initiate one’s own research programs for the detection of landmines?
That is not merely a European problem; it is a global problem.
Could you envision identifying suitable institutions here that engage with research programs in this area?

Colleagues, in the transatlantic dialogue, there is much that unites us on both sides – fundamental values, fundamental rights of freedom and democracy. However, there are also differences, namely in the application and concretization of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
Especially when it comes to security questions, this contradiction becomes strikingly apparent.
Data protection is a source of persistent misunderstandings, something we have known for a long time.
And therefore, the framework agreement, should we succeed in obtaining a very good one, will be a very significant step forward.
We must find a solution here that enables citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the other partner.
A second important point where we have similar foundations but entirely different approaches is climate protection.
Therefore, I greatly desire that it becomes a topic and that it is discussed explicitly.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments.
The introduction of the investment fund manager marks the first instance of a degree of transparency and regulation within this opaque thicket of hedge funds and alternative investment funds.
Unfortunately, these rules remained incomplete.
It remains possible to access the common market with unregulated products within the framework of passive distribution.
Essentially, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed an opportunity to expand its rules internationally and to achieve a uniform regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, unlike what the Parliament desired, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.

Currently, it remains solely the responsibility of national regulations to limit the level of indebtedness of funds, and that means, in effect, that the consequences of the crisis are not being addressed here.
There will be a national race to the bottom in regulation.
What is crucial for us once again is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively prevented either.
Of course, there are Private Equity investments that are sensible for companies.
But the rules now being implemented are, unfortunately, far from sufficient.
Also ineffective are the information rights of employees, whom they are rightfully entitled to, as well as the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises from this form of exploitation.
Therefore, it is very difficult to justify this in this case vis-à-vis the voters.

Unfortunately, it is the case. The responsibility for this does not lie with the parliament; rather, it rests primarily with the intensive lobbying efforts of the relevant industry, successful particularly with the British.

Within the French government, but I must unfortunately say also partly within the German one, and we had representation of these lobbies here in Parliament primarily in the form of the liberal faction.
We cannot agree to this proposal, because it would establish a precedent for the parliament’s failure to enforce effective rules.
It is not possible for us to appear before our voters with a clear conscience and say, "We have succeeded in effectively regulating this shadow realm."
We hope that we will be able to make further progress when revising the guideline.
Many thanks again, and especially for the collaboration here with colleagues in Parliament.
Mr. President! Also, my sincere thanks initially to the colleague Balz for the collaboration.
I can only underscore that. Even with differing positions, it was a productive collaboration.
Many believed—I want to reiterate this—many believed that the Eurozone crisis had been over.
Ireland demonstrates that this was not the case.
Europe continues to voluntarily surrender itself to the financial markets.
The Member States of the EU must continue to hawk their government bonds on the financial markets and acquire the confidence of speculators through austerity.
Over the weekend, we once again had to observe where that leads.

This time, it was not the Greeks, supposedly predisposed to fraud, but model student Ireland that was driven into the European rescue funds to save its banking system, which for a long time was also considered exemplary, and exemplarily deregulated.
Meanwhile, the financial sector appeared to be anticipating Portugal’s default, with its interest rates continuing to rise.
The ECB bears a share of responsibility for this drama.
She failed to provide, and continues to fail to provide, a civilized alternative to the state casino through the issuance of Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB watches impassively as the other half falls ever deeper into poverty and insecurity.
The austerity measures imposed on entire national economies may suit the tastes of European funds and banking giants, but they have aided neither Ireland, nor the monetary union, nor the ECB.
Mr. Trichet, do not disregard Ms. Merkel’s straightforward funding department.
I say: If you want to save the Economic and Monetary Union, do not let European government bonds hang in the air.
Introduce Eurobonds before the next speculative victim falls.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner! When one considers how we discussed this Commission proposal in the previous legislative term, from total rejection to expressions of jubilation regarding the positive developments to come, then I must say, I am delighted with what is presented here now.
And a great deal of thanks is due to the rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs for having crafted a coherent opinion from this wide spectrum of views.
I believe the key to this lies in the patient-centered approach.
One has not, therefore, considered the various side effects and asked, "What does the patient need?"
I believe it is correct that we have agreed that the patient can become informed in various ways and not just one.
But I would like to emphasize that the physician will continue to be the patient’s primary confidant and will also undoubtedly exert influence in crucial matters.
We guarantee this, because we have, in fact, prohibited advertising for it and the information that the patient receives has been verified and approved by an authority.
This ensures the information is initially supported by scientific evidence, and the patient can confidently handle it as a result.
Naturally, it is correct; not everyone can do this.
We can submit it via the internet; we have various ways, and I believe that because it is so widely distributed, we do not need to worry.
I only hope that the council now finally has the courage to address this topic.
It is very important; it must be acted upon swiftly.
The patients expect that.
And I believe, then we will have accomplished a good work.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! Coal is a part of the energy supply; that is indisputable.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization may not be the correct approach.
The question now is whether the date with 2014 or 2018 is the correct one.
My colleague Rapka has presented a wealth of insightful arguments that I need not reiterate.

My request to the Commission is essentially only this: There is evidently a large majority within Parliament, in all the committees involved, in favor of affirming that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that we establish the necessary flexibility in the question of terminology, which ensures the possibility for Member States to implement it, and that the burdens on people, on jobs, and on economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that has been raised—which, incidentally, also contrasts with the Commission’s view, which initially appeared to be in favor of 2018—was the argument that climate policy considerations could play a role here.
I want to emphasize this aspect once again: it makes no difference to the question of climate change whether one burns foreign coal or one’s own coal.

And my request to the Commissioner is to reflect once more on whether this four-year period, within the Parliament and if such a new line of argumentation arises in the Council, could not lead to the Commission also becoming somewhat more flexible.
I understood the suggestion just now to mean that the commission is reflecting on this, and I thank you for that.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner! If one must draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, held the presidency, then it is this: that the European Union must speak with one voice in future conferences.

We may, at certain points, differ in our opinions, but if we, as Europeans, already speak with different voices, then our influence will not be credible, and if we are not credible, then other people will not follow us.
Why should you?
Therefore, it is correct that the figures we decided upon at the end of 2002 under Chancellor Merkel must, in essence, remain valid and form the foundations of these negotiations.

I share your opinion that the ambitious 2-degree target should not be seriously questioned today in favor of a significantly lower figure, as doing so would render these goals exceedingly difficult to achieve and would drive people away from them.
I have a significant concern that we are challenging our intellectual property.
Also, our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we now were to loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes as they are at present, then the valuable parts, namely our property, would simply walk away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a point in investing in it, and therefore intellectual property must not be diluted.
Regarding commitments, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible, and they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise, we do precisely the opposite of what we intend, namely, they will distance themselves from us.
Being able to present oneself convincingly in Cancun is also an important point.
The really big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancún, I believe we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in good order, the harvest will be unsuccessful.
Let us focus on the fertile field.
Mr. President! An incident occurred during the debate on the European Council this morning to which I no longer wish to respond, as I was the target of an insult.

I want to say, however, that there are levels at which I cannot be offended, and where I do not perceive something as an offense either, because to offend me, one must possess a certain degree of seriousness.
