I would, however, like to express my sincere gratitude for the countless expressions of solidarity I have received here in this building since then.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude to you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I believe this is a sign of our collective, democratic, and pro-European conviction, which is shared by the overwhelming majority of this House.
For this, my heartfelt thanks.

Mr. President! Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr. Gauzès, and dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, for the first time, I am pleased that we have now created this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is placed under direct European oversight.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe within a single market, for robust control over a sector that has contributed to the crisis.

I would like to add a brief remark.
Dear Mr. Barnier, the selection processes for the new authorities are currently underway, and the new authorities are only as good as their personnel.

I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, the focus will truly be on expertise, on independence from the financial industry they are meant to control, and on a clear commitment to public interests, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that supersede these important criteria.
Furthermore, there remains much to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still lack genuine transparency regarding the information used by rating agencies, and there is far too much reliance on regulatory ratings within the financial sector and in regulations governing the financial industry.
We have severe conflicts of interest, we have a clearly defined market dominance by three major providers, and we bear no liability for negligently prepared
Therefore, I ask you, Mr. Commissioner. It is good that the consultation is now underway, and we are eager to see the results.
I also believe that civil society should participate in this consultation, but then it must also be about putting forward a bold proposal.
I look forward to receiving your proposal.
Let us be as courageous as we have been thus far, and let us together legislate next year in a manner that truly resolves the problems that still exist in the ratings market at a European level.
This is what we owe to the citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues, the damage that rating agencies can inflict has been demonstrated in recent months since the beginning of this year.
There is, therefore, an urgent need for action.

Therefore, I welcome the directive, and indeed I welcome the fact that the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) will be responsible for the supervision and registration of credit rating agencies.
I believe this is an important and positive step forward.
However, numerous good and progressive proposals failed to materialize during the negotiations concerning the report.
I would like to add that here once again.
The designation of ESMA therefore remains the only genuine and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database for the creation of ratings have been dropped, and here, the reference to the establishment of a public rating agency is also missing.
Even the consistent and continuous review of created ratings by the supervisory authorities has been dropped.

The Commission had also continued to propose funding for independent ratings in order to overcome detrimental issuer instructions for the evaluation of financial market products. Nothing of that has remained either.
I hope that these aspects will be considered in the remaining reports on this topic, which Jean Paul Gauzé and you, Mr. Barnier, have also mentioned.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! First of all, my thanks to those who worked on this report, especially to Mr. Benson.
I would like to draw attention to two points and perhaps prompt some reflection.
We agree that energy efficiency and energy-saving usage are the simplest and most sensible solutions.
The question is: How do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to pose the question: What, actually, has it achieved that we in Parliament have repeatedly forced new and higher percentages upon the people?
Have we truly achieved more and accomplished more?
Or why, and in what instances, has energy been handled more efficiently?
I am learning that industries with high energy consumption are handling energy more efficiently because it saves them money and because it is advantageous for them.
I am learning that people, when they know that this device consumes more energy or less energy, and can decide for themselves that there is an advantage, will choose accordingly.
Perhaps the method is not correct in working with percentages, but rather in proceeding through incentives.
Second Question The Commissioner has just very impressively and clearly stated how complicated the mere description of the term is. What actually is it?
How differently is this implemented in the member states?
The colleague has just pointed out that the member states also have quite different situations—economically, geographically, totally different.
Is it then the correct approach to work with a number, a binding number, or must something else not occur to us?

I believe we must, in energy policy, distance ourselves somewhat from the debates of the past, which, with simple figures, binding targets, and purported miracle solutions, seek to achieve something, because it is obvious that we have not achieved enough.
Perhaps we should once try the other path—the path of differentiated, varied responses that accommodate differing situational circumstances, but also achieve impact.
It depends on the effects, it does not depend on our state of being.
Mr. President! This regulation, which is being discussed today, has not received much attention in the various committees for quite some time.
But now, at the conclusion, as the result became available, some people in this building awoke.
Some are unfortunately not present for the debate now; it would have been very interesting to hear their perspectives as well.
As a former member of the Convent, the spirit of the Convent remains vividly clear to me.
has clearly demanded in many areas that the European Parliament must receive specific rights in order to maintain its credibility both within the institutions and vis-à-vis citizens.
In that case, what the chapter house has given us was still not freely given.
Extremely difficult negotiations, particularly those led by the Belgian presidency vis-à-vis the Council, have enabled some important progress to be achieved.
I recall what my colleague Lehne already said. That was precisely the question of the constant possibility of verifying whether the Commission had exceeded its competencies.
Naturally, there are some arrangements that are not entirely ideal, such as international trade agreements, but nevertheless, I can agree with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian presidency.
She truly dedicated herself to ensuring something would happen, and our correspondent, who negotiated with both heart and mind.
13. I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a proposal that my colleague Göran Färm put forward in the Committee on Budgets on behalf of our group.
We did not resubmit this amendment, but the Green Party parliamentary group has resubmitted the proposal with 40 signatures from Green parliamentarians.
We will abstain from this application.
However, I have reached an understanding with my Green party colleagues. We are absolutely of the same opinion on this matter.
However, having fundamentally stated that we, as a parliamentary group, will not be submitting any new amendment proposals, we will abstain.

I would, however, like to state explicitly that we support this point, the financial transaction tax, and hope that our colleagues on the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
Mr. President! I believe it is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
Especially in the case of cross-border services, this is particularly important, as equal treatment is required here.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price limits were introduced as a crisis-related tax measure.
That is unacceptable, particularly the financial, insurance, and commercial sectors, but also energy, which is significantly affected here.
I hope that this is not also employed in the field of healthcare services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orbán to review these arrangements, as they inherently contradict the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU engages with the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has presented corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is no precise analysis of the implementation of existing legal provisions.
Even concerning the new proposals, there are scarcely any well-developed calculations and analyses.
I must state that the EPP unequivocally affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
However, the consideration of reality unfortunately also leads us to the problem that the right of asylum is being claimed for entirely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for general immigration into the 27 Member States.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers are not given the opportunity to profit from the fate of people through our asylum law, reaping billions in the process.
Asylum procedures must be conducted in a qualified and thorough manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
Therefore, the Commission intends to include corresponding obligations in the new directives.
I consider many of these points to be correct, such as interpretation, proper medical care, and consideration of specific protection needs.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities of the Member States receive far too few opportunities to counter abuse.
The possibility of conducting expedited proceedings and border proceedings should not be unduly restricted.

If an applicant substantially violates their cooperation obligations, there are scarcely any possibilities for sanctions—quite the contrary. If they abscond illegally, the Member State should no longer be able to terminate their proceedings negatively. If they reappear, an expanded range of procedural options should be available to them.
Even in cases of obvious lack of merit, an expedited procedure should be possible following the second successive application.
This entails significant cost increases.
Even free legal advice in the form of a lawyer—as it is currently worded in the Commission’s draft—represents a considerable increase in costs for the states.
I simply ask the Commission to reconsider the consequences of its proposals for practical reality, the financial implications, and the challenges for the administrations of the Member States.
We want to maintain a high standard, but it must also be feasible and, above all, must not place particularly burdened member states before entirely impossible tasks.
Dear Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor briefly once again.
I have a significant request of you, Commissioner Füle.
I want to begin by stating that false assumptions lead to inaccurate cost estimates.
We are currently not seeing decreasing numbers in the asylum seeker sector, but rather a significantly increasing trend.
That relates to visa facilitations, for example, with Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently witnessing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in attempts to enter a country of the European Union.

If one proceeds from false assumptions, namely that challenging the initial proceedings in a higher-level reform would save costs in subsequent instances, one automatically assumes that, so to speak, all member states have a deficient initial procedure.
That is not the case.
When one raises standards overall, it consequently implies that cost increases will result.
An increase in quality standards for all involved, and also the complication of procedures, I am happy to discuss; in practical reality, however, this leads to increased costs.
Therefore, I earnestly request once again that the concerns of the Länder be taken seriously, as the practical reports from the Länder are, in part, available and being provided.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues! This report attributes a successful competition policy to the Commission.
However, it must not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and a widening gap between rich and poor.
Unfettered competition still ranks higher in the European Union than the social needs of its people.
The credo of free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are also incapable of establishing social justice permanently.
A few procedures regarding distortions of competition and price-fixing do not resolve this problem.
A fair and simultaneously social internal market functions only with strong and equitable regulation.
More is urgently needed for that.
It is, for example, not acceptable to subject an increasing number of public service facilities to private-sector competition.
The report formulates recommendations for the Commission's future competition policy.
Far stronger consumer protection, the exclusion of public utilities from competition rules, and the control of cartels – all of this is urgently needed.
Furthermore, a contractual clause for secured social progress would be necessary, one that stands at least on an equal footing with the competition rules in Europe.
Mr. President! This is truly a momentous occasion, as we commemorate for the first time in the European Parliament the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti.
Let me begin with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy wrote to Robert Reinhardt in 1943 before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote: "I have found my parents again."
We are being transported to the concentration camp.
I have braced myself internally to the point that I can endure death.
I thank you once again for all you have done for me.
Greetings to all, farewell in heaven!
Aier Oberg

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500 others of Roma and Sinti descent. And although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, were among the first victims of industrial mass murder, 66 years later, the full truth about it remains unsaid.
And complicity of the majority society is also frequently obscured.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be prosecuted as a crime against humanity and acknowledged, so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must passionately combat the prejudices against these people.
We must put a stop to racist hostility and acts of violence, such as those that occurred in Hungary just before last year, and do so with civic courage.
Freedom and equality and solidarity are not the privilege of individuals, but the right of all, for the rights of humankind and the rights of citizens are indivisible.
Mr. President! Esteemed ladies and gentlemen, colleagues! In my view, the time has come to truly harness the potential of the law online.
We aim to maximize strong financial oversight in Europe, and we have doubts whether institutions are truly exploiting these possibilities.
We see deficiencies in the process. As Parliament, we have not received the candidate list in advance to date, but only the finalized result.
It would be straightforward to send it to the Executive Directors now.

We clearly have a deficit of gender equality in the filling of positions, and we have doubts, due to certain occurrences within the process, whether the Member States are truly appointing individuals in the European interest to this institution.
This and the further points in our letter justify posing a fundamental question.
But beyond that, it naturally concerns the suitability of the individual persons, and in that case, each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There, we see two significant problems.

During the hearings, we observed that one of the candidates disputed the institution’s status as a European body, instead referring to a network of supervisory authorities, and remained unwilling to correct this statement even when prompted.
When asked whether you are prepared to make all lobbying contacts with the financial industry transparent, we received no clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive responses to it.
Mr. President! Mr. President! We, as the Social Democratic fraction, have an identical motion to submit.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and to this esteemed assembly that we formulate it somewhat more precisely.
We are dealing with a rather substantial influx.

Today, Italy, like any other Mediterranean country, is certainly overwhelmed by the need to manage the current situation alone, and Italy will certainly not be the only country confronted by a massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain too will be confronted with this problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, it is our request that we formulate the title of the statement very precisely, namely as a statement by the Commission regarding immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected in managing the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues! I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

The implementation of the regulation will ensure that, firstly, a high level of protection comparable to that of other modes of transport is established for all passengers in scheduled coach transport, including those with limited mobility.

Firstly, it ensures that consumers benefit, secondly, a high general level of consumer protection is guaranteed, and thirdly, account is taken of the fact that the sector is predominantly characterized by small and medium-sized enterprises.

Thus, the extreme demands that would have practically rendered bus transport impossible due to excessive requirements are off the table, as are demands under which the majority of member states would have fallen entirely outside the scope of the regulation.
Bus services that benefit the public at large must also offer a high standard of quality to people with disabilities and those with limited mobility.
You should be entitled to assistance; in the interest of social integration, this should be provided free of charge.
Madam President! I would like to congratulate everyone, particularly the colleague Mr. Kancsjan for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy development of a compromise in this challenging dossier.
There were successes that have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties that have already been described.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to establish a common, coherent, and efficient framework for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU among European citizens.
To maintain credibility, therefore, the coherence of rights for the various modes of transport must be strictly respected.
It is unacceptable that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of air passengers than, for example, to those of train passengers.

Therefore, it is particularly important when developing a framework program not to adhere to the lowest and weakest standards, but to ensure that we do not lose sight of ambitious goals in the interest of the citizens.

Madam President, esteemed Mr. President, dear colleagues! We are indeed facing a major economic crisis, something we have been discussing for months – and that is correct. However, we generally speak in headlines and then proceed to make decisions here as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is due to the fact that we in parliament, too, do not behave concretely enough, nor honestly enough, but rather it is such a headline-driven policy that occurs.
What does one truly do to advance growth and stability?
Are we ourselves also contributing to handling finances more properly and wisely?
Have we truly engaged in a critical examination of whether we are making the right expenditures, or does each of us not have a new idea every day regarding where further funds can be spent?

If we lack the capacity to concentrate financial resources on future projects—that is to say, conflict, disagreement, and decision-making—then there is no point in talking about innovation and research, but not providing the means to support them.
That is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we must also pursue policies that stimulate it and do not spend from morning to evening contemplating how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We cheerfully continue to pass resolutions, demanding new resolutions even today, which disrupt the economy in its developments.
Does anyone genuinely believe that the question of binding energy efficiency targets, to cite but one example, contributes to advancing the economy?
Do you truly believe that our decisions, frequently made in the context of energy, have stimulated the economy?
Or have we disturbed them?
I would like us to be a little more honest about this and then make a few fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that truly move things forward.
That is more strenuous, will also entail dispute, but that is the essence of democracy.
Mr. President! Ladies and gentlemen! The demand for a financial transaction tax is not new; opponents of globalization have been calling for such a tax for several years.
Yet, just five years ago, few would have believed that it could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week, it is on the agenda in the European Parliament alongside a carbon tax and Eurobonds, and I think that is a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments proposed by Anni Podimata in her report, and I believe we will also vote in favor of them accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on reducing expenditures.
The reduction of public spending primarily affects employees, pensioners, and the poor—that is, those who depend on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has hitherto been completely overlooked.
It is the second adjustment knob one can turn to consolidate public finances.
Above all, however, those primarily responsible for the public debt crisis can also be appropriately involved in the reduction of public debt through measures on the revenue side.
To consolidate public budgets, an increase in tax revenues is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high level of public debt is primarily a consequence of the nationalization of private debt, specifically the assumption of private banks’ liabilities and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by public authorities.
The responsibility for the debt crisis therefore does not rest with the states alone.
It is therefore not only logical but also politically necessary to call the financial sector to account.
The financial transaction tax would finally involve this sector, now recognized as a primary contributor to public debt, in the reduction of that debt.
This constitutes a significant political signal emanating from this report, should it be adopted as presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to debt reduction than all sanctions or well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens would increase due to Eurobonds are, however, unacceptable, because these surplus countries also profit from their exports to deficit countries at the same time.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
However, anyone who desires a social Europe, anyone who wants the EU to remain cohesive in the future, must, in principle, at least agree to a transfer union.

Finally, I would like to address the Commission and express my hope that it will now finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax, which have been requested for over a year. Thank you.
Mr. President, Madam President! The rescue shields should protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they are burdening citizens with brutal austerity programs and letting those responsible go unpunished. Moreover, the Commission is now also intervening in national wage policies.
Mr. President! It is absurd, and it brings tears to one's eyes, to hear this formal argumentation here. None of this was ever intended to be socially or politically motivated.
This position is entirely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the responsibility of the EU. This policy of the Commission is in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union has never been a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
One can read there about wage rigidity, which is to be reduced.
I only want to speak plainly. Wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, the blind are talking about color—people who formulate such statements have absolutely no understanding of collective bargaining agreements.
They interfere with wage autonomy and reduce the much-invoked autonomy of social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.

I want to state this clearly: This Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue, and to prevent further dismantling of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policies and punitive actions. Thank you.
You are a more astute man, but you have not answered my question.

Therefore, I am asking again: When Mr. Oettinger says that we currently suspect that certain facilities connected to the grid will not survive our stress tests, I interpret that as you possessing knowledge that these facilities are so inadequately secured that they cannot meet the criteria.
Why don’t you intervene today?
For me, that is a real danger.
Mr. President! I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why you believe it necessary to address this topic with soundbites.
I believe it helps no one if it is not stated explicitly that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the member states of the European Union and the European Union
must finally fully meet their commitments for development assistance, and it cannot be tolerated in any way that Member States increasingly evade this commitment.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still hunger every day and that most of them live in LDCs, that is, in the least developed countries of the world.

It is unacceptable that a significant portion of our development aid is not directed towards the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but that this share has rapidly declined in recent years, with a billion people suffering from hunger.
And then to speak of that. We hope that LDCs become more shock-resistant—I’m gradually coming to think that...
I urge you to address the problems specifically and clearly, and to undertake concrete commitments to genuinely assist the LDC.
Mr. President! In connection with the internal market, public procurement law, the awarding of public contracts, is an essential component.

Mr. Barnier, if you say that in this context you also want to promote social integration, then I must ask you: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
That belongs to the fundamental rules that you, as you say, do not wish to question yourself.

If one wishes to protect fundamental principles, it will be necessary in the future, when awarding public contracts, to ensure that elementary social standards are protected, that collective bargaining agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is brought to a halt.
This is part of a modernized public procurement law.
I expressly state that social basic rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe, or we want perpetual conflicts with the people who are turning away from this Europe in which they do not see their vital interests protected.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner Kroes! Radio frequencies are a valuable and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and taking into consideration societal aspects as a whole.
Therefore, the radio spectrum policy program assumes particular significance.
Radio frequencies must be utilized efficiently, taking into consideration economic, social, and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be fully utilized across all bandwidth areas to generate maximum efficiency.

The basis of radio frequency policy must be the telecommunications package adopted last year, as it also stipulates that radio frequency management for the EU and its Member States must equally serve cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be considered particularly when harmonizing frequency usage within the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend 1 has been progressing at considerably varying speeds in the member states.
Further opening of the UAF band, particularly below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experiences gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions have not yet been conclusively resolved.

And precisely the issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities during technical upgrades, for example in the area of radio microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
When allocating frequency bands, the diverse interests must be responsibly balanced against each other.

Widespread provision of mobile broadband networks is, on the one hand, a fundamental requirement in the interest of European citizens; on the other hand, developments in the area of public and private broadcasting must also continue to be considered as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must set the course for technological development, Europe’s positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity correctly.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn, I first want to say that you have described it – the situation has worsened.
The Eurozone: the divide widens between countries that are recovering and those that are performing more weakly.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries continue to rise.

In this situation, I have some questions for you. As Currency Commissioner, I ask you: on day two, liabilities and receivables between the central banks within the ECB system have accumulated to over 400 billion euros.
This is due to the fact that banks are still not sufficiently financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities, which are not provided for by the Eurosystem?
Then the major problem as to why we are not making progress with the restructuring of debt is that the banking system, as Ms. Ford also stated, is not properly positioned.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present it?
And how do you, as Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, assess this delay?
What are you doing to make it go faster?

Then we saw how we, as the Greens, had predicted this much earlier, that the measures against Greece would not work in Portugal, as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone did not improve.
We still have absolutely rising interest burdens macroeconomically for these countries.
We are observing increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, particularly from the strong Eurozone countries.
And we have rising resource and food prices, at least if one discounts recent fluctuations.

I am wondering, beyond the bailout for these countries, beyond the aid on the financing side, what measures are being taken to ensure that the weaker countries receive relief macroeconomically on these fronts—regarding taxation, external demand, and the question of interest rates.
And she
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that macroeconomically improves the conditions of these countries within the Eurozone.

And finally, in my view, the measures have affected the most vulnerable in countries like Greece, Portugal, and Spain, contravening the spirit of the EU Treaty, while the stronger, the wealthier, have not yet been brought to bear a share of the burdens.
What measures are you taking to ensure that those with assets also contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Mr. President, Ms. Kinger Göncz is a Member of Parliament from my parliamentary group.
One can be opposed to Ferenc Juchani, one can support Ferenc Juchani.
One can reject Kinga Gönn as a politician, or support her.
It is certainly for everyone freely and independently to determine, whether one is for or against a person’s political conviction.
The debate we are conducting here is about the last dictatorship that exists in Europe.
And we will guide you through the life of one of the most brutal and bloodthirsty dictators Europe has ever known.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that a freely elected democratic member of my faction is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I believe that Parliament must also reject this, particularly from a representative of a party that distinguishes itself by subjecting the Roma minority in Hungary to a hatred and persecution unparalleled in Europe.
If anyone here lacks the right to criticize Frau Kinga Göncz, then it is Frau
Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, dear visitors! Europe’s cultural diversity is a valuable asset that must be preserved and further developed in the future.
To make this possible, we must confront the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the field of culture and creative industries.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
Approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector within the EU.
This corresponds to approximately 2.5 percent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector, developing faster than many areas of the broader economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven just as much by the content provided by the cultural sector as the nature and quality of that content have been altered and advanced by technology.
We therefore need to establish framework conditions for the culture and creative industries that enable them to develop sustainably in light of the challenges of the digital age.
We require a modern, accessible, and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and the creative industries are an engine for Europe.
Therefore, we must also focus on this area within the realm of school and vocational education.
We must impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
We must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators, not only their entrepreneurial competencies, but also a good level of media literacy in the area of new technologies.
We need frameworks in which cultures can create livelihoods for themselves.
Therefore, we will need to engage intensively with the issues of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, as well as open access to information and content, in order to

to ensure that the creative and cultural industries thrive in a digital environment in the future and to be able to preserve Europe’s cultural diversity and cultural heritage as an essential characteristic of the European Union.
Mr. President! Dear Colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic States, dear colleagues! Today, we are particularly commemorating the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic States.
These expulsions belong to the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was called a century of expulsions, not only and not least for this reason, and not unjustly.
And we all bow our heads today in respect for the victims of these inhumane acts.
In this context, we demand a comprehensive investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the crimes of Stalinism.

Today’s focus on Russia should not be understood as a political attack, but rather as support for confronting its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is marked by both bright and dark aspects.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the following century.
We reflect upon the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
The deportations in Europe reached a particular peak in the mid-century through the Nazi regime and through the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
Expulsions following the Second World War also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav Wars.
However, we must also not forget that many colonial regimes were characterized by displacements.
We must demand a serious engagement with the various forms of dispossession and the specious justifications thereof.
This also includes the clarification of guilt and the punishment of the guilty, as far as that is still possible, as is now the case with Mladic, for example.

But the decisive answer lies in European unification, specifically through and with the independent Baltic states, and a clear commitment to continuing the still-incomplete European integration process.
And this historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but particularly to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries of Europe, both East and West, have worked on this.
Let us consider, for example, the Danzig Declaration, signed by the Polish President Bosniewski and the German Federal President Raus.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must remain vigilant even towards initial signs of displacement, as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all such statements, for example, the assertion that Arab migrants should be sent back in boats across the Mediterranean, and we must resist when some seek to dismantle Europe’s achievements of openness and return to a narrow-minded nationalism.

Let us bow our heads in Erfurt before all victims of expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously affirm our commitment to the continuation of European unification as the only true guarantee against

This is a policy that has brought so much misfortune to the people of Europe, and beyond, in the past century. Never to forget, never again—these were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have lost none of their validity; they are best preserved within a united Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, my esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I had the opportunity, as a parliamentary election observer, to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan, and I was impressed by the strong support of the South Sudanese people in wishing to determine the future of their country themselves.
I also observed the considerable expectation among the people, who viewed their country’s independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of so-called Internally Displaced Persons, driven by decades of conflict in the south to refugee camps in the north, embarked on a journey to their former homeland in South Sudan.

And naturally, the people of South Sudan, alongside the country’s independence, desire above all else to live in peace and to embark on a path toward a happier future after all those decades of armed conflict in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9th, the new state of South Sudan is now scheduled to officially become independent and expand the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are extremely unfavorable, and much has already been said about that here.
70 of the people live as norbanizing livestock breeders, 80 are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already casualties and wounded.
As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also escalating, and observers estimate that more than 100 people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and the violated are scarcely numbered.
Sudan already belonged to the category of failed states.
There is a risk that the state of South Sudan is already beginning to resemble a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that there is a significant obligation of Europe towards this region.

In view of the colonial past of those countries. Together with the UN and the African Union, a common European foreign policy is called for here, and it can demonstrate its effectiveness here as well.
This is not only about money, but also about supporting the delicate, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate firmly with those in whom the fate of the country rests, namely, the tribal leaders at the head of the military groups, that they not disappoint the hopes of their people in the country.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues! I am very grateful to my colleague Mr. Bartolozzi for initiating this request and bringing Mongolia to the attention of the European Parliament as the subject of a debate.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now treated from various perspectives in Parliament, Mongolia and its situation found only very limited resonance here.
Quite unjustly, it was Mongolia that, as a state of the former communist bloc, quite early utilized its independence and embarked on a path toward the democratization of its society.

As early as 1992, Mongolia adopted a democratic constitution, and since then, several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, proceeded in an overall democratic and correct manner – a development that is far from commonplace in states of this region.

The Mongolian government has been attempting to combat corruption through legislation for several years, and in 2010, it imposed a moratorium on the death penalty, a feat that even some large democratic states have yet to achieve.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this geographically large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, suffer the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
Thus, a largely still nomadically living rural population is pressing into the few towns that are not structurally prepared for it.
The country’s natural resources are not being extracted in an environmentally sound manner.
Energy problems are making civilian and economic life more difficult.
Squeezed between the major neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia faces the risk of becoming even more dependent on these states than previously.

The efforts and successes of Mongolia – and here I see the glass half full, not half empty, regarding the democratization of society – should be acknowledged, as they are exemplary for this region and demonstrate what is possible despite a difficult past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only within the framework of aid programs, but also by ensuring the European Union has a direct presence in the Mongolian capital with a
I view this proxy as a sign that the fate of Mongolia is not indifferent to us Europeans and that European interests should no longer be represented through Beijing. One sentence, please.
I am very disappointed that the Conference of Presidents did not show itself willing to further emphasize this concern by approving a resolution of the Parliament.
But very dear colleague, I certainly acknowledge this right.
I merely assume, and I hope you will also acknowledge the right that the position of the Dutch government is not proclaimed ex cathedra, but is open for discussion in a multinational democracy.
I have absolute respect for Mr. Rütte, who secured 2.7 increases in the EU budget.
I have taken note of that, and I am pleased that you listened attentively to me, because in this Parliament, the positions of all governments are openly discussed.
In that case, I haven't quite understood the meaning of your question, but what I believe I gathered is that you, too, are committed to democracy.
That is at least some progress.

Firstly, I reacted so agitatedly because I am still annoyed that we failed to secure a joint resolution on safety measures here, because the absolute assertion of a position was considered more important than consensus.

Secondly, I explained back then in the debate, and I am explaining it once more now, that I, too, have learned from this and now see that we must do more, exert more pressure, and show more initiative in the area of stricter regulations for European nuclear power plants.
That is precisely why I am in favor of a joint resolution, and that is why I believe we should support the Commissioner and not attack him constantly.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, regarding the intermediate category. Initially, I too, Mr. Pieper, would certainly have been able to envision other solutions, for example, granting transitional arrangements to the regions which currently have the highest demand and will no longer have it after 2013.
The discussion revealed, however, that we must consider additional regions, particularly those affected by the crisis.
We are currently discussing 51 regions.
And given so many affected regions, it would be practically negligent not to establish an intermediate category.
Only in this way can a reliable framework for the responsible promotion of these regions be established, which, after all, must overcome developmental deficits with their own strength.
Otherwise, the Pipa report reveals a great deal of both light and shadow.

We criticize, among other things, the lack of a clear commitment to a much more decisive fight against poverty and consider formulations, such as those contained herein, linking cohesion policy with conditionality that compels member states to implement reforms, to be unclear and very broadly interpretable.
The cohesion policy must remain an instrument of social equity and solidarity in all regions.
Mr. President, honored ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, internal regional cooperation will increasingly gain importance in the future.
Cross-border cooperation and macroregional collaboration are exceptionally important for achieving the 2020 targets in an increasingly integrated Europe.
Border regions still face particular challenges today.

Cross-border concepts and projects, such as those in the fields of infrastructure, corporate cooperation, research collaboration, labor market development, and vocational training, are a driving force for large parts of the European Union.
We require clear and simplified structures in the processing of interregional projects.
Different national requirements among project partners often complicate cooperation and the realization of concrete sustainable projects.
It is an important step that the PIPE report incorporates the demand for an expansion of the share for interregional cooperation under Objective 3 to 7, and I would like to strongly support this.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues, after almost three years of intensive work, after well over 3 amendments, after countless conversations, discussions,

Following the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, it is now put to the vote: the political package, the major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers regarding the future labeling of foodstuffs.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food products, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that is not all. The European food industry is also to benefit.
Legal certainty, deregulation, and improved legislation are the goals.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it is essential to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80% SMEs.
Simultaneously, this labeling must be suitable for every food product and every non-alcoholic beverage, from basic staple foods to highly processed ready meals.
Therefore, a mandatory label in traffic light colors is also not possible, because such a label simply does not suit basic foodstuffs.
Despite all difficulties, despite all political and ideological differences in Parliament, despite all national egoisms of the member states, the compromise now achieved is nonetheless impressive.
Allergens will be clearly identifiable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is an origin labeling requirement for pork, poultry, lamb, and goat meat.

For other products, a consequential assessment will indicate whether and how the origin can be specified, for example, for milk and dairy products, that is, products consisting primarily of a single ingredient, or processed meat.
Imitations of products etc. must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to form fillings and to compositions of form fish assembled from small pieces.
Packaging must not create the impression that it contains something which it does not.
If a picture of fruit appears on a yogurt, then fruit must also be present inside, and not just coloring and flavorings.
Additionally, the mandatory indication of the most important nutrients is always provided per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be labeled, the date of the first deep freezing for meat and fish, and many other details.
Above all, all information must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have established a minimum font size, and we have tasked the committee with establishing binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the text and the background.
At the same time, we protect crafts from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Unpackaged fresh produce must provide allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information, which requires costly analyses to determine.

The Commission did originally want this, but that would have destroyed our national and regional peculiarities and specialties, it would have led to a European homogenized mass, and that is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the reputable consumer protection advocates are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I therefore thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs of the Commission, in particular Commissioner Dalli, for his statements, which he will hopefully deliver shortly and with which the knot that has formed among us in political discourse will be untangled.

And I would like to thank, in particular, the Hungarian presidency of the Council, which achieved something that was almost no longer to be expected—almost the squaring of the circle, the agreement on this regulation.
Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, esteemed presidency of the Council of Poland, allow me to join your thanks to the rapporteur, Ms. Ojala Sender.
As already noted, the Council had blocked progress in this dossier since 2008, until a compromise could finally be reached under the Belgian presidency.
As stated, improved data exchange among Member States will, in the future, enable cross-border prosecution of various traffic offenses throughout Europe.
The paramount objective must be to enhance road traffic safety and to reduce the number of traffic fatalities and injuries.

Alongside Dieter Koch’s initiative report on road traffic safety, which proposes a number of highly specific suggestions, this directive can also contribute to better adherence to these rules through its repressive character.
I need not elaborate on the rules, as they have already been presented positively here.
The change in the legal basis, from European transport policy to police cooperation, has finally enabled the Council to draft a common position.
This, however, means that some countries, such as Great Britain, Ireland, and Denmark, are excluded.
Consequently, not all European citizens are equal once again.
Citizens must be clear about the rights they possess regarding data protection.
We have endeavored to strengthen this aspect to ensure that access to the collected data, their transmission, and their storage are regulated as rigorously as possible.
We were also deeply concerned with the information.
Mr. President! Although the current text does not fully meet the Parliament's expectations, I am nonetheless optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that we can build upon this foundation in the coming years to take a step towards a greater harmonization of European traffic regulations.
The revision clause added by the parliament would certainly permit such a course of action.
I deeply regret that this text has now been drawn into the vortex of institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament regarding the correlation tables.
We agreed during the trilogue to find an overall compromise on this issue through a joint statement.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues! First of all, my heartfelt thanks to Ms. Mac Matthias for this report.

Heartfelt thanks also to the colleagues who prepared the reports beforehand, Ms. Mörkis and Ms. Carvalho. This is a sequence, and the day is approaching when we will not only be making political decisions.
We must not only state this here, but also demonstrate that we are serious about research and innovation—that is the crucial question for the future viability of the European Union.
Therefore, I am very grateful that the representative of the budget committee also pointed out that sufficient, good financial provision in this area is an important matter.
We will shortly have to settle this dispute as to whether we possess the capacity to provide the necessary funding so that this area of research and innovation truly experiences central importance.
He is of central importance to the question of whether and how Europe will develop in the future.
Then, small and large Sunday speeches are no longer sufficient, but rather facts must be delivered.
Second Remark We ourselves will not be able to avoid, and this is very well elaborated in the report, also taking a close look at whether we cannot deploy our available resources more effectively.
How can we achieve simplification in the process?
Where are we headed with speed?
We are designing research funding more effectively.
How do we move from the currently still labyrinthine structure of diverse research funding towards greater structure and greater simplification?
Sometimes, less is more; few projects, but considerable investment, ultimately yield a greater impact.
Therefore, I am grateful that we have again taken a further step in this report.

Naturally, the European Research Council and the European Institute of Innovation and Technology will play a special role, and naturally, the area of small and medium-sized enterprises is an area that is important.

I have read it again. We also need a solution for the states that, in promoting excellence—which must remain the correct, imperative, and indeed the only principle—require an answer, as do the states that are not yet so advanced.
And this report also raises the idea of a potential competition, through which one might perhaps advance leading research centers in neighboring regions.
And that is an important task that still needs to be resolved.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! In light of the currently extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at the European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
Only in this way can we restore trust among our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report concerns the strategy for avoiding endless human suffering, resulting from approximately 35 deaths and over
2.5 million often severe injuries as a result of traffic accidents, and to avoid the associated economic damage of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of fatalities alone corresponds to what would be mourned in the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized commercial aircraft.
What wouldn't we do to prevent that?
The follow-on costs of accidents significantly exceed the annual total budget of the European Union.
Therefore, I am certain that it would serve us well to become sustainably active in this area.

Thanks to the constructive collaboration of all shadow rapporteurs as well as many colleagues, for the first time with this report we have succeeded in developing a unified, holistic, and coherent approach to improving road safety.

He takes into account the content of the UN Charter for Road Traffic Safety 2010, as well as the content and objectives of road safety work undertaken by EU member states and broader circles of civil society.
It encompasses first, ambitious yet realistic goals for the period until 2020 and with the SEERUM vision for the time thereafter.
Therefore, the aim is to reduce the number of traffic fatalities by 50, the number of children killed even by 60, and the number of severely injured by 40 by 2020.
That lies in the most fundamental interest of each individual within us, but also within our national economy.
We recommend that the Member States break down targets and methods to their respective territory and expect them to develop their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it specifies who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is far more than just the European Union.

In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the holistic approach signifies that member states, regionally or locally responsible enterprises, and indeed each individual road user, in the interest of their duty to participate, must assume responsibility.
And thirdly, it includes how—that is, with which instruments, activities, and measures—the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are only one strategy.
We cannot and will not forgo guidelines, recommendations, or assignments.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity, meaning that responsibilities and accountabilities have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission’s diverse activities.

However, as they originate from the most diverse Directorates-General, such as Transport, Economy, Consumer Protection, Environment, Communications, Research and Development, Internal Market, and others, they are not always coherent, frequently uncoordinated, and sometimes contradictory.
Therefore, we propose the appointment of a coordinator for road safety within the European Commission.
This avoids the permanent establishment of an agency for road safety, but significantly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as EU-wide data exchange while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six primary fields of action were identified.
It concerns humans as road users, traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking, and the special consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request your approval tomorrow.
Madam President! We should focus on urgent and essential issues in traffic safety.
I am very convinced of this, and from my perspective, it primarily concerns the two greatest distractors in traffic—namely, alcohol and excessive speed.
Here, the European Union also needs to have something to say and not just propose technical measures, which, in my view, are certainly good, but by far not sufficient.
Above all in cities, the lack of attention, the problem of inattentive drivers, is particularly dramatic.
Therefore, the speed must be reduced here.
I was very pleasantly surprised that a broad majority emerged regarding the recommendation of 30 km/h speed limits.

must be particularly considered, and that is also included, and I believe it’s important and good that vulnerable road users are finally brought into the focus of attention, and I hope that these measures will finally and definitively be implemented.
That seems pointless to me, but I would like to extend an invitation to you.
I have never seen him at the consultations regarding Rio or other major global conferences, but I have always heard him speak here in the general assembly.
I would genuinely like to ask you, colleague, to please join the committee!
Engage with us, submit your proposals, and then we will discuss your contribution further.
And the contribution you just made—there’s simply nothing to be done with it.
Madam President, Commissioner, thank you for the fundamental remarks.
However, these fundamental explanations do not constitute an answer to the questions that were posed.
For the questions are, indeed, aimed at ensuring that we arrive at results promptly.
The industries we wish to exempt from these additional burdens here, or where we want to establish fair conditions, require planning certainty.
Therefore, we require decisions soon.
We need swift decisions, dependable decisions, and also clear statements from the committee.
This process has been dragging on for a very, very long time.

We all knew that this was a very complicated procedure that we were entering into, but at the time, in the compromise regarding the Emissions Trading Directive, we also said: We will do this with the Emissions Trading Directive.

Only on the condition that the industries in Europe, which are thereby excessively burdened, can experience relief, because otherwise they cannot withstand competition with other regions of the world.
And I expect that what was the basis for business and the decision-making situation in Parliament, with the Council, with the Commission, will also be realized in that way.

I have some concern that, along the way, the circle of those affected is becoming increasingly smaller, that the consideration is becoming ever more petty, that more and more areas are being excluded.

But it’s not just about steel; it’s about aluminum, you know that, it’s about many other areas like chemistry, etc. And that one simply isn’t implementing what was, back then, the political basis of the decision.
Mr. Commissioner, you are right to point that out. The situation for industry in Europe has not become any easier since this decision, but rather more difficult.
We are facing an entirely new situation; we have a much more competitive landscape.
We are all striving for this and declaring here in Sunday speeches that the industries are a vitally important area for Europe’s future development.
Yesterday, we heard eloquent speeches.

I expect the Parliament expects – and I believe this to be the case – that what was agreed upon then will also be implemented now, and specifically to the benefit of industry, not of industry itself, but of the people who work in these companies, of jobs, and therefore of Europe's future prospects.
Do you know of any example that would actually justify the expenditure – we are talking about many millions, in fact billions – to develop these body scanners?
Are there examples that demonstrate an increase in security as a result?
Mr. President! I would first like to thank the representative of the Council for his very clear description of the current situation.
We have consistently heard in this debate that it concerns improving the situation for working women who are considering having a child.
In my view, the directive unduly rejects the increase of maternity leave to 20 weeks.
But do we truly believe that the decision to have a child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity leave?

As a mother of three children, I am very well aware that comprehensive concepts and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision for a child and to establish equal opportunities for women.
The present draft guidelines do not even remotely do justice to the diverse, in some cases very good, offer concepts and overall concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that address the situation in member states and societies, and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful thinking will not lead to a solution here.
Therefore, we must first develop a solid and realistic foundation for negotiations here in Parliament.
And the comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children have the highest priority.
This can be ensured in various ways with different models.
Someone who wants to force their way through a wall will not necessarily reach their goal any faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise opens no doors and builds no bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution and for more maternity protection, in order to move forward here.

I believe that we truly need to seek another approach, based on the Commission's draft guidelines, to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also protection for children in the first months of life with greater flexibility for different concepts in the individual Member States.
That will not work with the draft presented here today, which certainly did not have the support of the majority, as some colleagues have attempted to make clear today.

I would like to see a bit more flexibility here, a bit more realism, and a slightly better understanding of what the member states have already achieved, without questioning our fundamental demand for that.
Madam President, Commissioner! I would like to make a few remarks on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have done already.
Instead of preventing tax evasion, which would be sensible, or closing loopholes for tax offenders, what has been produced here is a Swiss cheese with large holes.
The proposed transition period of five months allows tax offenders ample time to transfer funds from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient to transform assets stored in Switzerland into a foundation's assets.
Corresponding forms are available at Swiss banks.
The German tax authorities received information some time ago regarding numerous tax evaders who have concealed their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals an amnesty, and tax authorities are no longer permitted to utilize the information available to them.
What kind of agreement ties down the tax negotiation?
Accordingly, in an advertisement for Swiss banks, it states regarding this agreement: Even in the future, customers will benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial center.

This agreement clearly lacks the necessary coordination at the EU level, and it also runs counter to the EU’s efforts to enhance transparency in tax matters, make tax collection in Member States more efficient, and, above all, to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, this cannot be acceptable from our perspective.
We support this agreement and we request that the EU, if necessary, strongly advocate against it as well.

Mr. President! Thank you very much! In accordance with the rules of procedure of this assembly and in consultation with the parliamentary groups, I hereby request that this matter be referred back to the committees.
Madam President! I am pleased that we have managed, together with Roberta Angelilli’s report, to launch a sustainable and effective directive, and I would like to thank her for it.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of one thing: to this day, the vast majority of crimes occur within children's closest social environment.
The perpetrators are found within family schools and circles of acquaintances.
And here we still stand at the beginning of our educational work.

Therefore, our children must be empowered—strong enough to have the courage to confide in someone close to them in a serious situation, but also strong enough to recognize dangers such as grooming when navigating the internet.
We must therefore work together to ensure that responsible media literacy plays a greater role in the education of our children.
In this context, education is of paramount importance, as many teachers and parents are simply unaware of what is possible with their children’s computers or mobile phones.
And I believe there is a significant need for catching up.

It is therefore to be welcomed that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, as authorities, but also schools and families, must do everything possible to ensure that such abhorrent crimes do not occur in the first place.
Consequently, more effective negotiation strategies for the EU with third countries, such as the United States and Russia, are also required.

Pages stored outside the EU can only be effectively and swiftly deleted if we also work closely with these countries in the investigation of the perpetrators and jointly send a clear signal regarding the respect for the protection of children from sexual abuse.
Once the perpetrator has been apprehended, the legislature has often been surprisingly lenient thus far, suspending the majority of offenses only on probation.
Here, the seriousness of the offense should be given greater consideration in the future.
Overall, however, it is important that the public debate continues, as the topic encompasses a wide range of dimensions.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, extinguishing operations before barriers, legal rulings, public education, and intensive scientific documentation of the facts must continue to be advanced even after the consultation tomorrow.
It is imperative that we do not simply fold our arms.
Rather, we must embrace the mandate for action of all, each of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Mr. President! For years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at roughly the same level.
In this process, the tasks of the EU have continuously expanded, and the financial requirements have risen significantly.
Thus, new institutions necessary for financial market supervision have been established.
To effectively fulfill their tasks, these institutions, however, require sound financial resources.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become readily apparent.
To strengthen the economies of these countries, a comprehensive stimulus program would be necessary.
Some economic experts even speak of the necessity of a Marshall Plan for the EU countries shaken by the crisis.
And secondly, the EU does not need austerity programs that destroy growth, but rather a growth-promoting expenditure program that secures work and income for employees and young people in the EU.
But what does the council do in this situation?
He shortens the draft proposal, which already falls far short of necessities.

If, in the current political climate, a reasonable increase in the budget cannot be achieved, then Parliament and the Commission should nevertheless do everything possible to fend off the cuts proposed by the Council.

Should we want a union in which the connecting element genuinely includes the conviction that we do care whether people have to live in poverty in any country, any member state of the European Union?
Do we see ourselves as jointly responsible for combating poverty and social exclusion?
Or do we opt for a union as it has just been outlined by the colleagues from the far-right faction of this Parliament?

Sometimes I believe that we, with the attitude of the member states and particularly some governments of these member states, are dangerously close to that vision of a European Union as it has been formulated by the far right.
You must simply avoid any shared practices, establishing no shared instruments, deploying no shared indicators, using vague formulations wherever possible.
The interim report makes this very clear in many respects, and I believe we must become considerably stronger here.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sell-off of public assets, the sell-off of social security systems.
We require social and ecological minimum standards.
Given the impending winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the street, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death due to rising energy prices.
Here, we bear a shared responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
For that, we must advocate, and not for this nationalist charade, which we have heard from the right wing.
What advice would we have given our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, when there was a depression, when financial markets were already undermining democracies, and when they were heading towards war?
I believe two things would be necessary: two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you must do, swiftly; do not allow yourself to be slowed down; regulate every product, every institution, and every player as such.
Mrs. Merkel has said. But a transitional government alone, which enforces the financial emergency program, cannot have a future if there is no emergency program for democracy.

That means, in this case, naturally we need a new European Community, naturally we need other treaties, naturally we need a system that works, but which only gains legitimacy if there are referendums.

And for that, we must already advocate that the situation has become so dramatic that a fundamental shift in perspective is needed, before the far-right, before national dividers gain the upper hand over something that has already been built.
Madam President! There is no doubt that this Assembly champions transparency and openness towards the citizenry.
That is also the position of my EPP Group.
However, the present report goes far beyond the actual objective.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are disregarded, and the protection of competitive procedures, sensitive, and personal data is neglected.
That, among other things, massively violates data protection, for which we always advocate so strongly elsewhere.
Should we now sacrifice the privacy of the global public?
Precisely this danger exists with the present report, because administrative processes and decisions, which, for example, also include personnel matters, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information within the context of authorization procedures, court proceedings, and competition proceedings.

With its vague, imprecise, and overly broad definitions, the report permits public access even to such documents, since a document is defined as all data and content standing in any connection whatsoever with the policies, measures, and decisions of all EU bodies and institutions.
This includes preparatory, confidential, and secret documents, as well as all associated information.
And thus, this definition encompasses not only documents, but also information.
Also, information from ongoing interinstitutional proceedings, such as from informal trilogue negotiations, should be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, because truly, what does that mean?

It means public access to the procedure, it means public influence on the decision-making process—then we might as well seat the lobbyists at the table and let them negotiate. Is that what the citizens want?
I cannot imagine that.
Furthermore, documents related to non-legislative procedures should also be published, as well as measures of internal administrative organizations, etc. Where is the public interest in that?
Or would it not rather impede our work?
I believe this report is not in the spirit of our citizens.
He would unleash a deluge of useless information.
He would render our work impossible, and above all, you have heard it from the commissioner—he is unacceptable to the other institutions because he violates existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and fundamentally you are working against greater transparency and against the citizen.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! With a topic as important and comprehensive as the White Paper on the Future of Transport, there is always the risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to squeeze in their two or three wish topics.
When we look at the outcome that will be put to a vote tomorrow, there is no doubt that we can congratulate our rapporteur, Matthieu Grosch.

He managed to distill several hundred proposed changes into a sound, coherent, and manageable result, which prioritizes safety, environmental protection, energy, and technology as key focuses for the future of transportation.
I expressly welcome the fact that important issues such as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are also appropriately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in light of the looming skills shortage in the transport sector, which requires active intervention if future bottlenecks in well-trained specialists are to be prevented.
Further liberalization of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair practices are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given a significant place here.
Road safety is a matter that will continue to concern us in the future.
I view other aspects more critically.
I would have preferred a statement addressing the Modern Shift, whereby more traffic would be shifted from roads to rail and waterways.
And for this reason, I do not believe the discussion surrounding Gigaliners represents the best solution for greater sustainability.
Equally critical is the continued liberalization of the railway sector and the opening of national passenger transport—one should await and reconsider these developments.
There remain technical harmonizations and fair competitive conditions to resolve.

But as I said, in this report I hope that expressing the expectations of Parliament here will not remain a pious wish list, but that a goal will be achieved by 2020 and our proposals will have become reality.
Mr. President, colleagues! It has been only 20 years since the Central Asian states gained their state sovereignty as a result of the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
Emerging from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a lasting challenge.
Nevertheless, these states are important trading partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
