It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU’s relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to facilitate collaboration and foster a spirit of partnership, though not to lead to one-sided stigmatization.
Child labor, and particularly forced child labor, remains an unfortunately widespread affliction in many countries of the world, which must be combated.

I do, however, point out that it was common practice in many agriculturally-defined European regions to extend children's school holidays during harvest time and to allow children from farming families the opportunity to assist with the harvest, which today would not be considered forced labor.
2. However, should there be indications of child labor in cotton harvesting in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence, however, must apply to all other states where child labor still exists, including those states in which we pursue economic interests of an entirely different magnitude, such as in India or China.
We should not apply double standards here.
Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues, I can only join the ranks here who have offered their congratulations to the Council Presidency.
You were not only an honest broker in difficult times, but you were also a European broker.

I believe that it was very pleasant to feel this in these difficult times, when we have political currents in a variety of member states that suggest to people that one could achieve more alone than together.
You have emphasized the common ground.
It was also very refreshing to see that you, even in the domestic political debate, have found approval among the people in Poland with this clear European agenda.
It wasn't entirely straightforward in this context.
And also for that, the highest respect for what you have accomplished.
We have been able to initiate quite a few developments, particularly in the area of financial market regulation, over these past six months.

If I may single out just one area that I myself was able to negotiate, namely the question of regulation concerning short selling and uncovered credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission was hesitant to propose a stringent regulation, where we from all

In the Member States, it was said, you will not succeed, and where, thanks to the Polish Council Presidency, it has been possible to sanction such a highly speculative instrument and where it is necessary to prohibit it, so that we can contribute to greater stability in the financial markets.
I would like to express my sincere thanks to your finance minister and the state secretary, who spearheaded this through a laborious process of discussion between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of what can be achieved together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Mr. President, thank you very much.
Since yesterday, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances has come into effect.
Meanwhile, the concrete substantive regulations are also available.
What developments does the Commission now consider dangerous, and what economic problems does it wish to correct?
A growth in unit labor costs in the Eurozone of more than 3 percent per year is considered a problem by the Commission.
A limit for decreasing wages, however, is not planned.
Inexpensive, dear Commissioner, does not necessarily mean good.
It is not enough to tailor the member states to achieving prosperity at the expense of trading partners.
Without investments in education, healthcare, and energy efficiency, we may exploit our workers to the bone, but we will not write economic success stories.
Another example from the Scorecard: The loss of export market share is to be reviewed and sanctioned.
That’s nonsense!
With increasing global trade, Europe’s shares inevitably decrease statistically.
Consequently, the indicator penalizes countries already integrated into global trade.
Therefore, we, the Commission, should withdraw this basket and subject it to a comprehensive overhaul.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! Firstly, I would like to join in thanking our rapporteur and all those who contributed to the report, because it is not a routine matter, even though we are addressing competition policy based on a Commission report for the fortieth time.
I am very grateful to the Commissioner, as 2010 was the year you first took full responsibility for competition policy, for the very comprehensive presentation.

However, I would still like to express the request, and you also addressed this in your contribution, that we need to work through—particularly in the area of subsidies, of public subsidies, in the banking sector—a certain degree of processing.
should arrive, because, due to the new stress test by the European Banking Authority, a new capitalization within the banking sector is already being urged.
I do not believe that this contributes to the stability of the banking system when, on the one hand, we still have a multitude of unresolved or outstanding legacy cases.
We have, in fact, already seen new cases arise because of the pressure being built to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the area of private banks.

Therefore, here my most urgent request, Mr. Commissioner, to arrive at a swift resolution, one that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector so that it can also meet the challenges in the international environment.
The second major topic of diffusion control will continue to occupy us significantly in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the continuation of the previously clear and transparent path that the Commission has followed within the framework of merger control.

I believe that it is in the interest of all parties involved, particularly consumers, to ensure that competition remains possible, even in larger or different structures—I don’t want to evaluate that further.
In that sense, my sincere thanks to everyone who contributed here, and I hope, Mr. Commissioner, that we will soon arrive at a solution, particularly in the area of banking.

Commissioner, you have just hit the nail on the head by noting, all of us together, that we are capable of initiating a third industrial revolution in Europe if we understand that we must perceive sustainability opportunities as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke of resources, and that reminds me of a thought I completely forgot today.
I, in fact, forgot the human resources in my office.
And Mrs. Philipp, allow me to say, you have toiled like a horse, your successes marvelous, you were a truly leading figure in this matter.
For that, I would like to express my gratitude.
Mr. President! Freedom of speech in parliament also requires a functioning microphone system.
The button for turning on the microphone has broken.
I would request that a technician restore the speech freedom.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! It surprises me that we repeatedly have to remind ourselves what structural and cohesion policy actually entails.

Cohesion policy and regional policy constitute one of the central policy areas of the European Union and, by definition, are intended to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, particularly by promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been demonstrated particularly during the years of crisis.

Many regions see the situation as considerably more difficult.
With regard to economic development, these funds would not be available.
The implementation of Structural Funds support is based on operational programmes, as has already been indicated, which describe the funding strategy of each region.
The European Union, Member States, and regions collaborate here in a partnership, thereby creating genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy also relies on the reliability of the programmes and the resources provided and available.

Therefore, I am very surprised when, repeatedly, both from Member States and, as we can see now, from the Commission's side, attempts are made to treat Structural Funds as a savings account for all sorts of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the spirit and purpose of cohesion policy and, furthermore, unsettles the actors in the regions who are already working towards achieving the objectives based on long-term strategies and contracts.
Undoubtedly, combating youth unemployment and advocating for economic growth are important goals.

This can only be achieved, however, if the collaborative partnership between the regions, the Member States, and the Commission is maintained, and the actors in the regions are involved and remain so.
For only they possess the knowledge of what needs to be done in their regions.
Cohesion policy and structural policy represent the unifying, collaborative, and solidarity-based framework for action among the various levels of governance within the European Union.
Within it, solidarity in Europe becomes visible locally, in the regions, and it should not be lightly abandoned due to political expediency.

Mr. President, Commissioner! I support the compromise found in Klojok, which aims to strengthen the bargaining power of dairy farmers vis-à-vis the processing industry, although I am aware that it does not resolve all the problems currently faced by dairy farmers in some Member States.
Already, Commissioner Mantzold had, 50 years ago within the framework of the Common Agricultural Policy’s preferential measures, planned for the establishment of producer organizations.
Even in my country, Luxembourg, the dairy sector, due to the high proportion of grassland, is the primary pillar of our agriculture.
Our agriculture and our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join together in a cooperative that handles the processing of milk itself.
Five member states voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet the requirements of a soft lending instrument.

The European Commission has the right of initiative with regard to legislative proposals, and therefore I would like to urge you to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament before the end of 2012 in order to rectify this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction of the super levy until 2015, charged per kilogram of milk delivered, or the abolition of the fat correction could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring regulation, without harming member states not affected by it.
The present milk package also serves as the final report of the High Level Group, intended to ensure a soft landing for the milk quota exit.
Remarkably, there is no mention of milk quotas at any point in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and in four other member states are attempting to prepare for the liberalization of the milk market and to expand their production.
If you want to keep pace with the global market after 2015, you can only do so by purchasing quotas even now, so shortly before the end of the milk quota system.
This represents a significant additional and unnecessary capital expenditure, disadvantaging them compared to their counterparts in 22 member states.
Question: Are you aware that we have community bonds already?
And that the resolution does not speak of Eurobonds in a general way, but of a great many different options.
And are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have again isolated generalities about Eurobonds here.
Precisely the level of differentiation we have achieved here with Ms. Gulaar’s excellent proposal is what we should not relinquish.
I would appreciate a bit more differentiation in your statements and am eager to hear your thoughts on that.
But it is time, I will say only very briefly, dear colleague Gouault, that this is not an assessment I have made here.
I merely want to point out that the last Italian government bond, before Italy joined the Euro, yielded 10%.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should now take that over.
It was, of course, standard practice to pay high interest rates.

And now suddenly, because we have had ten years of low interest rates and accumulated excessive debt, because money has become cheap for investments as well as for the public sector, then there’s a desire to extend this through Eurobonds.
This is a trap from which we cannot escape, and I maintain that.
Mr. President! Mr. Commissioner, your response has genuinely disappointed me somewhat.

You clearly want to stick with the existing system, which requires complicated negotiations per country and, in turn, does not grant further access to literature, meaning no more opportunities arise for the blind and visually impaired.

This makes it all the more saddening for me, because now the European Union is blocking a step forward in the VIPO, while all other or many other contracting parties would be prepared to move forward.
Here, a tremendous opportunity is being missed.

They are not fighting here for enhanced rights for authors, but they are fighting against people to whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is intended to guarantee equal access to cultural goods, and that they can participate comprehensively in these cultural goods as well.
I appeal to you. Please dismantle barriers and agree to a binding treaty.

Mr. President! The discussion here in this assembly demonstrates that we, so to speak, represent the entire spectrum – on one side those who desire no restrictions whatsoever, and on the other side those who equate every form of immigration with the endangerment of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this framework.
I believe that family reunification must be considered with great reason and also with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in Member States where unduly restrictive measures are being taken.
For family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that, in the end, no one is reunited at all.

On the other hand, it is entirely justified that member states, for example, require language proficiency, that they require integration, but also that they require a willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, Member States naturally have the right, and we should not dismiss these issues, the problems that arise in family reunification, to articulate them.

When countries like Greece or Malta, or indeed Romania or Italy, are no longer permitted to articulate the problems they have, in part, in this context, then I do not know whether we are democratic if we simply ignore problems.
I do not believe that we need a new directive again so soon.
We need. I believe we should carefully discuss the problems and then consider how we can eliminate them.
The constant re-issuance of guidelines does not lead to improvements in the guidelines and their implementation.
We are currently experiencing implementation challenges in some areas.

However, I also fully understand the need for us to first address the fact that we shouldn't be creating another new directive and adding to it before we have thoroughly discussed the existing directive’s problems in any way.
I am in favor of listening to the member states and simultaneously respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
And if one does this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will come to a good path.
Mr. President! Pomićl, Sanim, Pomiślich! Consider, before you think, urges the Polish aphorist Stanisław Jergelec, and this recommendation would occasionally benefit us even in this Parliament.
Few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia Strategy, adopted in this house, which assigned censures to the Central Asian states, strike events in Jena Ozen are now also…
in Kazakhstan, reflected without awaiting the results of ongoing investigations conducted with international participation.

As much as the deceased are to be mourned, and as much as the injured and those detained as a result of these events have a right to the processing of what occurred, the underlying causes remain obscure.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, meant this. This was a group of other people. The unrest is not in the interest of the strikers at all, because it only provides the pretext for taking action against them by force.
The Central Asia expert Arkady Dubnov also did not rule out the possibility that parts of the Kazakh opposition, living abroad, are also involved.
On the other hand, however, it could well suit someone in the Kazakh capital, Astana, to maintain the tensions.
Ultimately, Kazakhstan’s power elite are already vying for the succession to President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition here in Parliament, in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador.

The UN Special Representative Miroslav Jenscha announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government’s observation of the events by Jana Ozen, and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of UNRWA.
We should take the Khazar authorities at their word, measure them by their actions, but not arrive at reflex-like preconceptions.
As I understand it, the statement you made today is yes, the Commission is advocating for the continuation of the food program for the most vulnerable people in the European Union.
She will do everything to present concrete proposals in the foreseeable future regarding A where the program will be situated, B how financing will be achieved.
I consider this urgently necessary, and I believe that we share a collective responsibility to ensure that this food program actually becomes a reality.
Not because I consider it the ultima ratio, but because, from my perspective, it is a signal to show people that we still possess a fundamental feeling for the necessary solidarity with the

of the life situations of people in the European Union who, unfortunately, were unable to participate in a development and who have become the first and greatest victims of the way the European Union handled the crisis.
I am thinking of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where precisely what we do as the European Union primarily impacts the poorest of the poor.
We set a marker, but unfortunately, it is no longer one.
I therefore believe that it is urgently necessary that we not only demonstrate consideration for the 18 million people in the European Union who, at this point, are dependent on the food
to be made available, but rather that it concerns ensuring we place the fight against poverty at the top of our own agenda, either continuing to do so or establishing it for the first time.
This signal we have not conveyed thus far.

That, from my perspective, is the crucial point if we want to make further progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union, in order to truly shape a social and solidarity-based Union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments, which have toiled thus far, must abandon this stance.
I believe that is also a measure of self-commitment for us.
Mr. President! Esteemed Colleague Dohl, I have listened attentively to you.
What you propose – to include a growth assessment for all expenditures alongside the subsidiarity review – essentially means narrowing the objectives to growth.
I would like to know from you how you reconcile this with the expectations of a Christian Democratic faction, which surely still has goals beyond growth.
It should be generally known that the economy does not bring children into the world to raise, nor can it provide them with a life in a healthy environment.
This suggests, therefore, that the priorities are being altered by the Commission and also by the Council, that they are being reconsidered.
As a parliamentary group, we will examine very carefully whether what you presented this morning actually constitutes a change in priorities.
Until now, the motto has been: First the economy, which needs functioning financial markets.
Therefore, the initial focus was on restructuring public finances, that is, reducing debt and reassuring the markets.
And Mr. Daul, who is unfortunately not present, I actually wanted to say to him that I would handle it exactly as Georges Machait would.
I may not have understood his answer, but I would still disagree with him.
I believe the measures that have been initiated were simply incorrect.
You were not correct; it was not correct to focus solely on economic recovery while completely disregarding what was happening to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the Euro above all else and to say that what becomes of the people is entirely irrelevant to us.
But it must be the other way around. First, it is about the people, and then we can continue discussing Eurozone stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain drove the interest rates on Spanish government bonds above 6 percent, bringing them close to the level at which other states such as Greece, Portugal, or indeed Ireland sought support from the rescue fund.
The austerity policy, also imposed by the EU, the ECB, and the IMF on the member state, with the drastic reductions of public expenditure of all kinds of
The reduction of wages and pensions, the increase in value-added tax, and much more have burdened citizens, rather than preventing a renewed spiral.
Rigorous cuts in government spending exacerbate the downturn, drive up states' debt ratios, and that must be our shared realization.
When Mr. Draghi recently stated that the European social model is at an end, I am pleased, Mr. Barroso, when you say no, we in the Commission do not think so.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece, to Portugal, to Ireland, and to register precisely what happens there.
What happens to the people who currently have to fight for survival?
What happens, or what do we do together, to finally interrupt this suicide spiral that has set in, particularly in the most affected debtor nations?
It simply cannot be that we stand here idly by.
And we benefit from no social policy programs that will take effect only when other measures have proven successful.

We must act now.
Where have your goals from the 2020 strategy for combating poverty gone?
What has become of the European Platform Against Poverty?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the midst of the crisis, people need help, they need support, and they need the action of the European Union.
You do not need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will receive the support of my faction.
Support all those who, even within the Commission, have recognized the signs of the times and wish to change things.
But please don't just continue like that and say "It will."

But nothing more will be achieved if things continue this way. I urge you to propose a concrete project, a concrete program, outlining how we can now actively help the people in the affected countries.
Do something about it!
We will have to do this in our countries, to prevent being blocked and to ensure that funding for the ESF 2013 or 2014 through 2020, or indeed for the other programs, is not reduced.
It is important that the member states fulfill their responsibilities.
Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues! The current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a fairy tale about tax policy.
The situation in the council is quite simple: little progress is made there when it comes to tax policy proposals.
Why?
Because some countries are opposed to further tax cooperation.
You benefit from aggressive tax planning; you are tax havens yourselves.
And the contracts explicitly stipulate unanimous agreement on tax matters.
Therefore, the EU Commission has repeatedly suffered failure with its proposals in the past.
They are diluted, they do not progress as with the interest rate directive, and in more recent proposals, nothing ambitious has been suggested at all in anticipatory compliance.

I therefore ask you, Mr. Schmetter, I know that your job is not easy in this regard; change the strategy, propose decisive measures, and then rely on increased cooperation to end the blocking position in the council.
Mr. President! The present proposal will certainly not prevent state bankruptcy where it should occur.
But to do something is still better than doing nothing at all.
And exceptional situations sometimes require exceptional measures.

The budgetary and debt crisis in some states has led to such an extraordinary situation that important projects and measures within cohesion and structural policy can no longer be implemented, because the banking sector is failing as a financier and private investors are no longer available.
I consider an exceptional measure to be the proposal presented here for the creation of risk-sharing instruments to refinance projects in structural policy.
Means of cohesion and structural policy that can be used to provide financial security for already ongoing projects for regions wishing to utilize these instrumentalities.

I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Danuta Hübner, for her significant contribution to the clarification of the Commission’s proposal and for once again making clear when and how these instruments should be utilized.
However, I am also of the opinion that these risk-sharing instruments must be attributable solely to the current situation and cannot constitute a prejudice for the future funding period.
Mr. President! Our faction supported the request to conduct a review and submit four studies after three years, following an amendment to the biometric passports regulation of 2009.
And specifically also because she had repeatedly raised significant concerns for data protection law reasons and also regarding the review of the benefit of biometric data in passports.
Belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this method, and the resulting consequences – namely, the underestimation of other links in the security chain – are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this significant misconception, namely the assumption that they are immutable and the most trustworthy.
And that is decidedly not the case.
These data, too, are changeable over the course of a lifetime.
In children, they appear differently than in old age.
And for that very reason, reliable and reputable studies and conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues diligently.
We have now been able to determine,
As incidents in Great Britain and other countries repeatedly demonstrate, chips are in no way secure against misuse.
They are cheerfully cracked and can mean lasting damage for those affected.
Even the standards within the EU are extraordinarily varied.
The error rate is very, very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
And time and again, the question must be posed: what use are biometric data to us if documents are forged and circulating?
Therefore, if a link in the chain is falsified, if the source documents are inconsistent, biometric data will not further assist us.
A final point: The Chaos Computer Club in Germany needed only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

For this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, instant adhesive, a digital camera, and a little wood glue. In just a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. So much for the supposed security.
We expect the Commission to submit the studies, and of course, also the results and the consequences that are derived from them.
Mr. Councilor, the commission is unfortunately not as adequately represented today as I would have wished, out of respect for the Parliament.

As a Member of Parliament from a region severely affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, after careful observation of the debate, the question arises for me whether the unfortunately only marginally useful attempt

whether a standardization of criteria for disadvantaged areas truly addresses the needs in these regions, particularly as the necessary information for a meaningful and responsible decision is currently lacking.
Above all, I wonder whether a sufficiently thorough impact assessment was actually conducted.
To do justice to farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria, but also socioeconomic criteria beyond that.

Therefore, I urge the Commission to reconsider this important aspect, with the necessary time, detached from the overall package of CAP reform, and above all, after the presentation of the necessary documents and a careful analysis of the impacts, regarding the criteria.

I do indeed believe that we must also work, in collaboration with the asylum support office and the Greek authorities, to identify more quickly which individuals who have arrived in Greece may actually

can also be transferred to other countries of the European Union, because firstly, they can definitively never return to their home country, and secondly, they may also possess potential and qualifications that are meaningful and beneficial to all.
Essentially, however, it is also about helping the Greeks to enable registration and identification more quickly, in order to facilitate faster aid processes.

To return those individuals to their countries of origin who neither possess the qualifications nor the right to remain in Greece or the European Union, because they would actually have the opportunity to stay in their own countries of origin.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Madam Commissioner, and my thanks also to the rapporteur for her consistently dedicated and exemplary work.
Much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has voiced, I can share, support, or have partially supported.
However, there inevitably comes a point at which one must assume responsibility.
And for the EPP, or for myself as well, I therefore also maintain that we must now engage with realities and cannot retreat to ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact is, the USA have been collecting this PNR data for ten years, and there hasn't been a single complaint.
The fact is that we all don’t want to be in a position where we can stop data traffic, even with a negative stance; we don't want to be able to stop data traffic at all.
You had just done that.
It is also a fact that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a standstill.
And it is also a fact that the USA has a right to know who is entering its country.
And my assessment is also that the legal services have all verbally expressed that this agreement is better than the other agreement as alternatives.
Therefore, one must also assume responsibility here.
And that is what we were elected for.
Responsibility for citizens who would otherwise be left alone and with fewer protections and rights?
Would otherwise leave the airlines—and the Commissioner had emphasized this—in a state of absolute legal uncertainty.
Responsibility, however, also for the EU as a contracting party in matters of data protection and security, and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, we are, in sum, also in agreement, taking into consideration that this agreement is not perfect, but in the consequences of agreeing to this agreement.
If one wishes to better protect citizens and if one also wants to provide citizens with better data protection, one assumes this responsibility here and consents to this agreement.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the remarks you have given us were most illuminating.
Thank you very much for that!

Numbers sometimes say more than grand words, and to this day, the European Parliament – as you also mentioned – has granted almost 2 patents on plants and almost 1200 patents on animals by the European Patent Office, which originated both with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I would like to mention two outstanding examples: the granting of patents on genetically modified and bred barley – this applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Consequently, our farmers, brewers, producers, and indeed we consumers are affected.
And this example, in my opinion, demonstrates a devastating extent of patenting.
Secondly, consider the so-called Long Life tomato – not to be confused with its Long Life oil, which they have in their diesel engines.
Using this tactic by the applying US corporation Arcadia, this patent was obtained in contravention of valid EU regulations.
It is not the tomato Worden that is patented, but its genetic material, namely selected enzymes.

This demonstrates the tactics being employed here, and that, as you said, Mr. Commissioner, plant varieties and animal breeds, and a and b, essentially biological procedures for breeding plants or animals, are not patentable under Article 4, click and clear, of the Biopatent Directive of 1998.
We are of the opinion that this definition must be made more precise; it must be interpreted more precisely.
Technical procedures used to support conventional addiction treatment must not lead to patentability in its entirety.
We are not claiming a patent on life, specifically.
And we need a clear signal here for greater ethics and greater honesty in dealing with depletion, again against patentability of life across Europe.
Therefore, Mr. Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are prohibited in Europe and will remain so.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive: No Patent on Life.
And thirdly, Commissioner, we demand, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, a clear and unambiguous enshrinement of the breeder's and farmer's privilege throughout all legislation.
Madam President! I wish to address the termination of Europol and Eurojust.
Regarding Europol, there is little to no claim to be made.
The annual financial statements reflect the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects, and all underlying transactions are compliant with regulations and therefore also lawful.
Noteworthy are only the high allocations in relation to the overall, actually low incurred costs.
Europol attributes this to a relocation to a new headquarters, which is, of course, understandable.
However, Europol commits to taking further measures in the future to avoid such high transmissions.
Furthermore, Europol intends to commit to monthly monitoring of the budget execution, starting in 2012.
I recommend we keep track of this to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend relieving the burden on Europol.
Regarding Eurojust: Here, the financial statement reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects.
All transactions are also lawful and compliant here.
But high operating expenses were also carried forward to the year 2011.
The delay was primarily attributable to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure, and costs associated with data processing.
It is announced that everything will be improved in the future, including better adherence to tender requirements.
I recommend that we continue to review this in the future as well, and above all, verify whether all open positions will indeed be filled in the future.
It has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we would almost have to consider cutting funds, and that would be negative for Eurojust.
I still recommend relief. Thank you.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! What must alarm and cause us to panic is not the sheer number of young unemployed people in Europe alone, but the development of unemployment.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of young unemployed individuals increased by 26.5 percent, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only decoupling an entire generation from the labor market, we are decoupling an entire generation from a future worth living.
When we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that they turn away from this EU, because they lack reasonable employment and life prospects.

Sir Inspector, I urgently request that you ensure decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already recognize certain things, but please ensure that this long period of intellectual stagnation does not now devolve into operational frenzy.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program whereby young people, when applying abroad, are now also to be financially supported, then we are staging a traveling circus that does not solve the problem.
Conversely, it becomes counterproductive; then technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff will be poached from states that are wealthier, that are not experiencing this crisis.
Now, in this crisis, which is caused by this development, what is needed are proactive measures, namely the dismantling of this obsession with austerity that is impacting the European economy.
We need a targeted growth policy; we need a strengthening of domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that offers young people a perspective on life.

Final Remark

Raising the retirement age for people to 70 is also incompatible with this youth unemployment.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labor market.
Therefore, I earnestly request this, thank you!
Colleague, you have just stated that everything arguing in favor of a financial transaction tax would be speculation, and yet you yourself have come forward with highly speculative examples.

I would like to know from you, in light of what you have said, what you think of these investigations of the Commission and the Commission's study, which very clearly states that, up until now, insufficient attention has been given to the dependence of the real economy on

to the financial markets that 95 of the companies are in no way dependent on borrowing, and that a negative growth effect, which has been discussed previously, can indeed be turned into a positive one by issuing appropriate growth-promoting public investments.
Is that also merely speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded, comprehensive study by the Commission has its justification and represents a strong argument?

Mr. President! Yes, colleagues! The financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been discussed and debated for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She at least adopts the idea of involving financial markets in taxation, of taxing them, and above all, of making them contribute to the costs of the crisis.
I believe that is a very important signal to the financial markets.
That is also a very important signal to citizens, to our voters.
There were a considerable number of actions in a number of Member States, from petitions to written appeals to politicians, ultimately to introduce a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I believe that Parliament, with the majority that is emerging here, has achieved a significant success with this report, with this tax.
Certainly, this is not sufficient to stabilize and restrict the financial markets, as might be necessary, but it is a truly important step that has been taken.
I would like to expressly appeal to the council to take the voices of citizens and voters seriously and to advocate for them.
I hope that a genuine introduction will occur, that the introduction of this tax will not be blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I believe it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I believe it is a significant responsibility.

It now rests with the Council to act here, and I would like to use my allotted time to appeal to the Council to do everything possible to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality.

Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues! I believe that, despite all the detailed issues we can discuss and that will still need to be discussed in the further legislative process, we should be clear about one thing.
That must be clear. Financial markets cannot function according to the model where banks pocket the profits when everything goes well, but taxpayers foot the bill when something goes wrong.
And therefore, it makes sense to also subject financial transactions to taxation.
And it makes sense to do so cross-border.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we will not experience disruptions, but rather we will consistently contribute to establishing a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended to do, namely, that companies

Access to capital, meaning that savers have the opportunity to set something aside or to accumulate funds for retirement, and that financial markets thereby fulfill the task for which they were originally created – to provide added value for the real economy.
All of this that led us into the financial crisis were products that did not create value for the real economy.
Therefore, it makes sense to contribute to ensuring that this is severely penalized, sanctioned, and regulated – in the sense that capital once again fulfills its purpose.
Therefore, I advocate for this proposal with a large majority today.
Mr. President! The reform of the general preferential system was certainly necessary.
It is now beneficial that there are longer durations and that there is greater security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the development committee has already stated.
The committee unfortunately refers only to World Bank registration.
In this regard, Parliament has repeatedly and critically examined gross domestic product as the sole criterion in the past.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with 4 or up to 12 dollars of Gross Domestic Product.
This represents a vast, and indeed far too extensive, range, and it does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
That countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are eliminated, we certainly do not find concerning.
The reform in that regard was therefore sound.
But these countries are high-income countries, anyway.
Russia and China are countries, however, with upper-middle incomes, regarding which we certainly need not worry about their falling out of the APS.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer nations, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Until now, the Commission had also, at the very least, been applying the criterion of economic interconnectedness, i.e., countries that export little or only very few goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on the export of few products and are very, very vulnerable from being rated too highly.
Why, then, did the Commission remove this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji, Gabon, and Botswana will thus be excluded, although their economies fall under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why did the Commission not continue with the existing criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
The suspicion arises that the Commission intends to force poorer countries into free trade agreements that are disadvantageous to them.

However, the preference system is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays a role.
Fortunately, however, colleagues in the plenary session will still have the opportunity to approve our amendment, which incorporates vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also results in trade regions being fragmented.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to adhere to different rules when exporting to the EU.
That has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should increasingly take development regions into account, rather than individual countries.
Here, too, we Greens have submitted an amendment that we hope will find broad support.
It is also problematic when countries that yesterday still benefited from the APS are to be excluded from the program overnight.
Transition periods must exist, and we see that a few months are not sufficient for economic development, as is the case in our own countries.

Ultimately, as Members of Parliament, we must also consider whether we want to focus solely on speed with every draft law and then work with skewed compromises, or whether we would rather involve the entire assembly.

I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation, and also for democracy; it’s not speed that is important, but rather time and democracy are needed to enforce and properly enact laws.

Mr. President, High Representative! I, too, was a member of the European Parliament’s election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to witness the hope and expectation for a better future with which people stood and waited at the polling stations to cast their votes.
We know today that these expectations were not fulfilled.
Although the Democratic Republic of the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as colleague Delcheva also did in her report.

The former president, Josef Kabila, has appointed himself elector.
The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes have reignited between government troops and so-called rebels, and whether third-party states, such as Rwanda, are involved remains unclear.
Those who suffer are, in any case, the civilian population, which has now for decades been unable to live in peace and quiet.
The country’s wealth is squandered in a swamp of corruption, and the Congo remains at one of the lowest rankings in all international assessments.

International organizations, here particularly the European Union, must utilize their influence to increase pressure on the President of the Republic of the Congo to allow genuine democracy in his country. He has the opportunity at the next regional elections.

I am hopeful that the Congolese army will not also harass the civilian population, but will finally apprehend humanity's internationally wanted criminals such as Bosko and Djangga and hand them over to a court of law.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying any further weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, the human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Mr. President! Ladies and gentlemen, the Tupac proposal seeks to establish further intervention powers against crisis countries within the Eurozone.
The European Semester, created as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be given teeth.
According to the Commission’s intention, Member States should be able to be compelled to accept financial aid.
The Sixpack has already established extensive sanctioning possibilities that can be imposed on Eurozone states experiencing financial difficulties.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a sensible instrument for economic policy coordination.
Simultaneously, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with exclusion from the Eurozone should they make the wrong decision in Sunday’s election.
Why do we not cease these degrading and undemocratic displays of menace?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically escalated – I am thinking of Spain, of Cyprus – it does not serve us well to put member states already in crisis on display.
We should finally develop solutions. The rapporteurs of Tupac have indeed developed sensible approaches to this end.
I certainly received from Elisa Ferreira the suggestion regarding the redemption fund—a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
However, the proposal by Jean Paul Gauzet for an orderly state insolvency is also sufficient.
Central, however, is that Europe is undertaking a collective and solidarity-based effort to return the Eurozone to a path of growth.
The stronger nations in Europe must cease to be complacent and point fingers at their partner countries.
You must begin doing your homework, investing in growth, and taking responsibility.
Angela Merkel’s one-sided austerity policy has simply failed as a crisis solution.

Mr. President! Dear Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! In June 2010, the heads of state or government of the EU finally recognized that the European Community requires a better coordinated fiscal and economic policy.
At the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is indeed entirely correct that the members of an Economic and Monetary Union must not solely focus on how their policies affect businesses, workers, and consumers within their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.

An internal market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents member states with a considerable temptation, namely to create short-term growth and employment at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can lead to the economic and political disintegration of the currency union.
And the EU is currently facing precisely such a situation.

For years, the German economy has drained its neighbors, providing no impetus through investment and wage growth; instead, Berlin has nearly driven the Eurozone to ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.
Therefore, it is welcome that the Commission is now slowly and deliberately addressing this core problem of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making corresponding proposals.

Quite rightly, the Federal Republic is being called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare, and quite rightly, the Commission is being called upon to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to adjust wage growth to productivity growth.
This is a late, but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will vigorously represent this demand to the German government, even though there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, my esteemed ladies and gentlemen colleagues! Firstly, I would like to express my thanks to the Commission, particularly to Mr. Commissioner Barnier, for a very simple reason: the experience from the previous legislative period, the one preceding 2009,

It was clear that, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening, when the proposal of the European private equity association came about, Mr. McCreevy, the predecessor of Commissioner Barnier, had essentially let company law sleep deeply, and as in these five years, in this important matter that is also relevant for the internal market,
have progressed.
Thankfully, that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there is a wide range of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has been developed to address the issue of further developing corporate law, and we now have a very current consultation with which, as Parliament, we are naturally also engaging.
The Legal Committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this topic with the Commission and with Commissioner Barnier, and simultaneously to clearly outline our position from Parliament in a subsequent resolution regarding what should happen next.
I believe that it is necessary, similarly to what we have experienced before approximately ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European corporate law, and that for a variety of reasons.
There are gaps within European social law, genuine gaps that essentially mean the internal market has not been established.
I would like to cite as an example the absence of the 14th Directive on Relocation of Registered Offices, which, in my opinion, remains a highly typical example of such a deficiency.
The Parliament has demanded this twice in the legislative initiative reports, that concrete proposals from the European Commission be put forward.
There is also the expert panel, which the European Commission itself appointed, that likewise held the same opinion on the matter.
It simply belongs to the fundamental freedoms within the internal market that a company must also be able to move within the internal market with regard to its registered seat.
This option is not available today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this backdrop, however, I must also simultaneously criticize the fact that the European Commission's previous position on Directive 14/EC has actually fallen considerably short of Parliament’s expectations and, in our conviction, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
I believe we are cautiously optimistic that, within the scope of the further work, should an action plan materialize, this proposal will hopefully be incorporated into the action plan.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the ongoing development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens for businesses.
Here, we already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example concerning the topic of
Accounting, but I believe there is also more to be done beyond that and further aspects that will also be clarified within the scope of the consultation.
And here we also anticipate further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the topic of the European private company, which is currently stalled in the Council.

If there are individual member states – and I may offer this from my own perspective – if there are individual member states within the EU that, due to a lack of their own decision-making power, are not able to resolve the deadlock here.

To advance Europe, one must, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, occasionally consider utilizing the instrument of enhanced cooperation, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the committee to reconsider this matter with particular attention.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, that is, a sort of Rome Regulation for cross-border problems in corporate law.
I also maintain that this question requires further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the commission to do so.
And this is also closely related.
We have insolvency law, but there is already an announcement that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission within a foreseeable timeframe.
You see, there is an enormous amount to do in corporate law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has once again taken the initiative, and that it is apparent that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative term, which can then represent progress in shaping the single market.
I believe the parliament supports this in principle and in its approach.
The details, of course, will still need to be discussed.
But also, my sincere thanks to the commission.
And now, we would, of course, be delighted if the Commission were to take up our initiatives and translate them into concrete proposals.
Sir Inspector, I highly value your proposal concerning a performance-related pay policy.
But on the matter of the minimum wage, you held back from Mrs. Merkel, and the issue of employment development in the healthcare sector – I don't believe you.
How can new work possibly arise there, when the Commission has already compelled southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How can employment in the healthcare sector arise, when the Commission is compelling some Member States, in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, to further reduce spending on healthcare?
I fear that this point in this plan is pure announcement politics, not a genuine initiative for new work.
On the contrary, even today, due to austerity measures, there is a shortage of medical supplies and medication, not only in Greece.
I believe that whoever consistently establishes new safety nets for banks must now commit to a safety net for the people, particularly for securing medical care in crisis-stricken countries.
Mr. President! The mood among countless pro-Europeans like myself is one of frightened dismay over what is currently happening in Europe.
It is, at the very least, pleasing that it is now stated much more clearly what we are dealing with, and that the eyes are not closed even concerning Italy.
You know yourself that you are stuck in a number of traps, not only in those of debt and growth, but also in those of trust and the power trap, as well as the esteemed Commission and the Council.
You have, unfortunately, failed thus far to address the central question of detaching the financial sector from the real economy.

Everything we have decided here will be repeatedly assessed in expert opinions.
Furthermore, no serious limits have been placed on shadow banking.
Furthermore, we are still dealing with systemic risks. Furthermore, the question of "too big to fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little point in discussing the rating agencies.

I can only urge you, as you now work towards the European Council summit, also to advise you on restoring credibility in Europe by seriously addressing this power dynamic between the real and financial sectors.
To put it succinctly, that they are finally working in a credible manner before Europeans to ensure banks are held accountable and that citizens do not always have to bear the burden.

Dear Colleague Färm, you come from a country that rejected the euro, ostensibly with the central argument that it wished to retain the flexibility of devaluation, particularly for reasons related to social policy instruments.

In light of the experiences you have now had in Sweden, would you advise the Greeks to also leave the Eurozone, in order to be able to actively utilize this socioeconomic instrument of devaluation accordingly?
Mr. President! I would also like to express my sincere gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We passed this report in the Environmental Committee with a substantial majority, 62 votes in favor, zero against, and no abstentions.
That demonstrates that we are actually very, very closely aligned there, even regarding compromises.

And, of course, the highest priority in this legislative process must be a high level of protection, strong consumer protection, especially for the vulnerable, for children in our society who are in need of protection.
Regarding gluten intolerance, this is an issue, particularly in kindergartens.
Looking around, I have two children of this age, and considering the allergies and intolerances that prevail there, I believe we made the right decision.
And we should also discuss this with each other in the second reading, with the council, with the commission.
I believe that we will also arrive at a good result.
Mr. President! A report on a traffic accident over the weekend involving a truck driver who fell asleep due to exhaustion and ran off the road has once again confirmed to me how necessary it is,
is a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times, and their control via a digital tachograph, for us, for traffic safety, but also for those affected themselves.
The digital tachograph represents a certain innovation; it has introduced new problems, but also retains old ones.
The new problems arise from new possibilities for manipulation, which we also need to bring under control technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the control or lack of control in various member states.
But what we are now regulating, in my view, has to be considered substantially. Firstly, that not every time when no journey is recorded, a rest period automatically ensues.
For many drivers involve loading and unloading, and this is, of course, to be considered working time.
The second problem is that the speed records from the dossier were removed.
I consider that to be incorrect, as there are also significant accident hazards here.
We would also like to have weight sensors, and we would also like to have a hotline so that fraud can be reported anonymously and tracked.
What I will also submit is a proposal that animal transport controls be incorporated into this regulation.
I consider this important, because this, too, is a central element of our legislation.

Madam President! Many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have permanent disabilities if, after their accident, professional medical assistance had been provided quickly enough, that is to say, within the first so-called “golden hour.”
We would be a good deal closer to Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system, about which we are discussing today, cannot prevent accidents, nor does it relieve one of the obligation to provide first aid.
It serves solely to automatically inform an emergency call center in the event of a serious accident.
This must also, in order to avoid abuse and overload through minor accidents, establish verbal contact with the vehicle involved in the accident.
Only when the emergency call is confirmed or no one responds will emergency physicians, equipped with a few but life-saving pieces of information about the accident site, be dispatched.
Responsibility for the proper functioning of this rescue chain rests subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system remains dormant, transmitting neither signals nor data and cannot be located.
It is, therefore, also considerably superior from a data protection perspective to a mobile telephone.
The system only becomes active with automatic wake-up controlled by sensors, or with conscious manual initiation.
It then transmits a pre-agreed minimum dataset of information to a rescue coordination center.
Europe-wide uniform standards and specifications will ensure that these data, upon arrival, are recognized, assessed, and processed as emergency calls.
Therefore, Member States must also upgrade and expand their rescue circuits accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU-harmonized emergency number 112, to be free of charge for the user, to function everywhere in the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
These can subsequently also support other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or parking availability.
In recognition of the automotive industry’s remarkable achievements in providing private emergency call systems, these should retain their validity alongside the public 112 eCall system.
Users can also decide in favor of such a system based on comprehensive information.
This may coincide with cost and cost allocation.
the use of data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services, or other service providers.
Mr. President! A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme points to a small problem that we have created for ourselves today.

For if this brewery or beverage distributor is 107 kilometers from my place of residence, I no longer have any chance that they will continue to offer me their goods in the future, without having to purchase a new tachograph, without incurring new bureaucracy.

And therefore, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today, because I am of the opinion that we should not impose too much on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many points that we managed to incorporate, which were positive, thank God.
It was, after all, planned to accept only distances of up to 50 kilometers within the service area of a regional provider.
That was utterly absurd on the part of the EU Commission.
So, with 100 kilometers, it’s just about feasible.
But what if it extends beyond that?
I find that to be excessive.
And a final aspect. As a representative of a workers' organization within the CSU, I also say that we are establishing complete oversight of workers with this regulation.
why
Because, for instance, the person who builds or supplies beverages, who offers their goods to breweries, has their entire workday completely monitored via GPS.
Therefore, I also consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable, for data protection reasons, and I would like to reiterate why I voted against it.
Mr. President! Yes, thank you very much for that question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision?

I awaited the approval of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee, as we raised the necessary questions regarding legal certainty with respect to ACTA while the process was still ongoing.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
That is what they did not want. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used to delay proceedings; that is clear.
Why did I mention the extensive room for interpretation?
Because you have, in fact, posed two questions, I must answer both of them; that is unfortunately the case.
Because, namely, from these extensive formulations, one can extract and interpret the monitoring of the internet, auxiliary police officers, ISPs, and everything else.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty also does not assist our economy, dear colleague.
Mr. Leichtwelle, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
Or are you completely opposed to the rejection of all intellectual property?
And how do you envision the e-commerce directive being adapted to modern circumstances in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject a debate about these matters altogether and do not uphold the concept of intellectual property.
Is that correct, or how does it appear?
Mr. President! It is becoming clear that this is not about individual facts that we need to discuss, but about the fundamental question: How do we treat democracy and fundamental rights?
And when we examine ACTA, we find that it represents, in a sense, a symbol of opacity, of a lack of democracy, and a violation of fundamental rights, because it was devised in secret.

and, in a way, came about democratically because the free use of the internet simply might no longer be possible afterwards, nor the freedom to utilize generics to the extent that has been the case so far.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and already voted on ACTA.
Yes, votes have been cast regarding ACTA on the streets, online, with respect to the petitions committee, in numerous countries, not just within the EU.
Also outside the EU. And I believe we must not ignore this vote; it is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who have elected us.
I can only tell you to file ACTA away; that would be decent.

Madam President, Madam President of the Council! As rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have concluded two procedures under your presidency: the budgetary rules, which establishes a framework for the coming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation had been pending in the Council, and you have brought this procedure to completion based on the results of the Polish presidency.
I would like to thank you, therefore, for two particularly dedicated civil servants who processed these dossiers, and also Ambassador [Name].
You will be missed, his efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
You have truly earned the financial interests of the European Union.
Heartfelt thanks!
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here as a representative of my parliamentary group and would like to support the motion proposed by my colleague Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This necessitates careful handling of the subject of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an opinion in order to clarify still-outstanding questions.
I believe that respect for the Court of Justice of the European Union alone dictates that we await this decision.
There is objectively no reason to make this decision today.
No one will be prevented from voting against it once the court has presented its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that will then be made will occur within a different awareness and a different understanding than today's.
I do not mean that those driving on the wrong side of the road on the internet highway should determine our policy, and therefore my request to support this proposal.
Mr. President! As always, when my colleague Mr. Turmes speaks, it is very insightful, and one would wish that what he says had much more influence on European policy.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Naturally, these project bonds are a sensible idea, but only if they are sustainability-oriented and if the necessary political groundwork is also established.
We risk insuring risks with guarantees that we do not have politically under control.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany would require 8,000 km of grid network, yet only 100 km of these corresponding high-voltage transmission networks have been built, partly due to resistance from citizens—and, incidentally, from ecologically minded citizens.
We need the political establishment to come up with something.

One idea would be to create shared utility corridors, that is, not only combining high-speed rail lines with broadband networks, but also constructing the cable networks above them alongside the highway.
That, however, requires a far more comprehensive planning process than has been foreseen thus far, but I would at least like to suggest this here.

Mr. President! Esteemed colleagues! I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements within the European Union. However, I am also aware that borders remain a very sensitive topic for our member states, and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems existing between Member States regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
There exist various problems.
Ignoring problems does not improve them, nor does it resolve them better.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and here, no one would ever consider wanting to close the border again, simply because we are experiencing problems.
But I also ask the Commission in this area for support, and not for restriction and correction.
The border controls have been established because we want to guarantee security while simultaneously maintaining freedom of movement.

And should we conduct the border negotiations successfully, I am currently participating in them at the borders, including in the Czech Republic, where one or two drug dealers are not just in a few instances, but in many.

If we are attempting to create a transition in these cases, then I believe it would be beneficial if the German Federal Minister of the Interior and his Czech counterpart were to meet to jointly resolve the problems that exist at the border.
And this is something the Commission should not influence through regulation, but rather positively and supportively.

We want to contain the populists, but resolve the real problems together. Therefore, I also ask the Council to work with the Parliament to find a solution so that we can successfully adopt the Schengen dossiers, ensuring freedom of movement while simultaneously guaranteeing the security of citizens.
Mr. President! The instances of disproportionate border controls listed by the Parliament in its question also demonstrate why the Council wishes to exclude the Parliament from Schengen in principle.
The council intends, however, to continue undermining freedom of movement without involving Parliament, without any form of parliamentary oversight, without any form of public scrutiny.
No wonder, then, that you prefer to pat yourselves on the back in back rooms, away from uncomfortable questions.

It is no surprise that the German government wants to rule out an evaluation of the internal borders entirely without conducting an evaluation itself, and thus does not want to examine to what extent freedom of movement is being restricted.
Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe, and therefore also belongs within the European Parliament.

Mr. President, esteemed President of the Council of the European Union, esteemed Dimitris Christofias! It is a special moment for me and for my parliamentary group to be able to welcome you here in your function as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person at the head of the EU stands before us, whom we consider to be a member of our political family.
You assume the presidency at a time when the European Union faces immense challenges, and it is imperative to determine the course it will take.
whether the Union will actually have a future, or whether it will prove to be a historical defeat, a mere footnote in history—that, from my perspective, would be the case.
Following the discussions we have had with you, with representatives of your government, and with the chairmen of the factions and parties in your country, I know that you are committed to this.
have excellently prepared for the new presidency and that you are also aware of the magnitude of your task.
But, and as you have also made very clear today, you intend to deliberately draw the attention of those in power to the living situation of the people.
I can tell you here, after everything I have heard in recent years, that it is the first time a President of the European Union has actually done and announced and said precisely this tone.

Therefore, I have long observed the absence in official speeches of the statement: It is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for this crisis, yet who bear the brunt of its burdens.
It will be difficult to implement this very approach.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and you will do that too, I am very sure, if you above all encourage people with your presidency and in the way you
to exercise their right to advocate for themselves and to contribute to ensuring that the Council and the European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We repeatedly discuss the euro and its stability, the necessity of which I also see, that it is important for the functioning of the European Union and for the Eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which have been defined.

It can never be the aim of the European Union to accept, for the functioning of the euro, that people within the European Union must suffer hunger, that healthcare systems collapse, or that local administrations are forced to cease their operations.
Something has become twisted here.
It is not what we can designate as the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that it concerns social cohesion, solidarity between the individual member states, but also between the most diverse population groups.
The European Union must not simply allow itself to be used as an instrument or as a spokesperson for a small, specific stratum of the population, nor present itself as such.

And one final point I would also like to address, naturally, to underscore that everything you’ve mentioned in your priorities is important to us, and that we will support the points that move in that direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people no longer live in fear.
Anxiety is the worst advisor for democracies.
And I think that some decisions in recent weeks and months, particularly in the elections in Greece, in the votes on the referendum in Ireland, have also been shaped by fear.
And if those in power in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Wishing you much success in your work!
I believe we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs working together.
It will be very important for the colleague to work on this dossier swiftly and reliably in the coming weeks and months.

Currently, eyes are on us and on the Council, urging us to take this step – to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step of European integration, namely through a European banking union.
It must be said that Parliament demanded this with a large majority already two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in that direction, but unfortunately not as far as would actually have been necessary.
Further billion-euro invoices have resulted from this.
It is good that the council has now drawn the necessary conclusions and wishes to further deepen this step for the Eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has developed the proposals so swiftly.
The decision by the Council that the ECB should become the location of the Eurozone supervisor, however, is associated with some difficulties.
In the council, this leads to unanimity, and it results in the Parliament not having a co-decision role in this dossier.
After the experiences with the supervisory package, this is unacceptable.

And therefore, it is important that we work swiftly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal regarding the changes at the ECB with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby effectively establishing the principle of parliamentary democratic participation.
Democratically, there are further challenges as well.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has not previously had any tasks.

If she now assumes responsibility within banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary powers, full control rights, the right to question, and appointment rights—and I am certain that Parliament will assert these in a broad majority.
The complex questions regarding the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility, we will thoroughly discuss in the coming weeks.
Mr. President! With the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to force them into free network agreements.
They are not these free usage agreements, as the term "economic partnerships" suggests, but concern only the interests of the EU and not the development interests of the partner countries.
