That runs completely counter to the EU’s objective of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with that goal.
Countries like Cameroon, Côte d'Ivoire, and Namibia would be significantly affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects, such as those in South Africa, would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade globally while simultaneously implying that other countries should obligingly purchase our goods.
If the Commission genuinely believes that trade can foster development, then it should not block it.
The Committee on Development of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
And to that, we should join in the plenary session.
Mr. President! Both in Central America and in Peru and Colombia, there are immense problems in the area of human rights.
And we, as Members of the European Parliament, cannot simply turn a blind eye to it.
We will thoroughly examine the roadmap for human rights requested by the EU in the cases of Colombia and Peru, should it be created.
It must possess substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of criminals and the safe return of displaced persons to their homeland.
And of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.

We Greens believe it is right that the Committee on International Trade is demanding environmental and social standards in the draft regulation on safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue must confirm this as well, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
Indeed, the EU must do far more to keep a close watch on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.
And that is why we Greens are also demanding a proper impact assessment prior to each negotiation, one that not only examines the economic consequences for the EU but also the impact on human rights.
Mr. Barroso, I made it clear in the first round already what I wish to prioritize.
My concern relates to the expectation of my faction regarding the Commission, that it fulfills its responsibility in the relevant bodies, such as the Troika, to make it clear and unequivocal that we

We, as a commission, as a European institution, stand for the principle that people should not be driven further into poverty, that working hours should not be shortened, and that ecological and social standards should not be undermined.
This is your task.

And if we succeed in making that clear, then we also send a signal to the people who are protesting by the thousands, by the hundreds of thousands in these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we, as a parliamentary group, also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
This morning, I heard the news that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and striking.
Where have we arrived, that individuals experiencing profound social and personal distress can no longer receive any assistance or support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here, we must finally become active.
And I would add one more point: an approach that prevails in the minds of many decision-makers is that the people in Greece and other states have lived beyond their means.
You must be punished for this today and must endure sanctions.
It is unsuitable to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I do not impute that to you, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that permeates many countries and unfortunately also repeatedly surfaces in my own approach.
Mr. President, I confess, I have miscalculated.
I do not wish to make a statement regarding this report, but rather to address the report by Moreira concerning the Agreement on Immediate Autonomous Trade Preferences for Pakistan.
Please call me back again.

Madam President! The new directive establishes a framework for dealing with books, newspapers, works of art, films, musical pieces, and television productions that are subject to copyright but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or located.
Consequently, books, films, photographs, or other intellectual creations for which no rights holder can be found should also be made available to the public.
And so a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us in the Culture Committee, it was particularly important in this legislative initiative to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the European Union’s cultural heritage.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting corporations, there are countless unused works, and they have hitherto been unavailable solely because the rights holder is unknown.
That changes with the directive.
It will enable the future utilization of this cultural asset, provided that a thorough search precedes publication.
This is a very important point to prevent the careless statement "We cannot find the rights holder."
For a balance had to be found with the very real rights of the creators of works and the need of the public as well to be able to utilize such works, where the legal situation is not ascertainable.
A particular focus for us has also been to ensure that both known and unknown rights holders are fully protected.
And where the rights holders are not ascertainable, the draft legislation makes the digitization of orphaned works possible.
Projects such as Europeana and other large European digitization initiatives, as well as our museums, archives, educational institutions, and public broadcasting, will commence.
In the future, however, it must also concern itself with opening up the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers to the public as well.
This draft guideline and the compromise now found, in my view, truly represent a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural heritage, which is too great, holds enormous potential.
And this is something we should continue to work on when revising the guideline in two years’ time.
Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would be pleased if we could also include clarity in the proposal of 2013.
The signals from the Council would show how we in Europe can expand growth and competitiveness potential and, above all, how we can provide employment again for young people.
Could you please inform us in which budget lines you intend to promote youth employment and prioritize entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises here?
We know that the CIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts here from the council.
or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs Programme, or the programme for media pluralism—here, there are only cuts.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by implementing cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is to be proposed by the Council.
Where is that to be found within this household, as submitted by the council?
Mr. President! North Sea Works Emmen was compelled to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was unexpectedly not extended.
This company, with 700 skilled positions, is undergoing a transformation from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

Now, the idea is that this company can be rescued through a mass credit and that the jobs can also be saved, because the 700 colleagues at Siak and Nordseewerken have already had to accept considerable reductions in wages.

Therefore, I request that the Commission examine this procedure benevolently, but also promptly, so that these 700 jobs are not jeopardized, as these 700 jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize sustainable energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues suffer as a consequence of the state government's inadequate crisis management.
The assets of Villueux often appear harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can use them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile software from Nokia Siemens Network that enabled Iranian security forces to suppress the source of the Green Movement protests.
Protesters were mass-arrested, detained, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is but one example of many.
Furthermore, the Commission also promotes these questionable dual-use goods, as it states, through a catalogue of measures for innovative and competitive security industries.
The aim is to establish, as it were, a better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy, quite literally selling off human rights, as well as our security interests.
Therefore, I would like to ask you to approve the proposed amendments from us and the Social Democrats and ALDE.
I would like to ask Colleague Regner, what do you think unions could do, for example, to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will be insufficient.
What active role could the internal market play here?
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! I believe that with today’s debate on MiFID, we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
In this legislative period, the focus is on regulating financial markets, and not merely examining individual products, as we have done in the past.
I would like to mention just a few key points.
We certainly didn’t make our work easy for each other last year.

We conducted a hearing in the committee, questioning all stakeholders and interested groups, and on that basis developed a result—incorporating various processes, working documents, and the like—which we will present to the full assembly for a vote today and tomorrow.
I would like to highlight a few key points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

On the one hand, we must naturally acknowledge that significant developments have occurred in the financial markets in recent years, and it is in the interest of Parliament to ensure that every transaction in financial instruments takes place within the MiFID regulatory framework. This is why, under many conditions, we are considering a new category

as have been agreed with the so-called Organised Trading Facilities, where only Non-Equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is prohibited, and where, according to execution and transaction and client interaction, appropriate execution can take place at their own discretion.
I believe that we are making an important contribution to ensuring that the entire area of OTC papers, which are traded, is handled within the MiFID world.
Another significant topic that was not yet considered in the previous MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here, too, our aim was to establish clear rules of engagement, ensuring that this area, which can be very dangerous and can also be used manipulatively, is subjected to strict regulations with minimum holding periods.

with possibilities for trading interruptions, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the possibility of a supervisory structure, to examine algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price increment, and through appropriate fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of genuine (or true) futures markets.

I do believe we have a particular responsibility here when it comes to restricting the speculative element in genuine futures markets so that we do not contribute, through misguided regulations, to a situation where people in the third and fourth worlds can no longer afford to buy food.
Therefore, we have chosen a two-part approach with the aim of curbing speculation while avoiding damage to the real economy.
With position limits, with strict upper limits for the number of contracts or positions, we aim to achieve this.

We also want to ensure, for those who can demonstrate a genuine need for a product, that they do not suddenly engage in speculative activity in this market as well, through a so-called Position Check System.
Another topic that occupies us significantly is the area of investor protection.
I would merely like to point out here that we have adopted a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
Here, the objective is to identify the needs of specific customer groups.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex instruments.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product reviews, telephone recordings, relevant consultations, disclosure obligations, but I also want to briefly allude to subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member States shall, in accordance with their structures, have the possibility to make corresponding adjustments.
I believe that we are on the right track.
Upon completion of my allocated time, I would like to thank all those who have contributed here.
I find it regrettable that one receives only four minutes of speaking time for such a complex dossier.
Therefore, I would like to thank all colleagues who contributed here, and the commission for its very constructive role in recent weeks and months.
I hope that, with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow, we will be in a position to enter negotiations with the Council, in order to close this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you.
Mr. President! Dear colleagues! First of all, thank you for the generally good collaboration on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal, which had already taken significant steps in the right direction, in key areas.
Within the realm of market structures, there will be greater transparency, indeed more comprehensive transparency, particularly in the area of derivative trading.

Within the framework of MiFID, the resolutions in the area of high-frequency trading of our compromise extend considerably further than what the Commission originally proposed and deserve support, particularly from the Parliament as a whole.
And even in areas that have provoked considerable public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

Even in the area of commodity and food speculation, after major and difficult debates – and this must be said – there is now considerably more emphasis than the Commission's resolutions, because position limits are now contractually binding there.
We still need to make further changes in this area, however, to close remaining gaps.
I also hope for supplementary input here through the plenary vote and ultimately, in the trilogue.
It is pleasing that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament’s more far-reaching proposal.
However, the report’s weaknesses lie in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the opportunity to prohibit products, which is a step forward, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
The distribution of financial products remains oriented not primarily to the interests of customers, but is strongly dominated by which product yields the highest commissions.
Even in Germany, but throughout the EU, consumers have lost a great deal of money.
Think of open-ended real estate funds.
For citizens in countries like France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The fundamental principle will continue to be commission-based motivation.
To invoke subsidiarity here is rather simplistic.
Here, I would have wished for stricter regulations.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues! Yes, what takes a long time eventually turns out well, I can only say.
The report on type approval for vehicles in category L has, in the end, become a good report after all.
The work took longer overall than we all thought and, above all, than we had hoped, and there were far more pitfalls than we ultimately would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to express my sincere gratitude once again to the rapporteur, Mr. Van de Kamp, for the truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we were still able to achieve a great deal in the negotiations with the member states.
As rapporteur for my group, I recommend approving this report. Nevertheless, it could have been much better.
And with better, my highly esteemed colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, vehicle safety and, consequently, the safety of drivers have been our priority from the very beginning. Particularly the safety of scooter riders, motorcyclists, and drivers.
The number of motorcyclists involved in accidents, however, has remained constant for years.
In this case, the figures for traffic fatalities generally decrease across Europe, but this trend does not apply to motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads – that was and remains my goal.
Every death is one too many.
Especially in a regulation so beneficial to the internal market, this topic must be addressed intensively.
That this can be achieved through effective technologies such as anti-lock braking systems, or ABS, I remain convinced.
And I am equally convinced of the cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

We have nevertheless achieved that, from 2016 onwards, all new and from 2017 onwards, all existing motorcycle types with an engine displacement of 125 cubic centimeters or greater must be compulsorily equipped with ABS by the manufacturer.
With motor scooters, we can expect manufacturers to equip them with ABS or combined braking systems.
At this point, we must unfortunately concede that we have not achieved any improvement over the Commission's proposal.
I would have wished for much more here, but the Commission and Member States have, to put it mildly, shown themselves to be very cumbersome.
We did, however, succeed in having the Commission present a report in 2019.
The report must be fed with traffic accident data from the member states and should examine the mandatory installation of ABS for motor scooters.
It will also be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
Based on this report, the Commission will then consider making the installation of ABS in Rolla mandatory.
You see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will endeavor to close the binding legislative gap starting in 2019.
I am confident that the collected data will substantiate my findings.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for riders of two-wheeled vehicles in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future.
Mr. President! Mr. Matthias Groote, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
And I believe that applies to what we are discussing here today as well.
I am very much in favor of us discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new addition to the energy markets through unconventional resources, namely gas – predominantly gas, but also oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to succumb to excessive euphoria regarding the great gas future. It is just as inappropriate as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, painting apocalyptic scenarios onto the wall that have nothing to do with reality.

I believe we must keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to transform all existing energy supply relationships between providers and consumers, and that the economic viability calculations of previous energy sources are also being called into question.
We must confront the development.

I believe that we should acknowledge that this can also be an opportunity for Europe, and not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to view and utilize new technologies positively, to fairly weigh opportunities and risks, and to avoid falling into ideological debates.
Mr. Commissioner, your response does not entirely satisfy me.
For I consider a year to be a very lengthy timeframe between the notification that a complaint has been received and potentially receiving a response so late.
I believe that a complainant, who has taken the trouble—and he usually has already exhausted all legal avenues in his own member state—deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If they do it in this way, we should treat them accordingly.

And I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have here a procedure that is clearly formalized and that regulates rights clearly. This is now an explanation of how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point, I have no objection if it serves the purpose of jointly seeking a mutually agreeable resolution with the Member State.
That will not always be sufficient.
We observe that, for example in economic matters, progress tends to be relatively swift when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

But when it comes to environmental issues and similar matters, where a very, very large number of citizens demand the activity of the European Union or also social rights, then the process proceeds somewhat more arduously.
I believe that these facts, too, must be considered clearly.
And I would like to see, for your next report, a clear formalization of the complainant's rights vis-à-vis the Commission—one that is truly explicit and effectively communicated.
Once again, if we truly want European law to be applied after we have put so much procedure into it here in the European Parliament, in the Council,
we have decided jointly. Then we must inform those who are responsible for it, those who are truly, so to speak, engaged at the European level, as well and as precisely as possible.
This is a matter of great, great concern to me.
And I will also carefully observe again next time what has developed here.
Mr. President, colleagues! Five years ago, the EU’s Central Asia Strategy was launched.
When assessing the balance sheet of this strategy today, the evaluation is ambivalent.

We observe how individual Member States strive for good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries of this region, while, on the other hand, progress in their endeavors does not advance.
to accompany member states in their transformation process towards modern democratic societies, or, as recent events in Kazakhstan demonstrate, the development is even marked by regressions.

Nevertheless, or precisely because of this, the European Union and its member states must express their influence in this region more strongly together, including and especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU states.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only result in competitors for influence in this geopolitically important country—to which pressure regarding the observance of civil and human rights is not so important—being able to assert their influence even more strongly than previously.
The linking of economic interests with the advocacy of citizen's rights is the core element of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also form the basis for the subsequent negotiations regarding a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report offers good orientation on this matter.

Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council, perhaps you are following us via the Parliament’s video stream, as you clearly have neither the capacity nor the inclination to speak with us live.
I regard the Council’s absence here and today as a gross disrespect of the Parliament.

Instead of avoiding this debate, you should rather reveal your secret as to why you are rejecting any improvement of the protection of personal data in the area of police and justice through a directive.

Police and the judiciary have for years – as we know – been an Eldorado of violations in data protection, not only concerning SWIFT, but for example in daily practice, where data of citizens, who for example demonstrate against Nazis, are unlawfully collected and stored.
We need equal protection standards for the public and private sectors, and for law enforcement and the judiciary—this is about guaranteeing civil rights.
If you demand that Parliament constructively participate in data protection-relevant regulations such as EU PNR or Europol, then conversely, that must also apply to the Council.
Therefore, I demand that you finally end the policy of obstruction in the area of data protection!
